PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of today's Press reports of continuing repression of people in Poland by the martial law authorities? Is the Minister aware of yesterday's Press reports that last week some 117 civilians were arrested and 40 persons were sentenced to prison for breaking martial law regulations? Is it a fact that our noblest peak, Mount Kosciusko, was named after the great Polish patriot who fought so valiantly against Russian occupation of his country in the 1790s? Mindful of this strong symbolic link between our countries, will the Government convey to the Polish martial law regime its strong condemnation of the continuing repression and deprivation of liberties being suffered by the Polish people, particularly the industrial workers and farmers formerly organised by Solidarity ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government has been very active in response to the martial law proposals and activities in Poland. To instance some of the things that the Government has done I mention that Australia has joined the Western allies in calling for an end to martial law, the release of the detainees and the resumption of genuine dialogue. We have conveyed our condemnation of martial law to the Polish and Soviet governments, told the Polish authorities that in the present circumstances we are not prepared to conduct normal bilateral relations with them and continued to defer a recent Polish request for further economic assistance. We have also indicated to Warsaw that the roll-over provisions of a current government guaranteed credit facility are dependent upon the prompt payment of accounts as they fall due and that the option to cancel or suspend those provisions remains open to the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We have supported Western moves to condemn martial law in international forums such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. We have told the Soviet Union that its role in the Polish crisis reinforces the need for Australia to keep in place the post-Afghanistan measures limiting bilateral relations. We have also consulted carefully with allies in order to support Western objectives arising from the Polish crisis and we have declined to accept an increased number of refugees and migrants from Poland, as recently announced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I think we have joined with the Australian people in sending private humanitarian aid to the people of Poland. In general I think what was outlined in the question is very broadly in line with the Government's response. We will continue to react in the same way until there is some reaction with regard to martial law in the country of Poland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs comment on reports that the Government of Zimbabwe has moved to expropriate property belonging to Mr Nkomo's political party? In view of the role played by Australia in attempting to bring majority rule to Zimbabwe, has the Government protested to the Zimbabwe Government about the move towards one party rule and expressed the concern that is felt here, and I am sure in other democracies, that this may be a demise of democracy in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Considerable attention has recently been given to statements by Prime Minister Mugabe in favour of a one party state in Zimbabwe. For some time now Mr Mugabe has been on record as considering that a one party system would be more appropriate to conditions and traditions in Zimbabwe than the Westminster parliamentary system which emerged from the Lancaster House agreement. However, in a recent interview reported in the London Times, and reprinted in the Canberra Times of 1 February, Mr Mugabe was quoted as saying that there were obvious constitutional restraints and that he did not want to move illegally or hastily. He has reaffirmed many times that he will abide by the Constitution. Mr Mugabe has acknowledged that there are provisions in the Zimbabwe Constitution which would make it difficult to move hastily towards a one party state. Any changes within 10 years of independence to key provisions of the Constitution, including the right to form or belong to political parties, would require an affirmative vote from two-thirds of the membership of the Senate and from all the members of the House of Assembly. Such a vote seems most unlikely in the present circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: As is well known, Australia played an active and positive role in the proceedings leading to Zimbabwe's independence. We continue to take a close and sympathetic interest in developments there. It is our firm hope that the democratic processes which secured peace and independence for Zimbabwe will continue to be adhered to for the benefit of all the peoples of this important African country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether she said on a television program this morning that the Department of Administrative Services had ' mishandled' instructions from the Government to reduce spending. Did she accuse the Department of sending out instructions for cutbacks in overtime for the Australian Federal Police and travel allowances for the staffs of members and senators without consulting the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman? Will the Minister outline to the Senate the terms of the Cabinet instruction about reduced expenditure sent to departments? Does she believe that Ministers, such as Mr Newman, should accept responsibility for the actions of their departments if matters are mishandled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On a television program this morning I explained that some of the Press reports which were abroad yesterday and are abroad today were the result of a misunderstanding or mishandling of the procedures which have been set in motion for the preparation of the Additional Estimates this year. The Government has decided that until the Additional Estimates are finalised discretionary expenditure and expenditure which might be flexible with regard to timing are to be deferred. Contractual commitments in respect of major equipment acquisitions or other project expenditures will not be entered into and increased wage and salary expenditures are to be absorbed to the maximum extent possible by eliminating overtime and perhaps other forms of departmental expenditure. Ministers may seek exemption from the above in areas of any special sensitivity or difficulty.

ANSWER.PARA: I explained on the program this morning that as far as the Department of Administrative Services was concerned-this has been reported also by its Minister-the procedures of consultation as outlined in the original telex and in the Government's arrangements for the establishment of the Additional Estimates were not followed. Had that consultation by the Department of Administrative Services with its own Minister, and in turn with me, been followed there would not have been the very temporary difficulty that was made public by telexes that had been sent, withdrawing authority for what would be regarded as the essential activities of Government. It is not the Government's requirement that essential activity be curtailed or that disruption to what is the usual departmental practice occur, but in the next four or five weeks until such time as we settle the Additional Estimates all departments have been asked to absorb as far as possible the recent salary increases in their original Budget figures and at the same time to minimise any further expenditure which they may seek under the Additional Estimates.

I do not think I need to explain to the Senate that there has been a shortfall in the revenue that was expected in the present Budget. The sales tax Bills, which have not yet been passed in the Senate, have been one of the reasons for that fall in revenue. The lower revenue received from the oil levy as a result of strikes and other things has also reduced income. In view of the reduction of income and the additional requirements for salaries and other expenditure, while we are settling the Additional Estimates there is a procedure for departments to minimise any outlays that may be discretionary or may be able to be curtailed in the interests of adhering as closely as possible to our original Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister a supplementary question. Firstly, do the instructions which were issued apply to the Parliament? Secondly, is it normal practice for a Minister to send directions of this kind to a department without informing the Minister who is responsible for that department?
—Which instruction was sent by a Minister to the Department? I seek clarification of the second part of that question.

—I give clarification in this form: It appears that the Minister for Administrative Services had no knowledge of what his Department was doing in respect of this matter. One can only assume from that that an instruction was sent to that Department by the Department of Finance without the Minister being informed. I ask: Is that normal practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Ministers were aware of the Cabinet decision with regard to the preparation of the Additional Estimates. All Ministers were aware that administrative processes would need to be developed between departments to respond to that Cabinet decision. As the Minister for Administrative Services has said, his Department did not follow the consultation process that was outlined. If it had done so the temporary concern would not have occurred over the items that were mentioned in the last day or two.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

Any small businesses that, in the normal terms of trade, have supplied to the Commonwealth Government would have no delay , particularly no delay that may have been occasioned by the matter that we are now discussing; that is, the settlement of the amounts required under the Additional Estimates.

— Mr President, I would like to add to the response from the Attorney-General. ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of New South Wales would do well to listen to the derisive laughter. TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, refers to the article in the Australian this morning which quotes back bench Liberal members of parliament as stating that nobody can bring children into the world and expect the bloke next door to pay. It went on to refer to the means testing of family allowances. Was the revamped family allowance scheme of 1976 largely paid for by the abolition of tax rebates for children, which tax rebates were a recognition of the fact that it is a costly business to raise children? Is not this recognition a basis for the current Government's family allowance scheme? Are the Government members who made that irresponsible statement talking about means testing on a family basis or on the basis of what is in the hands of the recipient? Finally, will the Minister point out to his faceless back bench colleagues that the children of today, raised at considerable cost by their parents, will tomorrow be the ones who will have to pay the parliamentary salaries of those who make that sort of irresponsible statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick up the last point of the honourable senator's question first. It is a matter of some regret to me that there seems to be a reduction in the reproduction rate in this country. Unfortunately whilst there is certainly a problem for the future with respect to the young of today having to pay taxes to pay the parliamentary salaries of tomorrow, it is also true that the young of today will be required to pay the pensions of today's wage earners. Therefore, the point raised by the honourable senator in his question has significance right across the field of social welfare. The fact is that we have an aging population and that there is a shift in the weight which is going to have to be carried by wage and salary earners in the future because of the reduced birth rate in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The main point in the question asked by the honourable senator related to the means testing of family allowances and the rationale behind family allowances. Until the family allowance reform of 1976 Australia, in common with most comparable countries, had a system of assistance for families with children which was basically regressive. The system provided assistance through relatively small amounts of child endowment and also provided assistance, as Senator Harradine mentioned, through the tax system. That seems to be a pattern which is repeated through a great deal of the Western world. The assistance through the tax system, of course, provided assistance to those Australians who were taxpayers. That, of course, is the great bulk of wage and salary earners. It provided a greater level of assistance for those taxpayers with higher incomes who were, therefore, paying higher rates of tax. It provided a lower rate of assistance for those who were earning lower salaries and it returned no assistance at all through the tax system to those who were not paying tax. So, we had a system in which the amount of assistance that went to families with children was highest for those on the highest taxable incomes.

The Government, in its change in 1976, ensured that all families with children received the same assistance, be they families with high incomes or families with low incomes, although I should mention that there are additional allowances for children with respect to pensioner and beneficiary families. But for the great bulk of Australians we went from a basically regressive situation in which the better-off received more assistance to a situation in which all families received the same assistance. I think most honourable senators would welcome that balance which was achieved in 1976. Indeed, in debates in this place suggestions have been made by honourable senators from right round the chamber that that level of general assistance should be increased to bring it back into line with the values which were originally established in 1976. In the last Budget the 50 per cent increase for families with three or more children went a fair way to returning the value of it to those children, but the assistance, as has been pointed out, is less in real terms now than it was in 1976.

The issue of means testing which has been raised from time to time from a variety of sources is a matter which flows from a real concern on the part of many people in the community that the substantial welfare bill which is paid by the Australian taxpayer-this year payments through my Department alone will reach about $10 billion-does not have the effect of easing the poverty which exists in some corners of the Australian society and at the same time it pays money to some people who could adequately provide for themselves. There is a quite vigorous debate in the community as to whether the system should be more directive. It is not suprising, nor do I think it is in any sense undesirable, that the debate should spill over into the area of family allowances so that that question can be canvassed.

In the question which has been asked of me today Senator Harradine has properly raised the offsetting argument that families with children should receive some assistance which places them apart from those Australians who do not have the care and custody of children. I concede that he has raised a point of considerable significance. I think it has a very significant place in the rationale behind the decision which was taken by the Government in 1976 to implement the present system. Clearly, it is a consideration which will remain very strongly in the mind of the Government. This is a difficult area and I would like to think that in this chamber we will get constructive contributions to the debate on the problems which face us in the Department of Social Security . I think they are real. I think there are at times difficult choices to be made . But I hope that there will be common cause in the fact that we want to advance the position of Australian families just as we want to protect the poor and needy in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is there a requirement in the agreements with the car rental companies granted exclusive franchises at federally operated airports that within normal business hours the offices at the airports be manned on arrival of regular commercially operated flights, including commuter flights? Will the Minister, when allocating future licences, take into consideration a willingness to service airports rather than give the exclusive right to the highest bidders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson seeks a quite considerable amount of detailed information in connection with the contracts between rental car proprietors and the Government in this area. I think the only thing I can do in the circumstances is to refer the question to the Minister for his advice. As to the policy matter which Senator Watson raised in the latter part of his question, I will refer that for more urgent advice and will come back to him as soon as possible.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, goes back to a question I asked her in this place on 15 October last relative to Press reports emanating from West Irian. I received a reply from the Department of Foreign Affairs at that stage saying that it was not prepared to answer my question because it delved into the areas of security and intelligence. I raised the matter with the Minister in this chamber and she requested that I put the question on notice. That was done on 26 November last. I have had no reply. Particularly in the light of recent Press reports emanating from the same area that some 2,500 people in Irian Jaya were killed by the Indonesians last November, I wonder whether the Minister will lean on her colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether an answer can be arrived at. It seems to me rather strange that the Western Press and Western governments seem to be able to derive all sorts of information from all corners of the world, particularly Poland and Afghanistan, but are very reluctant to gain access or have no means of access to information right at our front door.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the unanswered question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether any response can be made. As I understand it, the Government does not have any evidence of 2,500 people being killed in bombing raids by Indonesian aircraft during the last six months of 1981. However, as I have said, I will refer the question to the Minister to see whether there is some information that I can get for Senator Primmer on this matter.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health clarify the number of doctors who have been involved in the recently discovered medical frauds? Estimates seem to vary from 900 to several thousand and the cost to the community has been put at $100m a year upwards. In view of the very large cost to the community, is the Minister satisfied that adequate resources are being made available to detect the guilty and, more importantly, to deter others from committing offences? Is the Australian Medical Association co-operating fully? Would not the greatest contribution it could make be to reduce confusion over charges by stopping recommending that its members should charge different and higher fees than those that have been assessed as fair and reasonable by the arbitrator? Finally, is it not mainly bulk billing and the consequent lack of patient audit that makes frauds possible? Would not the recently announced Australian Labor Party health scheme greatly increase bulk billing and therefore make such medical frauds much easier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Concern about the activities of doctors and people in other professions who are acting illegally is not a recent event. It has only recently come to public notice. It has been of greater public concern with the greater public reimbursement of medical costs. One of the problems that has occurred has not been so much identifying the doctors or even getting some kind of prosecution, although that is difficult; it has been the imposition of appropriate and matching penalties. If a doctor has, for example, earned an extra $100,000 in increments of $20, it is almost impossible for the police to mount the evidence to take him to court on each of those $20 transactions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has looked at the possibility of altering the penalties to make them more effective. The Minister for Health announced in a Press statement a couple of weeks ago that the Government will be introducing legislation to increase the penalties to make them real and significant. The new legislation will provide that any doctor found guilty of a couple of offences, even if those offences are minor, will then be open to a major administrative penalty which the Government can then apply. That penalty will be that the doctor will no longer be considered eligible to be a participating doctor for the purpose of the medical benefits scheme. Obviously, the best interests of patients must be looked at to ensure that if this happens, adequate public disclosure is made and patients are informed that a doctor is no longer able to participate in the medical benefits scheme. That is an extremely severe penalty and would make any doctor who is playing the scheme think twice before he ran the risk of being caught. He would have to be caught for only a couple of small offences to face the administrative penalty of not being a participating doctor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not criminal proceedings?

—Senator Chipp asked: 'Why not criminal proceedings? One of the problems has been that the doctors go before the courts for a couple of events and the judge, in determining penalties-whether they are criminal or anything else-is judging them on the evidence of the particular offences. We are trying to identify a means of intervening effectively to make the small number of doctors involved think twice.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hamer asked a number of other questions. He asked what was the number of doctors involved. I understand that the document from which the figures he gave came may have been used to brief a number of people including members of the Labor Party and the AMA. It referred to 900 high profile doctors and another 1,600 to 1,700 doctors whose profiles required attention but who did not come in the first priority. I do not think that the recommended fee is the problem Senator Hamer suggests. His final point concerned bulk billing. The only statement I make about bulk billing-I am trying to contribute to the national debate-is that it has two features. On one side it contributes to the production of a better national data base and, therefore, easier detection of doctors who may be playing up. On the other hand, and simultaneously, it makes it easier for people to cheat the system. Anyone who looks at bulk billing must balance these two factors-whether he wants the benefits of a greater data base or whether he is concerned about the increased opportunities for cheating. It is that kind of concern that is before the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to a massacre which occurred in the Philippines on 15 September 1981. Is the Minister aware that 45 inhabitants of the tiny Philippines village of Sag-od were slaughtered by security forces, apparently as part of a campaign against the fledgling people's army. Is the Minister further aware that the incident took place near a massive Australian aid project to build roads in the island of Samar? Is it a fact that when Australia decided to spend $25m on this aid project, the Government did not discuss the project with the people of Samar but just accepted the Philippines Government's evaluation of the situation? Are the roads built by Australians in fact being used by the military to suppress the people of Samar? Is the Minister aware that there is a lot of opposition locally to the Australian project? What will the Australian Government do to ensure that this aid project is not used to exploit the very people it was meant to assist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the matter raised by Senator McIntosh. I think we would all expect and hope that aid projects that we develop in other countries would be for the benefit of the people of the community in which they were placed. We would view very seriously the suggestions that may be implicit in Senator McIntosh's question. However, as I said, I have no information on the matter. I suggest that as it is a detailed question it be placed on the Notice Paper and I will see whether I can get an early answer from the Minister.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to an announcement made last year by the South Australian Government which indicated its intention to establish an area in Adelaide to be known as ' Technology Park, Adelaide', the purpose of which is to develop high technology industries. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government recognises Australia's enormous potential in this area and our capability of successfully competing with overseas manufacturers? Does the Minister also recognise the importance of Technology Park, Adelaide, not only to South Australia but also to Australia generally? Given the benefits that could accrue to this country as a result of this planned development, will the Commonwealth Government consider assisting the South Australian Government in financing Technology Park and encouraging Australian industries-perhaps by way of the Australian Industry Development Corporation-to commercialise initiatives such as the super silicon chip which is currently being developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Adelaide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly recognises the importance of encouraging the development of high technology industries in Australia. It has offered to participate in the National Semi-conductor Corporation facility in Canberra. This, together with its revised purchasing policy, which gives preference to supplies from high technology areas of Australian industry, and its support for industrial research and development, provides evidence of its policy. These initiatives are consistent with the Government's overall policy objective of encouraging the development of internationally competitive export oriented and specialised innovative industries based on advanced technology.

ANSWER.PARA: The concept of Technology Park in Adelaide is to provide an environment in which high technology based industry can develop in close association with a technology oriented tertiary institution. This concept has been developed successfully in the United States of America and therefore the South Australian initiative is commendable. The Minister for Science and Technology is arranging discussions between officials of his department and those of the South Australian Department of Trade and Industry to explore ways in which the Commonwealth can contribute to the development of Technology Park, Adelaide.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to Question upon Notice No. 1652 to which I received a reply during the recess. I am not happy with that reply and therefore want to ask a further question. I draw the Minister's attention to the following part of my previous question:

QUESTION.PARA: Do the Iwasaki beef production interests in the central Queensland region have an agreement with a local export meat processing firm for the killing of cattle produced on the Iwasaki properties-

That meat is subsequently exported to Japan. I then asked whether it was sold by the same interests in Japan or disposed of through normal channels. In reference to the first question, the Minister said:

Such arrangements, if they exist, would be commercially confidential between the interested parties. The preparation of meat for export is subject to controls under the Exports (Meat) Regulations and must be prepared in a registered export establishment.
All beef exported by Australia to Japan enters that country under a global import quota.
In 1980-81 we exported all types of meat amounting to some 218,000 tonnes. I want a further explanation of the Minister's reply. He said:

Apart from a small percentage (around 10 per cent) all beef and veal imports into Japan and their distribution are controlled by the Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation, a semi-government authority.

Will the Minister obtain further information on this because it appears that almost 22,000 tonnes was exported from Australia. A percentage of this amount, undoubtedly, would have come from my State. Apparently the Government has no control over that amount of beef. Where does it go? Who is responsible for it? Who buys it? Is this one way that illegal exports of all sorts of game meat are going from this country? For all we know cans of drugs or anything else could be going out with these exports if there is no control over them. I ask the Minister for a more detailed reply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that the honourable senator is jumping at shadows in the last part of his question. I am only surprised that he has not suggested that we are managing to ship out uranium by dint of hiding it in beef carcasses. However, he has raised a question relating to the 10 per cent of meat exports to which he has referred. I certainly will make inquiries to see whether additional information can be provided for him as he has requested.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the failure by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council to recommend funding of 200-tonne coal gasification pilot testing in the United States and Europe of South Australian Wakefield coal and the importance of the project to South Australia, will the Minister give consideration to providing or assisting with such funding other than through the NERDDC machinery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council is an advisory technical body which is widely representative of industry, and therefore its aim is to make objective recommendations. That it has not made funds available to a particular enterprise or undertaking is an indication of its view and its priorities at the time. —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that many holders of disadvantaged health cards cannot afford medication prescribed by their doctors? What action does the Government intend to take to rectify this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the epidemiological study about which Senator Macklin seeks information, I point out that the decision on this matter was not taken on any ground of cost but rather on the problems that arose during the early part of the study. These were confirmed after conducting a pilot study into the circumstances of 600 Vietnam veterans in Sydney. It indicated that it would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to establish to what degree Vietnam veterans were individually exposed to herbicides.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of where we are to go in relation to future developments and studies has been thought through very carefully by the Commonwealth Institute of Health and the scientific advisory committee which has been advising me along those lines. We have come to the conclusion that we should develop alternative studies into three separate areas: The illness of veterans, the causes of death amongst veterans and birth defects of veterans' children-of course, an area about which there is a great deal of concern. Those studies are proceeding. They are matters about which I believe veterans themselves are very anxious to find answers. There is only one way to find the answers and that is by scientific investigation. That is the Government's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Department of Communications has had an extremely busy year in terms of its work load. It is short staffed and it has been considerably mucked about by the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, as a result of a variety of ad hoc policy decision changes made at Cabinet level and not on any advice from the Department itself. The Department's personnel have worked in that sense under extreme difficulty during the relevant year. The Secretary to the Department, Mr Lansdown, in his letter of transmittal, notes that it was an extremely busy year and the report shows an enormous range of matters covered by the Department.The stringent staff ceilings, uncertainty and the ministerial capriciousness about policy matters make it difficult for such a department to work and it is to be commended for what it has managed to achieve. There are very serious problems in the administration and development of communications policy in Australia. My view may seem blunt rather than circumspect, but I believe the fault lies with the Government and the absence of a communications policy; and it lies particularly with the present Minister.

The Department has to deal with a great complexity and convergence of issues. A few years ago broadcasting seemed a very simple matter compared with what it is today. It is no longer so simple because there is a vast convergence of issues as a result of new technologies. In the communications area there is currently an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal into the possible development of cable television in Australia. As a result of ad hoc government policy, there is an inquiry into the telecommunications system and the desirability of making parts of Telecom Australia's work available to private enterprise. There are the problems of satellite development. We also have within the province of this Department the inquiry into Australia Post.

All these inquiries are taking place at the same time. All of them arise from either ad hoc or ideological decisions taken by the present Government which are in no way related to a coherent communications policy. For example, it is ridiculous to have a cable television inquiry being conducted by the Broadcasting Tribunal at the same time as inquiries are being conducted into the future of Telecom because the two matters are intimately related in the sense of both developing technology and capital investment, as well as, of course, in relation to any structural arrangements which would have to be made.

It is a tragic confusion which the Department of Communications has to try to embrace. Ultimately the Government should get advice on all these things from its Department. It is commendable that the Department has set up a task force on broadcasting development which is referred to at pages 7 and 35 of the report. But it should be noted that this task force was set up by the Department, not by the Minister, and that it was to operate for only six months from February 1981. The question arises as to whether this task force still exists. If so, might it discover some inconvenient facts to bother the Government's so-called policy maker at the ministerial level? One wonders whether the policy issues are simple enough for a group such as a broadcasting task force to be able to second guess the work of two major inquiries as well as to canvass the satellite and general broadcasting issues in a period of six months.

The notion of trying to lay down policy guidelines and to develop a scenario, if I can use that awful word, for the development of a broadcasting system should be strongly backed by government. Even if the Department, on its own initiative, did develop a scenario and desirable future policy for the development of broadcasting in Australia, can we be sure that the Minister would take any notice of it? He is more likely instead to listen to some unidentified cabal of interests and develop things according to some unexplained and doubtless irresponsible prejudice or ideology of the present Government, the classic example of that being the decision, contrary to the best interests of the Australian business community involved in telecommunications, to give videotext to private enterprise when Telecom had already invested a considerable amount of money-something of the order of $1m-in that system.

That puts Australia in the position of being the only country in the world, apart from Belgium, where special circumstances apply under which that sort of system, that new technology, will not be developed by the major common carrier, the major provider-the state-owned provider of telecommunications services. We are placed in that one-off category because of the ideological prejudices of this Government. This is quite contrary to developments in Europe. France is moving ahead very much with the development of these services in the hands of government, for very good reasons. As the French Government puts it this is, firstly, because new technologies should be shared equally between the people and should not be the province of only those who can afford them and, secondly, because new technologies involve very severe threats to privacy and it is much better for those technologies to be developed by a government instrumentality than by private corporations which carry with them the threat to individual privacy.

I refer to another deep-seated and disturbing phenomenon which is illustrated by the Department of Communications; that is, the increasing tendency for Ministers in this Government to separate themselves from departments. They even thrust departmental officers forward to present issues and proposals not backed by the government; that is, to fly kites. If the reaction is adverse, the Minister can wash his hands of the proposal which has been floated. I raised a similar matter in a question to Senator Guilfoyle this morning. It appears that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) had no knowledge of what his Department was doing about a directive from the Department of Finance. Senator Guilfoyle appeared on television this morning and criticised that Department. I believe that under our system of government a department cannot be criticised without the Minister being implicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Wran does not believe that.

—The honourable senator should get some of these obsessions out of his mind. I am trying to talk about good government. He is trying to talk about good dirty politics all the time, and it is a different thing. Perhaps to illustrate his point he could tell us something about the Whitlam era which he would regard as being relevant to his performance in government. If we are to get away from this doctrine of ministerial responsibility we ought to be quite open about it. Perhaps Senator Carrick will make a statement about it in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Early last year the Department of Communications released a discussion paper on a commercial direct broadcasting service-a very sensitive matter. The document said it was giving attention to the matter without requiring the government to commit itself in advance of experience. The document was put out by the Department, not the Minister. I am not against those sorts of discussion papers but they should go out with the authority of the Minister, not the Department, because the Minister is the person responsible. This should not be a method of making the Department a whipping boy. A number of similar issues in relation to questions of government emerge from this important report of the Department of Communications.

Australia Post, as a government instrumentality, and Telecom Australia, as another government instrumentality, have in a sense been under siege since the Fraser Government came to power. Inquiries have now been set up into their operations on a very ad hoc basis. Very few reasons have been given for those inquiries. For example, the inquiry into Australia Post is clearly designed to expand the role of private enterprise in the area of postal services. I do not think there has been a very vigorous response from private enterprise in seeking to expand postal services. The ideology embraced in the so-called razor gang is being pursued to enable a public utility to be plucked for the benefit of the private sector. Professor Mathews, in his January paper about the activities of the razor gang, made the comment that if this Government devoted as much energy to revenue raising by catching up with tax avoiders as it does to allegedly trying to cut costs, there would be much better government in Australia. That is an important observation.

Australia Post is under siege because of the ideological ad hockery that lies behind the activities of that stunt called the razor gang. Since Australia Post was established by the Labor Government in 1975 it has shown increased efficiency. This is borne out by an examination of the accounts, the operating surplus, the amount of mail moved, the staff employed and the cost of mail services compared with the increase in the rate of inflation. Australia Post has had to carry out these operations while being starved of funds by the Government . It needs new equipment and funds in order to better serve its customers. This is not to say that there have not been disastrous attempts at modernisation. This is well known because of the proposals in relation to the Redfern Mail Exchange. There is no doubt that if Australia Post is allowed to compete effectively with private enterprise it can.

One of the reactions of this Government, of course, has been to try to strip Australia Post of its most profitable enterprises. Principally they, like the services offered by Telecom, are services which will result in no cross- subsidisation by Australia Post. People such as Senator Bjelke-Petersen will know that Australia Post subsidises country mail by some $20m a year. So people are able to send a letter from Birdsville or Weipa to Melbourne for the same price as they can send a letter from one Melbourne suburb to another. In my view it is a very good thing that that service exists.

However, Australia Post is only able to provide that equal service to the Australian community as a whole because it makes profits in some other areas of its operations. Areas where Australia Post is making profits in its operations, areas which pay for this equal service, are being attacked by this Government. For example, the attempt to abolish the Australia Post courier service will result in a decline in profits for Australia Post because that was a profitable operation. It is that area which is being attacked by the Government with the result that in the long term people will have to pay. The first people who will have to pay will be those who live in the outback areas of Australia and who obtain the benefits of cross subsidy and the cross subsidy policy which has been adopted by Australia Post over many years. We think there are many things in the report of Australia Post which require intelligent examination by honourable senators and some thoughtful concern as to how these issues are best resolved in the interests of the Australian people rather than in the interests of a few entrepreneurs who push the Government to try to obtain the profitable work of an organisation such as Australia Post. The report indicates something of that story and expresses some of those concerns. I commend its reading to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I wish to say a few words about the report. When the 1979-80 report was tabled in the Parliament on 24 February last year I complained about the booking system used by Australian National Railways for the transcontinental railway, mainly the Indian Pacific service. I made a complaint also about the way the ANR was crippling small businesses in country areas with an enormous increase in parcel rates. The report tabled in the Senate is the first report brought down by Mr Marks, the new Chairman of ANR. I continue to call the organisation ANR because it is a railway report that we are dealing with. The heading of the report is ' Australian National Railways Commission, 1980-81 Annual Report'. I remind the Senate again of the complaints that I have made made times, of this instrumentality wasting $409,000 of its money in dropping the word 'Railways'. It is now known as Australian National. But whenever a report is tabled in Parliament or we see advertisements in newspapers for loan funds for this organisation, the organisation is always called the Australian National Railways Commission. It is my view that the name should not have been changed.

Mr Marks states in the report that nine months of the operations detailed in the report were under the jurisdiction of the previous Chairman, Mr Smith. I congratulated Mr Smith 12 months ago on the fine work he did over the years that he was Chairman of the Australian National Railways. I will not do that again now. His service is mentioned in the report. I notice-I hope it was because of my complaints voiced on behalf of many people-that the Commission is now altering its method of bookings for railway services. It now has a computerised passenger booking system with the object of obtaining effective utilisation of long haul passenger services. The report states that this can be accomplished only if booking information is centralised and continually updated. That has been my complaint on many occasions in the Parliament. We found that dead cars were running on ANR's interstate train because people who rang for seats on that train were told by railway officers that all tickets had been sold. I am pleased that ANR has now taken some action to see that a stop will be put to that and the train will run at full capacity every time it operates.

I have travelled on trains in many parts of the world. Last year I travelled on the Canadian Pacific from Vancouver to Regina in Saskatchewan. A couple of years previously I travelled on the Canadian Pacific from Vancouver to Calgary. Such trains are of world note. They cannot be compared with our trans-Australia trains; they are second to none. I hope that the Australian service is further improved by fuller utilisation of the seating capacity on trains.

It is unfortunate that because of the Standing Orders we are restricted to 10 minutes for debate on these reports. Many of them we could not deal with in the 30 minutes that we were allowed previously, so we have to gloss over them. Under the heading of 'Country Passenger Services' the report states:
Patronage of country passenger services in South Australia continued to decline with a 10 per cent reduction on the previous year.

That is understandable in view of the fact that whilst people who want to travel on passenger trains within South Australia make bookings there is not enough staff on trains to supervise those bookings. I have had many complaints from people who have had bookings on trains run by the ANR. However, when they get on at the station they find other people sitting in their seats. They have to stand even though they have made bookings many days, sometimes weeks, before. In school holidays, some children going on holidays, would have to stand, for 100 kilometres or more despite having made a booking. I hope the Commission takes some note of what I am saying in making this complaint on behalf of the many people who would like to use the trains but who cannot do so because they find that they still have to stand even after booking a seat. There are now no conductors to whom one can go to lodge a complaint. If there were they could officially remove the person from the seat booked by the other passenger.

We see some mention in the report also of the increase in revenue from freight rates. I am talking mainly about parcel rates. The small parcel freight service has been killed in the railways. Some mention is made in this report of the increase in revenue from the carriage of mail. That is how that situation is coming about. The railways have lost the direct carriage of parcels. They are going into Australian Postal Commission bags and still being carted by rail but at a much lower price to the people sending them. The railways are losing a lot of freight revenue. Apart from that, this is having a very detrimental effect on many small business people because they cannot afford to pay these enormous small parcel freight rates.

In the couple of minutes left to me I want to relate to the Senate the complaints from the farming community in South Australia about these increased freight rates for grain and the detrimental effect that is having on the country areas. I do not have time to read the whole of a report of a meeting held at Karoonda Institute on 25 January between representatives of the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, representatives from the Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd and Australian National Railways representatives but part of the report of the meeting highlights the feeling of the people. The feeling of the meeting was that if A.N. continued to charge uncompetitive rates, there would be two losers, firstly A.N. because more grain would go by road transport and secondly when A.N. closed the lines because of lack of traffic, the farmers would be at the mercy of road transport operators re charges.
I have made that statement in the Parliament over the years. The minutes go on to state:
After many questions and discussion, sometimes heated, the following motion was presented, seconded and carried.

'That this meeting of grain growers express its strong disapproval at the ever increasing rate of freight being sought by A.N. for the haulage of grain. It is respectfully pointed out that the end result will not be more profit for A.N. on the contrary it will be the direct cause of:
(1) Less tonnage and profit for A.N.
(2) Increases in road haulage to terminals
(3) Congestion at terminals
(4) Unused space at country silos
(5) Country rail centres not being fully used
(6) Further decline in country employment and further imposition on country living including the added costs of road maintenance

Therefore the meeting recognizing the value of A.N. to the community as a whole , makes a genuine and honest request of A.N. not to pursue a policy which will result in the problems forecasted becoming realities to the detriment of all concerned'.

I hope that at some time in the future, perhaps on the first reading of a money Bill, I will have an opportunity to say more about the need for Australian National Railways to be competitive and to give a better service to people, particularly those living in country areas. DEBATE.TITLE: PASSENGER MOTOR VEHICLES AND COMPONENTS-POST-1984 ARRANGEMENTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In moving this motion I should like to make a number of points in respect of the Industries Assistance Commission, its report on the industry and, further, the effect of the report and the policies embodied therein on the South Australian economy. I think the hard effects of the report and the consequent Government decision making can be numbered about five. Firstly-this is not disputed-about one-third of the motor vehicle industry in Australia will be killed off by implementation of decisions consequent upon this report. That means a loss of about 30,000 jobs nationally. Secondly, and most importantly in my opinion as a respresentative of the State of South Australia, the decisions consequent upon this report will have a disproportionate effect on the South Australian economy because of our regional peculiarities, the nature of our economy and our already shrinking manufacturing base.

Thirdly, the report will mean an end to the Australian car. Basically, the Australian car will be a thing of the past; indeed, this is already virtually the case. Decisions in the future will more than definitely be made in places such as Detroit and Tokyo. The Australian consumer will have to buy what decision makers overseas tell him or her is available. Fourthly, and extremely importantly in an age of advanced technology, we will see consequent upon decision making a massive de-skilling of the Australian work force. The car industry has indeed been responsible for introducing a vast number of skills into Australian industry, and with the degeneration of this industry we will find a consequent degeneration of the development of skills in the work force. Finally, the one sector that will be affected more than others by the effects of this report will be the migrant sector. People who have historically been working in unskilled areas and who have historically been over-represented, in the motor vehicle industry, according to their proportion in the work force, will find that jobs will no longer be available to them. In this respect I will refer later to the situation at the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Woodville in South Australia.

The basis of the IAC report is an econometric model called Orani, which, in the IAC's own words, is a system of equations which impose conditions on a larger set of variables. There are some basic problems with the use of this type of econometric approach by the IAC.

The first problem is that the Orani approach pre-supposes some kind of perfect economy where all things are equal and rational. It is discussed at length in the IAC report, and indeed it is a crucial factor in the final recommendations put forward in that report. As I said, it is deficient in many ways. When one tries to apply this type of approach to the South Australian economy one is met with extraordinary pressures from within and from outside South Australia both in terms of international and national pressures. For a start, the Orani model takes employment projections only at a national level; it seems to ignore regional pressures and conditions. For this reason it can be rejected as an appropriate approach not only to the South Australian car industry but also to the Australian car industry in general.

One thing the IAC does not consider consequent upon this fault in the Orani approach is the likely investment response of companies which may be located in more than one region. In this instance once again I mention GMH. If as a result of what the Government announced last year GMH seeks to rationalise it will have to weigh up what pressure it has to reduce the overall scale of its operations. Will it reduce them in one State? Will it reduce them in another? Will it do so in Adelaide or Melbourne? It seems from all the evidence available to us that what will happen in this case is that the GMH plant in Woodville is more than likely to close down. It is ominous in this context to look at the land adjoining that plant in South Australia, and that is the Cheltenham racecourse which the South Australian Government is allowing to close down and be taken over for some type of development. It is my information that that racecourse, together with the degenerating Woodville GMH plant which it is expected will close down in three to four years, will form the basis of a development which the South Australian people and the trade union movement in South Australia have not been informed about but which government in South Australia, in secret cahoots with the South Australian Jockey Club, and GMH, is organising at this moment.

Let us return to the Orani model and look at other aspects of it. One other deficiency of the Orani model, when one assesses its relevance in respect of this debate, is its misunderstanding of the labour market. The IAC expresses a desire to have the price of labour float around rather like the price of other commodities, whether they be jumpers, apples or whatever. That is an approach which does not take into sufficient recognition the state of the labour market at the moment. It does not take into account the fact that unemployment levels are already high and, in fact, in South Australia are the highest in the country . The report to my mind has been formulated in a vacuum when it comes to employment, and especially regional employment. The IAC makes a basic assumption about the ability of the Australian industry to mop up any displaced workers. It makes some assumptions about the mobility of the Australian work force. It makes some assumptions also about the mobility of capital within Australia, that by freeing up capital through the lowering of protection further regional based industries will be created where they are economic. What the IAC does not take into consideration is that we have had year after year of structural downturn in our economy, in our industries, and that this freeing up, this mobility, has had more than enough time to operate if, in fact, it is going to operate. The economic environment is not there for it to operate. That has been shown by recent experience.

The other aspect of the report which I find objectionable is the fact that the Australian workers-male or female-are seen by the IAC as cannon fodder to be used, to be moved around the country. They are expected to pack up their bags and go around the country according to the dictates of internationally based industry. I do not have much longer to speak. Dealing with South Australia, I mentioned earlier the regional aspects of the implementation of a report such as this and Government decisions consequent upon it. There will, in fact, be very few winners under this decision-making process and very many losers-the major losers, of course, will be in South Australia. There will be two winners, as has been assessed by, amongst others, the Sydney Morning Herald. There will be General Motors-Holden's Ltd, a company which has already structured its operation to accommodate the international car, and the Department of Industry and Commerce. The local components manufacturers will be well and truly in a deficit situation after the implementation of the increased export facilitation scheme. As I said, we will see quite a number of people within Australia losing jobs with the implementation of this report. I will not say anything further in respect of this report. I know that my colleague from South Australia, Senator Foreman, wishes to follow me in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industries Assistance Commission report on passenger motor vehicles and components has led to enormous interest in the Australian community and in this Parliament. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

One of the persistent criticisms that have been mounted by the Labor Party of the present so called co-operative companies and securities scheme is that it involves a system of divided or joint responsibility or accountability which is all too likely in practice to produce a situation whereby the machinery in question and those who operate it and the Ministerial Council who supervise it are in fact responsible, to no one. It is against that background that this report comes to us. It represents one of the very few opportunities that arise in this Parliament for us to scrutinise the operation of the companies and securities law as it has recently developed. It is a matter of profound regret that there should be only 10 minutes available to me and to any other speaker who wants to come in on this to take advantage of this all-too-rare opportunity to look at some of the crucial issues.

This report is, by any standard, an excellent one. The test of any good annual report by a statutory authority must be its ability to convey an accurate impression-preferably in short compass-of the scope and direction of the activities of the body and, just as importantly, of the manner in which it approaches the discharge of its functions and the exercise of its powers. This report certainly satisfies those tests and is in fact an excellent handbook on the National Companies and Securities Commission. I commend it to anyone concerned about the future of companies and securities regulations in Australia. One particular aspect deserving of a mention is the setting out in the appendix to the report of the first seven policy statements issued by the Commission. Together with the practice notes giving interpretations of aspects of the present substantive law, the policy statements are a model, in a sense, of public communication by a statutory authority and they do represent a significant advance towards those goals of administrative uniformity and commercial certainty which are essential ingredients of a regulatory system in this area.

The occasion must be taken, however, to point to some of the very serious difficulties which have accompanied the operation of the NCSC so far. I have spoken in the past-I will not do so again on this occasion-of one of those difficulties and that is the problem of co-operation between the State corporate affairs commissions and the National Commission. The second problem which is starkly revealed in the terms of the report goes to the resources of the Commission. There is still, and has been since the Commission's inception, a chronic shortage of staff, in spite of repeated calls by the Commission itself, by business commentators and by industry organisations. The approval last week by the Ministerial Council of a so-called 50 per cent increase in the operational staff of the Commission still leaves the Commission something like 16 bodies short of its own minimum assessment of what it takes to run the show at a national level. The so-called operational staff that were approved by last Friday's ministerial council-the eight additional staff in question-were in fact support staff rather than professionals in this area. There is still an acute shortage of senior professionals in the Commission. Given the availability of places to fill, one of the particular problems that the Commission has experienced has been that of attracting operational staff of sufficient professional and commercial expertise. It has been very difficult for the NCSC to do this when it has been forced to pay in effect the gamekeepers so much less than the poachers out in the field are getting.

The main problem I want to address in my limited time today is not the co- operation problem or the resources problem of the Commission but the limitations and constraints which have emerged already in the legislative scheme supporting the Commission's operations. Unfortunately corporate raiders of the likes of Ron Brierley will always be concerned with the letter and not the spirit of regulatory legislation such as this, despite the laudable aim of really everyone , I suppose, associated with the new scheme-in the language of the NCSC and its report-'to encourage and secure compliance with the spirit and intent of the law and promote high standards of professional competence and integrity'. Regrettably all too many of those people out in the commercial jungle do not share that aspiration or those standards. That was, I think, vividly expressed and communicated by some remarks of Mr Brierley reported in Australian Business this week when he said:
I don't need a group of commercial failures, bureaucrats and academic dropouts with two or three months' experience in a new area to teach me how to look after small investors.

With that arrogant and contemptuous attitude being expressed by Mr Ron Brierley it is very difficult obviously for the NCSC to apply the law that it is supposed to be applying in a way that will be effective, and it needs all the co- operation that is possible from the court system. Regrettably, however, that co- operation has not so far been forthcoming and that sensitivity to the aims of this legislation has not been demonstrated in the two main trials of strength that we have seen in the last couple of months in the operation of the new system. The first trial of strength-which involved Mr Brierley-in the Industrial Equity Ltd case decided by Justice Needham in the New South Wales Supreme Court at the end of December was decided, it must be said, on a highly legalistic and unadventurous interpretation of the securities industry and takeover codes, and it had the result of narrowing rather than expanding the NCSC's powers. But it was with even greater astonishment that we read yesterday of the decision of the Queensland Supreme Court in the Pine Vale case involving really a quite extraordinarily narrow interpretation of the Commission's power to hold public hearings conferred by section 36 of the Commonwealth NCSC Act and in similar terms by section 7 of the corresponding Queensland Act. I pause here to note that there is a difference in the terminology of the relevant sections. The power in question, as described in section 36, is 'for the purpose of the performance of any of its functions or the exercise of any of its powers', whereas the corresponding section in the Queensland Act, section 7, is subtly differently worded, as follows:
. . . for the purpose of the performance of a function or the exercise of a power conferred or expressed to be conferred on it by or under an Act.

The point I am making here-I do not want to get too far into technical detail-is that we have a classic example of the kind of textual disuniformity which bedevilled the so-called uniform companies and securities legislation which preceded the current legislation. For no immediately apparent reason the Queensland Government, in common with other State governments, has chosen to re- enact the actual text of relevant parts of the NCSC Act rather than simply incorporate them by reference. For an even crazier reason, if there was any reason at all, it has chosen to vary the language in which those provisions have in fact been incorporated into the Queensland law. That creates a situation where there is scope for argument by lawyers, as there was in the Queensland case, that the Queensland legislation is slightly more restrictive than its Commonwealth parent. If there was one benefit which was supposed to be claimed by all its sponsors for the new co-operative scheme, it was at least that the text of the legislation in question would be absolutely uniform and that we would not go down this road of textual differences in it from State to State. This is an extraordinary problem that has become apparent just in the last couple of days with this case, and it is an alarming one to have to note at this stage.

A number of matters require immediate reform so far as the legislative framework of this scheme is concerned. One of them obviously is an amendment to the relevant powers to conduct hearings to cope with the Queensland decision yesterday, if indeed that is not overturned on appeal. Other amendments are obviously needed-I have not time to explain why-including amendments to section 14 of the Securities Industry Act, to the operation of section 42 of that Act and to section 60 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, all of which have been shown up in stark relief as having problems in the way in which they have been interpreted so far by the courts. Some more general amendments which are clearly needed to the legislative framework of this scheme are, in the first place, the enactment of a section 15AA-type provision in the overarching interpretation code which will in fact require courts applying this legislation to look to the purpose, the policy, the objectives of the scheme in the legislation and not to apply a narrowly literalistic approach. It is necessary for technical reasons to have an explicit provision of this kind in this legislation and not simply to rely on the existing Commonwealth provision in the Acts Interpretation Act. The insertion of such a provision should have very high priority.

Another overarching amendment that is needed to this legislation is, I believe, one to give the NCSC power to make consistently, to the extent that this can be done under Commonwealth constitutional constraints, binding orders without having to go to court. At present its powers to make binding orders are very limited and there is a whole series of matters, particularly its section 45 powers under the takeover code concerning the restraining of the disposition of shares and so on, in which the NCSC simply cannot move quickly and directly to deal with problems as they emerge. Innumerable problems are emerging in this whole legislative framework. It is regrettable that the attitude of the present Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, has not been one of more alert attention to the problems. The same goes, I regret, for his ministerial counterparts in the States.

A number of answers to the problems which are raised in the report have not been provided by the Australian Government in preparing the report. For example, the Senate will remember that a few years ago the Australian Government was persuaded to expend in excess of $6m to acquire the Cocos (Keeling) Islands from Mr Clunies-Ross in the belief that this would provide an environment in which the indigenous people-I suppose one could argue that they are not indigenous, but in any case they have had an association with the islands for the last three centuries-would be able to proceed to make decisions about managing their own affairs. But of course, as the United Nations mission that went there last year found, the influence of Mr Clunies-Ross, who saw himself as the uncrowned king of the islands-we left him in possession of several acres of land-still exists, inhibiting and in many ways restricting the aims of the United Nations and the Australian Government. I am sure that there is a degree of unanimity in the national Parliament about the rights of the people to self-determination in every sense. The report goes on to point to a number of other weaknesses that still have to be faced by the Australian Government. One can say that the Australian Government's mandate in this area still leaves much to be desired. The report indicates that there is a need for a great deal of diversification of economic activity on the island, that they should not rely on copra as the principal source of economic influence and development and that there is a need to extend the economic aid that is presently provided so that the people who have remained virtually untouched by mankind in a cultural sense will be able to progress towards development in the way in which the rest of the modern world has developed. The report indicates that steps ought to be taken to overcome the isolation of the people. They are living in such a state of literal isolation that they are not able to appreciate the evolution of man that has taken place in most other parts of the world.

It points to the need for a lot more education input. There is a need for encouragement of the people's cultural, personal, social and educational development if they are to be able finally to survive in the environment in which they live. In other words, there is a lack of overall development. The United Nations has found that whilst the islands are moving towards the objectives to which I refer it is nevertheless a slow development. The United Nations report also makes reference to the fact that the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands are a tax-free haven and that a number of foreign companies have taken advantage of this fact. In the annual report of the islands the Administrator, Mr Buffett, on behalf of the Australian Government, quarrels with that statement. I think the report is deficient insofar as there are two conflicting views on this matter. The United Nations report talks about foreign companies using the Cocos (Keeling) Islands as a tax haven.
