This is a sad occasion to the extent that it represents Al Grassby's reporting swansong so far as this Parliament is concerned. That may be a matter of profound indifference or a matter for applause so far as some of the more insensitive Government senators in this Parliament are concerned. But Al Grassby has been an indefatigable advocate of racial tolerance in this country of ours. He has fought a long and distinguished fight against prejudice and discrimination in the community at large and in the breasts of certain State governments and their Ministers in this country. In doing so he has had to fight , for most of the last six years, the overt hostility and lack of co-operation of this present Commonwealth Government. Certainly the manner of his departure from the independent status which he has hitherto enjoyed, and the manner of his no doubt inevitable departure altogether from this field when his seven-year term runs out later this year, does the present Government no credit.

The reports which Mr Grassby and his staff have prepared, compiled and distributed over the last six years are superb social documents on any view. His present one is no exception. As I say, it is sad that it seems inevitable that the voice of Mr Grassby and his staff will no longer be directly heard in the future. Of course the reason is that Mr Grassby has disappeared now within the flabby bowels of the Durack Human Rights Commission which was finally established on 10 December last year. He is not a commissioner of that body. He retains his title as Community Relations Commissioner under the statutory provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act but he is subject to the direction, discipline and everything else of the largely part time Commission which is being superimposed above him.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of whether he will be driving the lift.

—It is a question of whether he will be ever given that degree of independence and responsibility by that body. I know there are some more sensitive souls on the Commission, certainly including the Deputy President, Peter Bailey, who I know is concerned to make the Commission work well. Significant progress has been made in the last few months in devising work programs and so on. But it is clear, so far as the Goverment is concerned, that it regards the Commission, finally thus established, as being an essentially cosmetic exercise designed more than anything else to satisfy potential critics overseas about Australia's inactivity in the domestic human rights arena. I do not want to go into a repetive diatribe on this matter because I have done it before but we know that the powers vested in the new Commission are limited in the extreme. Its jurisdiction is limited in the extreme, confined as it is for a start only to the Commonwealth level of governmental activities and not extending, as would be constitutionally possible under a more advantageous government, into the civil liberty depredations of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had occasion to describe the Commission recently as a paper mouse in that not only is it weak, but it also looks weak. I also had occasion to describe my reaction to most of the present commissioners on the Human Rights Commission, who have not, between them, chalked up-despite the credit in which they are held in one way or another in their various professions-or established any kind of reputation as vigorous and effective human rights campaigners. Indeed, as I have said elsewhere, they have barely rocked so much as a dinghy between them in their previous professional lives. That is the kind of body that has been created; that is the kind of personnel. One would have to have more optimism than I have that they are going to perform the job in the future that Mr Grassby and his staff have so effectively performed in the past just in the racial discrimination area. But so much for that.

If, as seems certain, the official voice of Mr Grassby is stilled in the future , nonetheless it must be said that his influence will linger on in the reports which have been put down in this Parliament over the last six years. They amount -this one, in particular, does- to a detailed record of just how endemic prejudice and discrimination continue to be in this community. They amount to a record and a description of just how much effort is needed, both at the educative level and at the conciliation and enforcement level to counteract the effects of that all too pervasive prejudice in both word and deed, that applies in the community. Mr Grassby's report is a record, as all too many of his previous reports have been, of just how little co-operation in the process of creating a more civilised and tolerant society he has received from a number of governments at an official level in this country, conspicuously, of course, the Queensland Government which is presently embarked on the enterprise of trying to rub out completely the Racial Discrimination Act by subjecting it to constitutional challenge in the High Court of Australia. It will be a black day, indeed, if the High Court, in the next couple of months when it hears and determines this case, does come to the conclusion that technically the powers are not there to establish this kind of national legislation.

This report is also, in particular, a record of how much racial intolerance there is, not just by deed or by the actions of publicans and public servants and so on, but how endemic still is racial intolerance and predjudice manifested by word in crude, offensive, racist literature. I want to say something more about this in a moment. One whole chapter of the report demonstrates, as previous reports have too, just the extent to which overtly racist organisations continue to operate in this country, many of them, only with a tiny number of people directly associated with them, others like the League of Rights, which under cover of one or another of a number of front organisations has many thousands of people subscribing directly or indirectly to the really rather crude racist tenets which are propagated by that organisation. That does, I think, raise a number of questions which I will come back to in just a moment about what our response as legislators, as policy makers for the whole community , ought to be to that phenomenon.

There are a couple of points that I specifically now want to make using the report as a base rather than specifically referring further to anything in it. The first point I make is one about the emergence of a more sophisticated kind of racism in the last year or two, particularly in recent months, which can be charted. We are, and have been for a long time, familiar, regrettably, with the kind of thuggish racist organisations which I have mentioned. We have been familiar, I suppose, in recent months, with some crude manifestations of racism showing their ugly heads again. I am referring, I suppose at one level, to the actions of the Queensland Government in challenging the Act, but more specifically and more obviously I am referring to the lunatic genocidal nonsense that was mouthed by Lang Hancock last year and the more recent calls for the return to the white Australia policy that were so vociferously promoted by the Victorian Returned Services League President, Bruce Ruxton, again in the latter months of last year. But it is not that to which I am referring. I think we are sophisticated enough as a society to be able to cope with that and to shrug it off as the crude excess that it obviously is.

What I find a little more alarming and what I want to draw to the attention of the Senate is the more sophisticated racism which I see as being evident in the attacks on multiculturalism which are being mounted, in particular, by people such as philosophy Professor Lauchlan Chipman at the University of Wollongong, a leading member of the Quadrant group of intellectuals whose views are particularly reported in a long article in the Melbourne Age on 2 October last year but have had a good deal of circulation elsewhere. Chipman describes the kind of multicultural society which people such as Al Grassby, of course, have been long promoting and which is very much crucial to my party's view of the world, as being 'divisive' and as the product of 'political opportunism'. He expresses himself as being opposed to the preservation of the separate integrity and identity of ethnic traditions on the grounds that, while some traditions are valuable, others are not and ought not to be encouraged. He implies the propriety of selectivity in the maintenance of different ethnic traditions. He says that the old policy of assimilation of different ethnic traditions within the larger Australian community was, by contrast, effective and a proper course of action to adopt.

Such a point of view, of course, assumes, and it does so in a very subtle way, that the Anglo-Saxon culture of which most of us are part, the Anglo-Saxon tradition, is superior and that other migrants and in particular black Australians, Aborigines, must improve themselves by becoming like us. Migrants treated as second-class citizens under the old assimilation policy that some of us can remember all too well will be only too well aware, in turn, of the kind of society that Professor Chipman and others like him in the Quadrant group have in mind for them. I think the sentiments of the white Anglo-Saxon superiority and all the nastiness that is associated with that underpins the thought of Chipman and his intellectual peer group-his very influential intellectual peer group-every bit as much as the kind of jingoistic bigotry of people like Lang Hancock and Ruxton. I believe it is our responsibility as parliamentarians and as public figures in one way or another to resist what I perceive to be an alarming tendency of this kind.

The other point I make-I will finish on this-relates to how we should react to these cruder forms of racist vilification as promulgated by organisations such as the League of Rights and many others much less well known and often much more overtly crude in the stuff that they produce. How should we, in fact, deal with it? Do we just note its existence, condemn it when we are confronted with documentation of the kind contained in chapter 4 of the present report and then pass on or do we do something about it? The International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination which Australia signed back in 1966 and which we ratified in the last months of the Whitlam Government on 30 September 1975 contains a clause which commits signing and ratifying parties to do something about this phenomenon. It is article 4 (a) and is in the following terms:
State Parties . . .

Shall declare an offence punishable by law all dissemination of ideas based on racial superiority or hatred, incitement to racial discrimination, as well as all acts of violence or incitement to such acts against any race or group of persons of another colour or ethnic origin, and also the provision of any assistance to racist activities, including the financing thereof;

When Australia ratified that Convention it did, in fact, express a reservation about the implementation of article 4 (a). That reservation, which was expressed by the Whitlam Government, was in the following terms:

''The Government of Australia . . . declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by article 4 (a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, public mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of article 4 (a).''

Since then nothing has happened. It was not possible for the Whitlam Government to do anything more about implementing that intended state of mind because, of course, the Whitlam Government was not with us a short two months after this ratification. It is inevitable that lively controversy will be generated by any attempt to legislate for the supression in any way at all of incitements to race hatred, the dissemination of racially offensive ideas. Obviously a tension has to be resolved between the demands of free speech, free debate and free comment, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, the very obvious disabilities involved for racial minorities in particular in our community who have to tolerate the kind of sentiment generated by that kind of propaganda. I am all too well aware of the difficulties of finding a satisfactory formula to legislate in this area because I was involved in another capacity in trying to draft the language of the original Racial Discrimination Act and to negotiate with the then Government Ministers on behalf of the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, some agreed and acceptable formula at a time when, as now, there was a hostile Senate. I am aware that it is a problem but it is a problem that I think is--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a co-operative Senate on that subject.

—It was a co-operative Senate in regard to the Racial Discrimination Bill as a whole but it was by no means co-operative when it came to particular parts of it. There was a good deal of give and take behind the scenes-there was not so much overtly in the chamber-between the successive presentations of the 1974 Bill and the final 1975 Bill. One of the bits to go during that transitional period was in fact the section designed to implement article 4 (a) of the international convention. I do not suggest that a dismissive attitude was taken by the then hostile majority in the Senate to that matter. It was just a matter of obvious difficulty in reaching an agreed formula . I do not underestimate the difficulty now of reaching cross-party consensus on that problem, but at the same time I do not think we ought to go on putting that issue into the too-hard basket.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that some initiatives are presently being planned within my own party, as I hope they will be in the Government parties and by the Australian Democrats, to come to grips with this issue and see whether we cannot, acting together in this larger matter of community interest, find some way of legislating effectively both to discharge our obligations under the international convention and, more importantly, to try to remove what is all too obviously and all too clearly a continuing running sore in our society. I am talking about the continued prevalence of manifestly offensive racist literature of no redeeming social benefit whatsoever.

Finally, I repeat that this report, which raises that question amongst others, is an admirable document, recording as it does the boundless efforts and the boundless energy and goodwill of an admirable Australian, Al Grassby, and his admirable staff. It is a matter for regret, I think, that the calumny that all too often has been heaped on his head by members of the governing parties over the last five or six years has not been matched by an equally overt appreciation of the fine work he has done and the fine series of reports that have been produced under his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to add some remarks to the comments already made by Senator Evans and Senator Missen on the appearance of the sixth annual report of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Like my colleague Senator Evans I greatly regret that this will be the last independent report coming from Mr Grassby as Commissioner for Community Relations. Because it is the last report, of course, it is of particular importance. As honourable senators will be aware, the reports coming from Mr Grassby in the past as Commissioner for Community Relations under the Racial Discrimination Act were the only independent source of information to this Parliament and to the Australian public generally on the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act. I am not one of those people who regard Australian society as particularly or inevitably racist.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans made reference to some of the racist organisations in this country, and their existance is a real blot on our national life. But, as Senator Evans pointed out, there are not many of them and they certainly do not have many adherents. We would like to have a society in which there are none. As I said, I believe that Australians are not inevitably or naturally racist and that many of the racist practices, particularly against Aborigines, have been carried out and have been able to be carried out because most Australians have not been aware that Australian Aborigines have been suffering this kind of discrimination. This, I believe, has been the real value of Mr Grassby's work; that through investigation and documentation and independent reporting to this Parliament he has been able to place on record the kinds of discrimination that Australian Aborigines have to endure. Thus he has been able to raise the consciousness of the Australian community and gain support for Government measures and community measures to bring about a truly racially tolerant society .

Of course, under the legislation passed by the Fraser Government in 1981 Mr Grassby, as Commissioner for Community Relations, will have to act upon and be subject to the directions of the Human Rights Commission. Both Senator Evans and Senator Missen have made some predictions about how this new relationship will work but, of course, I am inclined to agree with the predictions of Senator Evans. It seems to me that Mr Grassby's independence will be eroded under the new arrangements. It seems to me also that the Human Rights Commission, as currently structured, will not investigate and report to Parliament in the same vigorous and fearless manner on race relations in this country as Mr Grassby was able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unfairly prejudging the issue, surely.

—Senator Thomas suggests that that is an unfair prejudging of the situation. My response to that is to ask: If the Government wanted the kinds of reports on race matters that Mr Grassby has been making to continue to be made to this Parliament why did not the Government appoint Mr Grassby as one of the commissioners for the Human Rights Commission? If the Liberal Party totally supports this kind of brave investigative reporting to the Parliament then it ought to have allowed Mr Grassby to continue in that position by appointing him as a commissioner. I think that is a great set back to the new Commission. We all want it to succeed but obviously we have doubts. It is a grave setback to the Commission that Mr Grassby was not appointed as a full commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to how the changes of status will affect the work of the Commissioner for Community Relations and what the relationship between the Commissioner and the Human Rights Commission will be. The Commissioner states on page 6 of the sixth and final report:

The Commissioner has neither been consulted nor informed on the Government's policies, legislation or intentions and, until the new Commissioners have been appointed, the basis of operation within the amended legislative framework cannot be known.

I think it is a great shame that the Government did not consult Mr Grassby on this matter. Whilst the Human Rights Commission is now in operation and some excellent commissioners have been appointed to it, grave reservations about the Government's motives in amending the Racial Discrimination Act and altering the status of the Commissioner for Community Relations remain. I should make clear what I think the basis of the Government's watering down of the Racial Discrimination Act and putting aside of Mr Grassby is based on. I believe that it is based on the Federal Government's unwillingness to come into confrontation with the State governments of Western Australia and Queensland on race matters. I have said that in this place before and, unhappily, it will probably be necessary for me to say it again. It seems to me that the very forthright reports that Mr Grassby made on racist practices backed up by State governments in Western Australia and Queensland are the reason the Federal Government found itself unable to appoint Mr Grassby as a full commissioner. I would like to make it clear that I do not have objections to the establishment of the Human Rights Commission but I do object to the downgrading of the Commissioner for Community Relations in the process. Under the amended legislation the Commissioner no longer has the powers of a permanent head within the Australian Public Service, no longer has staff in his own right and, of course, as I have said, can no longer report directly to Parliament. The Commissioner for Community Relations has not been appointed as a member of the Human Rights Commission but has been made subordinate to it. It is my fear that this loss of independent statutory powers will limit the effectiveness of the Commissioner-a concern which has been echoed by many members of the community concerned with human rights.

For six years Mr Grassby's thorough and perceptive reports have provided the only ongoing monitoring of racial discrimination in this country. The education and research functions carried out by his office are unique in Australia and are invaluable if racial discrimination is to be eliminated. Through Mr Grassby's work we have learnt that racial discrimination in Australia is widespread and that the most severe and persistent racial discrimination is suffered by Aboriginal people. Mr Grassby's work in conciliating in cases of racial discrimination and bringing them to a peaceful resolution has had a high degree of success and has attracted international praise for Australia. So the Government's apparent intention not to re-appoint Mr Grassby in a commissioner role reflects on its political prejudices and not in any way on the calibre of Mr Grassby's work.

The importance of effective measures-by that I mean measures that can actually change the situation-to guarantee human rights in Australia cannot be underestimated. The Australian Constitution has no guarantee of human rights. Mr Grassby himself has pointed out in this report that the common law in Australia has not proved an effective champion of the rights of the oppressed and the disadvantaged. Mr Grassby has, however, proved a powerful figure in defending such rights. In this respect I express the hope that the Human Rights Commission will emulate him. In his current report Mr Grassby outlines also the pressures which his job has entailed and the reasons why autonomy is vital. On page 2 of his report he said:

It must be noted that in almost all the cases against Departments and statutory bodies, a ready response has been made to the Commissioner's inquiries under the Act, and indeed in most cases exemplary co-operation has been the order of the day.

In some cases, however, there has been a complete lack of co-operation, announced public hostility, attempts to interfere with the Commissioner in the performance of his duty, and great pressure either to drop investigations, abandon them, or bring them to a 'no conclusion'. Only an Office operating with complete independence can be expected to resist such pressures . . .

I endorse Mr Grassby's remarks. Unfortunately, no such independent office will now exist. It is obvious from previous reports of the Commissioner that the pressure and hostility that he describes have come mainly from this Government's Liberal and National Country Party colleagues in the Western Australian Government and the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government, as honourable senators will be aware, is currently challenging the validity of the Racial Discrimination Act in the High Court of Australia. This is a case of great importance as it will determine the future of anti-discrimination legislation in this country. Of course, I am happy to congratulate the Federal Government on its defence of the Racial Discrimination Act. I trust that the defence will be successful and, if not, that the Government will take urgent action, if necessary through constitutional amendment by referendum, to ensure the protection of human rights in this country.

In summary, I congratulate Mr Grassby on six years of very hard and very effective work against racial discrimination in this country. I am sure, speaking as the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that a majority of Aboriginal people in this country would join me in congratulating Mr Grassby. I simply express the hope that the newly formed Human Rights Commission will do as creditable a job as Mr Grassby has done in the last six years.

Similarly, I believe that there has been a view in the minds of many Australians that that kind of divisiveness has sometimes come from statements made-perhaps even with the best motives-by Mr Grassby in his role as Commissioner for Community Relations. I come back to my opening remarks when I said that the work of that office has been substantial and has been directed towards the achievement of a better society in Australia over these past years. I appeal to Opposition senators not to feel that they are the only ones bearing the burden of enlightenment, virtue and insight in this Parliament or in this country but to have some generosity towards others in the community having a like commitment to increasing understanding and good community relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

My brief remarks on this subject do not, I think, have the same potential to arouse the backwoodsmen of this Parliament as other remarks of mine have, but one is never quite sure. I congratulate the Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, and his staff for producing what we have come really to expect from him-a thorough, detailed and informative Ombudsman's report. I note that it is substantially abbreviated by comparison with the report for the previous year, 1979-80, for reasons which are spelt out on page 1, namely, the increased work load which has been placing a great demand on the resources of the Ombudsman's office. Nonetheless, the only respect in which the report is really reduced is in the detailed reporting of individual cases. The main features and the quality of the report are certainly maintained and a sufficient selection of individual case notes is given to give at least a flavour of the Ombudsman's operations.

It is particularly welcome that an officer to whom so many members of the public are having recourse should provide, through his annual reports, a clear account of his method and approaches to the resolution of problems that come before him. For example, last year there was in his report a very helpful discussion on his approach to the power to recommend a remedy where he concludes that an official action is, in the language of the Act, 'unreasonable or unjust' . This year there is, again by way of example, a very frank and useful account on pages 12 and 13 of the Ombudsman's interpretation of that provision in the Act which prohibits the Ombudsman from investigating a matter where there is in the individual a right to pursue some remedy in a Federal court or tribunal unless, the Act goes on to say, the failure to exercise that right is not unreasonable. It is a very vexed question for people trying to advise other people of their options as to just what all that means, and I am pleased to see that the Ombudsman has given us a full account of what that means in his view. I am also pleased to see that he exercises a very flexible approach in determining when a failure to pursue a formal remedy is in fact not unreasonable.

Some particular points need to be noted about the operation of the Ombudsman's office and the Government's facilitation of reasonable requests that have been forthcoming from it. The first point I make goes to the very obvious and visible expansion of the work load of the Ombudsman, which demonstrates the growing public awareness of the existence of the office and a perception of its effectiveness. Oral complaints, we are told, rose from 8,535 in 1979-80 to 11, 345 in the last financial year. Written complaints similarly expanded from 2,646 to 2,824. Last year's report expressed its support for a recommendation of the Administrative Review Council that the Act be amended to formalise and, in the process, to streamline the procedure for dealing with oral complaints, but this appears still not to have been acted upon by this Government. I take this opportunity, as I will briefly with respect to several other matters, to draw attention to that failure to act. It is on these occasions when dealing with these reports that these points should be brought home to the Government about its failure to move.

Then again, and very importantly, there is a whole series of jurisdictional problems which have continued to plague the operation of the Ombudsman's office. The last two reports have referred to the need for extensive statutory amendments to resolve these jurisdictional problems. They were listed, for example, in the 1979-80 report as including, among others, the following difficulties: The definition of prescribed authority; the scope of Commonwealth employment matters from dealing with which the Ombudsman is precluded; the definition of statutory office holders; how to deal with bodies not established by statute; the question of private bodies in receipt of Commonwealth funds; the question of State bodies in receipt of Commonwealth funds; and questions relating to complaints about government policies. Each one of those areas raises very difficult jurisdictional questions. On all of them the Administrative Review Council has made recommendations of one kind or another, but there is still no sign of remedial legislation forthcoming. Nor is there evident on the part of the Government any attempt to implement another recommendation made by the Ombudsman in his report which would help in a partial way to solve these problems; that is, the suggestion made on page 11 of the report that the Act be amended to enable the Ombudsman to apply to the Federal Court himself for the determination of jurisdictional disputes between the Ombudsman and a department. One asks, no doubt to the empty air in the absence of the relevant Minister from this chamber, what will be done about this request for a procedural machinery to be created for everyone's convenience?

A number of other problems in the operation of the Ombudsman's office and the exercise of his jurisdiction are evident from the report. They are lingering sores from year to year about which no action seems to be taken. Let me mention finally just two of them. There is the problem of de facto relationships, dealt with at page 34 of the report, and the differing treatment and administration of claims arising from de facto relationships by the Taxation Office, on the one hand, and the much more insensitive, as has been the case in so many respects, Department of Social Security on the other. If the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who happens to be sitting at the table at the moment, has anything to offer by way of comment on that differential treatment of de facto relationships by the Taxation Office, on the one hand, and the less liberal Social Security Department on the other, we would be delighted to hear from him. That is a long-running problem to which the Ombudsman refers which clearly it has not been possible to resolve satisfactorily, notwithstanding successive mentions of the problem in his report.

Then there is the other continuing saga of Telecom Australia. One successful resolution of a problem in relation to Telecom is described on page 21 of the report. At the same time the Ombudsman points to the fact that, as he has indicated previously, there is still a fundamental problem in that section 101 of the Telecommunications Act 1975 renders Telecom immune from actions for loss suffered by persons by reason of any default, delay, error or omission, whether negligent or otherwise, by Telecom. There is a continuing saga of injustices which seem to have been denied remedy by virtue of that statutory prohibition. That is not something the Ombudsman himself can solve. It just means that he has to try to negotiate solutions in the absence of those legal remedies. It is clearly a problem in the fair administration of the present law which is adverted to. It demands a Government response and we wait in vain for one.

The Ombudsman's report is not by any means just an account of problems that have been experienced by the office. It is also a record of very considerable achievement now over the four years or so that the office has been in active existence. Many more individual matters are the subject of report in some detail in this document and there are very many illustrations of the extraordinarily valuable role that this office continues to play in making Australian government more sensitive and more accessible than otherwise it undoubtedly would be.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT ON GRANTS TO VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION ORGANISATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Statement by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This statement was made by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) in relation to the report on grants to voluntary conservation organisations which was presented to the House of Representatives in May 1980. As the statement shows, the report, although it was a report to the other House, has been of great interest to those who are interested in environmental matters and in the question of the funding of environmental organisations. The report arose originally from a request by Senator Webster in 1979 for a report on the program. It was therefore looked on with eager anticipation.

The report which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation put down analysed the change over a period of years in the financing by the Commonwealth Government of voluntary organisations. I regret to say that that funding has, in real terms, declined quite considerably. Paragraph 35 of the Committee's report states:

The Committee notes the comments on the amount of money allocated to this program. Grants totalling $323,000 were made in 1973-74 to 17 organisations, on the basis of recommendations of the Hope Committee. In 1979-80, $350,000 was allocated to 26 Organisations. In real terms the amount of support provided by the Government has dropped considerably, although support from other sources has increased.

It is a matter of concern to me, as chairman of the Government members home affairs and environment committee, that there has been a quite considerable whittling away in real terms of the amount provided. Of course, the grants now are to cover 26 organisations rather than 17. Therefore, when the House of Representatives Committee made proposals I had a great deal of support for them. Grants to conservation bodies were made on the basis that for every $2 of Commonwealth money provided up to a specified amount the conservation group must provide $1. In 1979-80 this was changed to a dollar for dollar basis. It was suggested that it was not desirable to impose further demands upon organisations which, by and large, are busy in the conservation area but which may not be terribly brilliant at the raising of money. They do not have great sources of supply.

In the ministerial statement which was tabled, one finds that the Government strongly supports the grants to voluntary conservation bodies but, regrettably, as one reads it, it is clear that although this is declared to be a healthy sign of democracy, the result of the ministerial decision is that the recommendations for additional funding or a relaxation of funding requirements are not to be acceded to this year. One brighter aspect is that for 1982-83 it is said that the case for additional funding as presented by the Committee will be considered . But I regret to say that in the last few years, as the value of that funding has declined, there has been no change. One must hope that it will at last be recognised that every year means a further loss in the support which these organisations get. Likewise, the Government has not acceded to the request that the dollar for dollar matching requirement be relaxed. It says that there should be a decrease in the dependence of conservation groups on government. The situation has come to a stage where the amounts of money they are getting from government are relatively small parts of their income. I think that a lack of funds greatly inhibits organisations which very often have to present massive submissions requiring a great deal of competence. The organisations come up against mining groups, companies and all kinds of organisations with a great deal of expertise at their disposal. The work of conservation organisations is becoming more and more difficult.

The Committee also recommended that additional funding be given to conservation groups to enable them to undertake special projects. Regrettably, again the Government has found that this is not possible and has decided that no special fund is to be established. On the other hand, the Government has agreed to the Committee's recommendation in respect of the eligibility criteria for funding under the program. It has acceded to widening those criteria so organisations will have a better opportunity of qualifying. A major recommendation made by the House of Representatives Committee was that the basis for advice in allocating funds should be the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the principal conservation organisations in each State as well as the organisations under the Minister's control. Unfortunately, that recommendation has not been acceded to. I regret it because I believe that those organisations have a very considerable knowledge of who is doing the effective work in this area. It should not be left merely to ministerial advice from the Ministers' departments.

I know that organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation have found that their grants have been eaten into over the years. The effectiveness of these organisations is weakened by the failure to increase considerably the total amount available to volunatary organisations. In moving that the Senate take note of the paper, I regret the paucity of hope and encouragement which the paper gives. I hope that in the determinations for 1982-83 there will at last be a recognition of the fact that if we believe in conservation and voluntary work being done by organisations we also have to be prepared at least to maintain the value of those grants in response to the inflation rate. In fact, they are falling behind year by year.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen made the point that conservation organisations are doing a reasonable and worthy job, and I respect him for putting that point of view. It is not in the interests of the future. I urge people such as Senator Martyr who have a categorical view that there is nothing good about conservationists to think again, to think what sort of world all of our great grandchildren will see if somebody does not take into account what will happen at assets such as the Mount Windsor Tableland which are genuinely irreplaceable within any span of time that we can think of. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the remarks made on this matter by Senator Missen and Senator Mason and to be critical of the unenlightened contribution of Senator Martyr. I think the best example of that was the movement to save Fraser Island. Unfortunately, those of us who were involved also with saving Lake Pedder did not succeed in doing that. But we certainly did, with assistance and by creating public interest and public awareness, finally see a position taken by the Federal Labor Government on that matter. The stance was taken by the then Prime Minister Mr Whitlam and followed through, to his credit, by Prime Minister Fraser. SPEECH.PARA: I think it is wrong to get into an area of controversy as Senator Martyr attempted to do. He suggested that we should see one thing against another. In fact, government encouragement and support for community action groups is, I think, a very worthwhile obligation that governments ought to have. If we look at the work that is being carried on by many conservation groups we see that they are, as Senator Mason indicated, not concerned with self-advancement but with protecting the community's interests and assets. I allowed the Minister to do so on that occasion because I felt he would relate his remarks back to the aspect of funding which came into discussions.
