SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I will restrict my remarks specifically to the ninth annual report of the Criminology Research Council. The Criminology Research Council was established as a result of an Act of Parliament in 1971 and was formally established in 1972 . We have before us its ninth report. As we are dealing with some 47 reports this afternoon it is likely that the work of this important organisation may well not be recognised by the Parliament. I have certainly been very impressed in following the work of the organisation over the years. I am particularly impressed by the work that the organisation still has in the pipeline. I became aware, I suppose in the last 10 or 15 years, of the importance to human behaviour of the problems that flow as a result of a whole number of environmental effects upon individuals-what they do to the individual and what they do to society and humanity generally. Therefore, I commend the decision of the national Parliament some 10 years ago to establish this organisation and to review the work that it has carried out.

I am sure Senator Baume would be with me 100 per cent on this because I know that he and some other members of his party are concerned with human behaviour and the great difficulties that we have with recurrent criminality and the problems of anti-social behaviour that are so much a part of modern civilisation . Therefore, it is with regret that we see this organisation having to say in its report that it has to draw the attention of the Parliament to the relatively low level of income provided to the Criminology Research Fund. I hope that we will not be as at daggers drawn on this debate as we were in the previous one. As the report indicates, the Council's current income of $100,000 per annum is the same amount as it received in 1972. As we know, the rate of inflation has increased several times in that period. It is clear that the work of the organisation is considerably retarded by its receiving the same amount in money terms as it received in 1972. It therefore ought to be of some concern to the Senate that the Council has provided funds for 77 separate research projects over those years to a total of $803,000.

Let us look at the work that the Council has done. A program inquiring into juvenile delinquency in planned urban areas, a survey of juvenile offenders, a study of migrant crime in Australia, an examination of a children's court hearing and what that does to teenagers, a study of community-based treatment for young offenders, a study of the behavioural effects in three simulated prison environments and a whole number of projects have been carried out by this organisation. In the brief moments that are left to me I want to refer to the projects that are currently being considered by this organisation. These include a study of the impact of Australian criminal law on remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. Surely that is one project that would be of interest to members of the Parliament and particularly to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I have had the opportunity, as I am sure the honourable senator has, of visiting those areas. We can understand what impact white civilisation has had. This is important work that the Council is doing. The Council has approved research grants for a literature review on recidivism which is, of course, important because of the repeated turnover of criminals in our penal institutions. A grant has been made for a project to be conducted on juvenile runaways and alternatives to incarceration.

A very important survey is under way into mental retardation and its relation to stealing. It appears that there is a high incidence of people who are partly mentally retarded who also have an impulse to steal. We know what that means. When those people get into the hands of the authorities, the police, they are treated in exactly the same way as people who have all of their faculties. The Council has provided funds for research into criminal law in the bedroom as a result of the legislation carried out in the South Australian Parliament. I will not extend that issue. There is a pilot scheme dealing with diversion and prevention of juvenile delinquency called the 'Time Out' program which was initiated in late 1978. The report states:

It was hoped to establish a program that would be attractive to a group of young people, seen as being 'at risk' by the teachers at the high school they attended. In the short term, the aims were merely to involve these young people in enjoyable activities in an effort to promote the constructive use of leisure time, and to aid the development of initiative, confidence and feelings of self worth.

Surely that is a very important work that is being carried out by this organisation. I do not believe in the Government's general philosophy that if we spend money in these areas it is a misuse of public funds, that the funds all ought to be diverted to the private sector in the hope that somehow or other they will rectify all the ills of modern society. I hope that the Government, having regard to the excellent work being done by this organisation and by many people in the academic area, will ultimately allocate sufficient funds to enable this work to be proceeded with, completed and extended. We must avoid the tremendous waste of human activity, the tremendous waste of public funds with people being incarcerated-some 9,000 people are in our prisons in Australia-and the high turnover of people who commit crimes regularly. They need some understanding by Governments and by communities. This sort of work should be carried on so that we will have a more rehabilitative approach to these sorts of problems instead of just putting people in penal institutions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRE-FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF A URANIUM ENRICHMENT INDUSTRY IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have been waiting for some time to speak on this subject. It is some irony that under General Business for tonight honourable senators will see listed the same kind of report, I think, going back to 1979. We are only just starting to debate that. It is rather nice, I suppose, to be able to debate a report that is a little more recent even though we have had this study waiting to be dealt with since 26 November 1981.

I want to speak to it to make it quite plain that the Australian Democrats are flatly opposed to the establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in Australia because we believe that such an industry would introduce to this country all of the least desirable aspects of the uranium industry. I think it has been shown in many parts of the world that enrichment is a dangerous enterprise in itself, whichever technology of the three that are available is used. It is dangerous not only because radioactive materials have to be handled constantly and this somehow has to be reconciled with the safety if the human beings who are working with them, but also because of the constant risk of criticality of enriched materials in quantities-not very large quantities; just a few kilograms- accidentally come together. That, of course, can result in a nuclear explosion.

Honourable senators may recall that there have been persistent reports of a huge disaster in the Soviet Union-reports which have been so persistent, I think , as to be worth giving some credence to. This disaster is considered by many respectable authorities to be due to amounts of plutonium held together as waste coming into contact and exploding. Of course, it is a known scientific fact that if highly enriched material beyond a certain volume is brought together it certainly will explode. That is the way the nuclear process works.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a critical atmosphere?

—No, there is no necessity for any kind of critical atmosphere. What is necessary is that a piece of highly enriched uranium 235 or plutonium and another piece are brought together at sufficient speed and in a certain way.
—At what percentage of enrichment?

—That is a matter that is debatable. Unfortunately, the Russian experience and things like that show that enrichment at not a very great degree might cause an explosion if plutonium is involved. When one is enriching uranium one will have by-products. I think it is the intensity of the by-products which has to be considered, not just the uranium that one is enriching. It is the residuals from the fuel elements that have been reprocessed that we have to consider in addition to the--
—We are not talking about processing, we are talking about enrichment.
—Order! I think Senator Collard can give the Senate the benefit of his report later on.

—Senator, I think we are talking about residuals. I would hesitate to try to educate the honourable senator but if he takes fuel rods, he will get some hundreds or possibly thousands of isotopes in the spent rods if he enriches and reprocesses those rods. However, I take the point that has been made by the honourable senator. I suggest that it would be naive to consider that we would have in this country an enrichment technique without also a reprocessing one. I think the two things go together economically in such a way that one would lead inevitably to the other.
—Why?
—It would be good if at some later stage we could get a reassurance from the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) that indeed that would not be considered.
—I do not understand why you have said that. They are two quite separate things.

—But they associate themselves quite conveniently with the same industry. If the Minister feels that he can give an assurance that that kind of enrichment industry in Australia will not lead philosophically or because of its technologies to a reprocessing industry of spent fuel rods, from whatever source , I would be delighted to hear that. Perhaps the Minister can take that one on board and give me that assurance when he is ready to do so. If he did that it would reassure a large number of people in Australia who are concerned. This is really the point at issue. There are people in Australia who take the view that I do. Very many of them are concerned that there should be any type of industry in Australia which associates itself with the nuclear process. Having got one I think it is quite likely that we will get the other.

SPEECH.PARA: We might eventually consider, as we have large amounts of U238 which are available as a result of the enriching of uranium extensively in U235-honourable senators will know that U238 is a by-product of that process-that we will get into the fast breeder technology as well. It appears to be an attractive proposition from one point of view. I think we have to look very carefully at all aspects of the beginnings of a nuclear industry in this country. That is really what this matter is about. The Government has said now that it is considering looking at an enrichment program. I see this as a first step towards a complete nuclear industry in this country in all its aspects. If the Minister is in a position to reassure the public that that is not the case I will be only too grateful to hear that reassurance from him during this debate. As I said, it is salutary to note that there have been persistent reports of a huge disaster in the Soviet Union due to amounts of plutonium being held as waste coming into contact and exploding. Of course, it is not possible also to retain the security of uranium that has been enriched to a certain proportion which can then be taken by some other person at some stage and enriched to a greater proportion. The history of the world's security precautions for nuclear materials is such that we cannot derive any comfort whatsoever from it. There has been a persistent history over the years of the loss of nuclear materials in quite substantial quantities; certainly substantial enough quantities to make nuclear weapons. Probably some of those things which have been lost have been made into nuclear weapons-certainly that uranium oxide which was carried in the cargo of the ship Sheersberg A which went missing. When the ship arrived at its destination the uranium oxide had disappeared. It went somewhere. It has been said frequently by a number of people-this is a matter of record-that it went to Israel where it was used to make nuclear weapons. That may or may not be so but the amount of money and the amount of time and effort that went into the Sheersberg A exercise were such that obviously it was not done for fun. Somebody put enormous amounts of money into the diversion of that cargo. It is of great interest to us that in the report of the Uranium Advisory Council it has got out from under on the question of the economy or otherwise of the industry. It says on page 8 of its report:

The second consideration relates to the economics of enrichment processing-the balance between construction and operating costs and marketing prospects. The Council does not regard itself as competent to offer a valid judgment as to the economic viability of an enrichment project.

I thought that this was something to which the Government would have been giving its mind. I hope that it is because I think in more ways than one one of the 64 dollar questions is: Whether or not there is value in this country having a nuclear enrichment process.

If that is the case I would like to draw to the Government's attention one other implication which I think should be taken into account-an important implication for ordinary Australians, for everbody in this country who owns a house or any other type of real estate. It derives from the fact that any damage caused to homes or other property through any accident involving such nuclear materials that will be moving around the country if we start to develop ourselves into nuclear technologies would not be covered by insurance. As anybody who has read the fine print on his insurance policy will know, there is now what is called 'a nuclear exclusion'. That means that if enriched material or any nuclear material is in transit in any kind of vehicle and there is an accident that damages or contaminates property the unfortunate owners of that property will not get a single cent to compensate them, even though they have fully paid up insurance policies. There are too many people in this country who have not read that fine print or who have not understood it. I believe it is time that the Government had a look at it as indeed the Government in the United States has had to do. If we are to set up an enrichment industry in this country or we are to have reprocessing or fast breeder reactors or whatever-Western Australians have said that they will have a nuclear powerhouse-then there should be--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Sir Charles Court said that Western Australia was to have one.
—Who?
—Sir Charles Court. Did not Sir Charles Court say that Western Australia was to have a nuclear powerhouse?
—He did not.
—I am delighted to hear that Western Australia is not to have one.
—He is not the Premier of Western Australia.
—That is what he said when he was the Premier. Do all of his utterances no longer count for anything because he is no longer Premier?
—The new Premier has said something different. You ought to keep up with what is happening.
—I am obliged to the honourable senator for that information. I would like him to put it on the record by way of interjection. Is Western Australia not to have a nuclear powerhouse?
—You may read what the new Premier has said.
—I suggest that the honourable senator is wriggling on the pin. I have asked him to reply to me that it is indeed to his knowledge that Western Australia will not have a nuclear powerhouse.
—Order! Senator Mason, I think quite often you attract interjections. It would be of benefit to the Senate to address the Chair .

—I am not objecting to the interjection. What worries me is that I do not have an honest reply to it. To return to the point, this nuclear exclusion in insurance policies has to be counted as a huge debit cost to Australia of a nuclear enrichment industry. As I have said, it will leave people with fully paid up insurance policies who ought to be protected-who are protected in every other way-not protected at all as the insurance industry has washed its hands of that kind of risk. The mere fact that it has washed its hands of that kind of risk is highly significant. It did this more than a decade ago; it did this because it understood then, being very concerned with money, that the time would certainly come when huge pay-outs would have to be made under policies unless the nuclear exclusion was there. That was why the nuclear exclusion was put into the policies. I think it is time that the Government looked at that matter and gave some sort of assurance to the people of this country. If indeed we are so foolish as to have this industry here, if there is an accident, if there is damage, or if there is contamination of people's property, the Government should give an undertaking to underwrite that damage completely. That is the only basis upon which the matter could operate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many millions of people throughout the world-I suggest possibly tens of millions now-who are very concerned at a process of gradualism in which high fall-out, dirty, fission-type weapons, the crude Hiroshima-Nagasaki-type atom bomb, will proliferate in the world and will come into use in an increasing range of regional wars. There is evidence that a number of countries are already using their nuclear reactors to breed material. It is a fact that many types of ordinary, so-called power reactors will produce plutonium far more quickly than a fast breeder reactor which produces it rather slowly. When I use the word ' fast', honourable senators will know that I am referring to the speed of the neutrons.

What will be the situation if the atom bomb continues to proliferate in the world and comes into use in a range of regional wars? Of course, contamination will result throughout the world with accelerating rates of spontaneous abortion , foetus malformation and very much higher rates of all forms of cancer. As to the risk of an explosion of fission weapons I would welcome a reply from the Government to the effect that those consequences would not ensue. I think it has already been demonstrated that they would. These would become permanent factors of life generation after generation, because it is the nature of such contaminants to remain in the environment for many centuries, sometimes for thousands of years because of their very long half-lives. So we could have a situation in which regional wars took place, wars which we could see only on our television screens, and quite unknown to us, quite unseen by us, the contamination would continue and its often fatal and always health diminishing consequences would reap their silent effect on our people from the time they were in the womb to the time they died. I cannot believe that Australia and the Australian Government would willingly want to contribute to such a process.

I am concerned-and here again I put this matter to the Minister-at the apparent lack of government concern because of its want of any response or reply to recent publicity asserting that Australian uranium will find its way into nuclear weapons. There was this interesting point on page 9 in section 26 of this report:

The risk of nuclear proliferation 'inherent in enrichment technologies' also has to be considered. The Council must assume that the Commonwealth Government would not authorise the establishment of a commercial enrichment plant without ensuring that it was subject to the effective international safeguards, institutional controls and surveillance measures that the INFCE Working Group believes can minimise the risk of diversion of low enriched uranium for production of weapons grade material.

I am quoting the report, not some statement of my own. I draw particularly to the attention of honourable senators the word 'minimise'. This is a new word. In the past it was said that these safeguards worked; that there would not be any materials. But the word 'minimise' is rather a subjective word, is it not? One can minimise something if one reduces the risks from 100 per cent to 80 per cent . One can minimise something if one reduces the risk from 100 per cent to 95 per cent. I am saying that that sentence does not hold water; that if that sentence is taken into policy it will mean that Australian uranium in dangerous quantities could find its way regularly, persistently and continuously through to weapons grade material. That is something which should lie very heavily on our national conscience because it is not necessary for us to indulge in this industry at all.

A final point needs to be made about suggestions that the United States would find in Australia a handy source of enriched uranium for its weapons program. This is another matter on which some statement from the Government would be very welcome-whether in fact such action is contemplated, whether the Government would entertain such an approach, whether it would feel that it was the right thing for us to do to provide enriched uranium to the United States for the large and increasing numbers of new nuclear weapons which President Reagan now proposes to make and for which he is going to find great difficulty in getting weapons grade material. This could result in the most appalling consequences for Australia, especially that part of Australia in which the enrichment facility was located, since an enrichment plant providing weapons material to an ally would be a prime nuclear target in time of war. The consequences of its being bombed during an operational phase when it had large amounts of fissionable material within it, I think, are rather alarming. I would like to feel that we in Australia are not quite reconciled to the fact that our enriched uranium will be diverted to make weapons.

With all respect, I make a plea to the Australian Labor Party on this matter because I think nothing could be more important than that it should maintain the stand which so many members of the Australian Labor Party and so many ALP members of Parliament, including senators, take on this subject. I think they agree with the uncompromising stand that the Australian Democrats take; that we should not be exporting uranium, that we should not have an enrichment industry, that we should not have nuclear power houses; and that by doing so we are merely indulging in a lemming-like rush towards a brink. At times in the past Senator Carrick has said to me that the alternative is for the illegitimates to be cold in the dark, and things like that. I suggest that it is much better to try to cope with that in other ways. Perhaps whoever is cold in the dark might put on an extra cardigan or something like that if they are short of electric power. I would have thought that the other prospects, of proliferation of fissionable weapons, of major contamination, of difficulties in getting rid of waste materials and of the long term effects on generations to come, would have been more serious and that we should try to seek other solutions to problems of energy in the world rather--

TALK.START.PARA: —Other solutions than putting on an extra cardigan too, I would think.

—Indeed, that is true though I would like briefly to comment on that point. We talked earlier today about electricity in New South Wales. There is no doubt at all that a genuine, dedicated and well-thought-out electricity conservation program can cut consumption down to perhaps 50 or 60 per cent of what a community would normally use. That certainly was the case in California and elsewhere. In Sydney one still sees the lights on in buildings at night and things of that sort. I would have thought that there were approaches that could be made. One is that the Government could go further, as I have suggested here before-let me suggest it again-and give genuine tax concessions, along the lines of those given in California and in many other States of the United States as well as in Japan and many other countries, to people who install energy saving devices such as solar appliances, insulation and things of that kind. I think the time is right for the Government to consider that idea. I think it would find most Australians on side because there are now about 110,000 solar heaters in Australia. Everybody wants to put one in. Why should they not be helped with that rather considerable initial capital cost if it is going to reduce our requirement to build new powerhouses and to go on producing energy? Why produce energy simply to waste it? Why do it if there are other alternatives? That is the point that needs to be made here.
—You know that there are electric hot water services with a solar booster.
—Yes, and I approve of them. They are very good but unfortunately many councils still will not grant concession rates to people who install them, which is rather silly.
—You did hear what I said? I said there are electric hot water services with a solar booster.

—I understood Senator Martyr to say 'solar with an electric booster', but what is the difference basically? There are two ways of heating water; one is solar, the other is electric. I would have thought that there was no great difference. Anyway, that is obviously a point that Senator Martyr does not want to debate. I am talking to the Labor Party rather than to him at this stage. If the Labor Party finds that there are people in its midst who talk of jobs in the uranium industry-and it is very important for people to have jobs-I would like to draw their attention to the experience of Nuclear Fuel Services, an organisation in the United States which some years ago was involved in the reprocessing situation.
—I take it you are advising us on this matter with the expertise you have in completely changing your own policy.
—No. We have not changed our policy on this matter at all.
—No, not on this matter.

—No, I do not think so. I think that on this matter we are not likely to change our policy. We have not changed our policy on anything. We simply change our tactics. I want to put one other point. I suggest that Senator Button listen to it because there is a point to it so far as jobs in the nuclear industry are concerned. Jobs in Nuclear Fuel Services did not pan out terribly well for the people who took them, especially for some of its casual workers. It was the custom in that organisation to hire people regularly to do work where there was a high radioactivity risk, such as in maintenance and so on. Young unemployed people and people of that sort took the heaviest possible doses of radiation in a short period for very high wages. There was no control over whether these young people might eventually go to another place where they would also go through a similar situation and be exposed to high radiation for a certain time. It is increasingly becoming the view of respectable scientists that there is no really safe minimum dose of radiation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunately the case-as Nuclear Fuel Services proved-that if one is going to maintain or keep running any facility which has to be repaired and which does have areas that are radioactive, one must accept the risk of having to use people in high risk situations. I would have thought that this was not an area of employment which would be particularly appealing to anybody. These technologies, of course, are not particularly labour intensive-they are capital intensive-but, and the word 'but' is important, when it comes to having to repair things or to pull then apart or to do work of high risk-there is a labour intensity and one which costs very dearly because not only does it use up man hours but also it exposes people to degrees of radiation over a period which remains with them and can cause problems throughout the rest of their lives. I say, with respect, that the ALP ought to consider very carefully whether it should hold to the view-I know many of its members and senators do-that we should not have a nuclear industry at all, or whether it will allow itself to be tempted by expediency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the tabling of a paper by the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia called 'Pre-feasibility Study for the Establishment of a Uranium Enrichment Industry in Australia'. That paper has been tabled against the background that in the world around us, operating now and over the past 20 years, there are 220 or more nuclear reactors providing electric power. An equal number of such reactors are under construction and a roughly similar number are on the drawing boards. So, the world around us has a very considerable number of nuclear reactors which are vital to its electric power supply, and that number will double or perhaps treble. There has been 20- odd years of practical commercial and domestic experience in the use of those reactors. That is the first situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second situation which is important is that, despite what Senator Mason has said, the International Energy Agency, which comprises some 21 nations of this world and therefore has some collective wisdom, has representation from governments of all political faiths-of socialist faith and of Liberal faith. That agency has said that no matter how much energy conservation there is, no matter how much use of renewable energy such as solar power there is and no matter how much use of coal or gas there is, it will be vital for the world's living standards and for the economic and political stability of the world that there be a growing use of nuclear power generation for peacetime purposes. Let me get that quite clear. It is facile to the nth degree to say: 'Could we not have solar power?' I would be the last to say anything in denigration of the use of renewable power, but I ask those who speak here to understand the state of the art today. I remind them that most of the processes for the generation of solar power in use today consume more energy in their construction than they save in their use. The fact is that it is facile to talk of solar power. I do not want to denigrate solar power in any way. But I repeat that the International Energy Agency is made up of 21 nations of all political persuasions, every one of them composed of people who have at least as much regard for human life as Senator Mason does, who have great concern that we do not get any genetic mutations or damage people and who are unanimous in one thing, that despite the use of alternatives, the world cannot survive for the future unless it uses nuclear power for peacetime purposes. That is the background which was conveniently overlooked.

The second thing that was conveniently overlooked was that a commission of inquiry was set up in Australia-it has come to be known as the Ranger inquiry or the Fox inquiry-to study the various steps; and it indicated that it was perfectly safe, under reasonable conditions, to mine and mill uranium. It went on to say that it was safe, under proper safeguards, to enrich uranium and that the operation of nuclear power stations was safe under ordinary safeguards. It could have gone on to point out-this is a thing on which the opponents are silent-that the use of coal in power generation has a very bad record in terms of health. The people of the world with some knowledge of the effect of coal upon human health, of the effect of coal in creating a hot house situation in the destruction of the ecology, and of the effect of coal in creating acid rain believe that the increased use of coal will be a much greater threat to the total ecology and ecosystem of this world and a greater danger to the health of the human race than any alternatives. This is all recorded and documented and can be provided. I wish that those who are pursuing a political line would at least concede that, although there are needs for safeguards, the track record of uranium is that it is much more healthy and much safer than other ways of generating power. Indeed, the radiation fall-out of coal fired power stations is a genetic threat to the population.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I am interrupting in a constructive way. There is expensive technology, is there not, which can control that problem?

—Not to solve it, but to mitigate it, yes. Of course, we would want to do that. Let me say this: We all absorb radioactivity in the courses of our lives from our bodies, from the rocks around us and from the atmosphere above us. Of course, one has a choice between elective absorption and compulsory absorption. Should one elect to live in Sydney, which would be a wise choice, one would be absorbing from the ordinary ecosystem about 100 millirads of radioactivity at any time. One would be absorbing it from the rocks, from one 's body and from the atmosphere. In addition, one would be absorbing two more millirads, making it 102, because of the residue from all atomic bomb tests of the past. Should one elect to live in Canberra one elects to add two more millirads. That is the amount that the residue from all atomic bombs has put into the atmosphere over a period. I say that not to justify atomic testing but to illustrate the relative situations. Should one elect to fly from here to Perth one would take on much more radioactivity, and should one elect to live in altitudes such as those in Brazil one would absorb much more indeed. So, one must be very careful about trying to frighten people about these kinds of situations. Of course, there must be safeguards.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that the world around us has nuclear power stations and will build twice as many of them, let me state what this report is all about. A group of four Australian companies was asked to look at the commercial feasibility of enriching uranium for peacetime purposes. At the moment Australia is exporting yellowcake and will continue to do so to provide the world with its basic fuel for reactors.

TALK.START.PARA: —And for bombs.

—No. I emphatically deny that Australia is exporting any yellowcake for any purpose other than for peacetime nuclear power generation . I will elaborate on that and make perfectly clear the degree of control. People constantly talk of yellowcake as though it were some highly radioactive material. In fact it is poisonous to eat but it is very low in radioactivity. Yellowcake is exported but it needs to be enriched to a certain extent to be used in nuclear power plants. The enrichment that is necessary for the use of yellowcake-that is, taking it through two stages from yellowcake by conversion to uranium hexafluoride, which is a combination of the yellowcake plus the gas fluorine-is a chemical process. It is in any way dangerous only in the sense that any chemical process is dangerous; otherwise it is not. Then the gas, the uranium hexafluoride, is basically spun around to separate U235 and U238.

SPEECH.PARA: So the original percentage of about 0.7 per cent is raised to about 3.7 per cent. The yellowcake is in no way enriched to a level that could be of any use at all in making nuclear weapons. Indeed, no government that has signed the Treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons would allow within its community an enrichment plant that would in any way lift the level of its enrichment to nuclear weapons percentages. Let it be quite clear that when that process is undertaken all we are doing is enriching the fuels and providing more of it for use inside the reactor. The enrichment plant itself constitutes no particular radiation hazard. It is like all plants of that kind. It is necessary for it to exercise the ordinary safeguards for health but it is in no way a health hazard.

I think Senator Mason talked about bombing. Of course no one would want an enrichment plant to be destroyed but it would not constitute any more risk in that regard than bombing some other toxic manufacturing plant. The enrichment itself is for peacetime purposes. Australia, as the result of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, set up a code of safeguards in this country, signed the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty and established the Australian Safeguards Office. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty insists that the countries that sign it will not sell their fissile material to anybody for use in weapon making or to any nation that has not signed the Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Russia is not a signatory.
—We do not in fact sell uranium to Russia.
—Not directly.

—Let me examine that matter with Senator Chipp. I understand what Senator Chipp is saying-that some of the countries to which we sell our uranium have an enrichment process undertaken by Russia. That in itself constitutes no possibility of adding to Russia's weapon stocks. I want to make it perfectly clear that Russia, sadly for this world, is so awash with plutonium that the thought by anyone that it would want to sneak some uranium from around the world is, if I may say so, completely false. At the risk of annoying people, shall I say that it is another error of judgment. The fact of the matter is that Russia is awash with plutonium. That is one of the tragedies of this world. Indeed, so is America. The concept that Russia would sneak a little and put it in its pocket to make a weapon-assuming that it could do so-is to the nth degree ludicrous. It cannot do so because the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty operates also with the International Atomic Energy Agency which is an international auditor of a stringent kind. Also, Australia has its Australian Safeguards Office.
—There are too few inspectors in the International Atomic Energy Agency.

—There may be too few. If that is the case there is an argument to have more. I do not know that there are too few. I am not saying that all is perfect in a perfect world; to the contrary. I am describing the world around us. In Australia we have our code for the handling of fissile materials, and that is being observed. We have the Australian Safeguards Office, the job of which is to audit the movement of all our fissile material from the moment it leaves our shores over the whole of its lifetime. So the material is audited not only in its form as yellowcake but also in its conversion to hexafluoride, in its conversion through the enrichment process, in its conversion to fuel rods, in its reprocessing and in its disposal. There is always a complete audit going on both by--
—Do we audit in Russia too?

—We audit the going in and the coming out of the enrichment process; that is, the going into the country that has bought from us the material for enriching and the coming out in volume. Senator Macklin said: ' . . . in Russia too'. Does he really believe that Russia wants more uranium and that her way of getting it is by taking it from one of the countries that wants to undertake the enrichment process? Does he know the sources of uranium ore that are available to Russia? Does he know that Russia does not need to steal it from others? Does he know the volume of plutonium that Russia holds?
—I am implicitly trusting of the Russians, yes, Senator!

—In response to the honourable senator's interjection I simply say that Russia has an abundance of its own uranium ore and an overabundance of plutonium, and it is not within reasonable thought to believe that Russia would want to sneak some extra uranium for its own purposes. It is not a question of trusting Russia; it is simply a fact that it would gain Russia nothing to do so. In any case the journey along the way is audited at every point. The International Atomic Energy Agency does the auditing along the way and the Australian Safeguards Office audits all the way also. If in fact there is a need to strengthen the auditing procedures, there is an argument for so doing. The fact is that we are now debating a reality in this world. Yellowcake is moved around this world as the preliminary fissile material for nuclear power stations. A process is necessary for its enrichment so that it can be more effectively used in power stations. That process in itself does not make bombs; it does not contribute to the bomb stock of this world. The enriched uranium is not an explosive material in itself. Contrary to what has been said, enrichment is a normal process in the journey of the nuclear cycle.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course there are elements of danger in the handling of radioactive materials , just as there are elements of danger in the handling of coal or any toxic material. We do not ban coal or natural gas because they are potentially lethal; we lay down rigid standards for the use of these things. This world of ours has to make sure that more and more of these safeguards are applied to uranium over its journey so that we get as near a perfect control as we can. It is easy to talk of mutations. Everybody loathes the thought that we might get genetic mutations. Everybody loathes the thought that there might be a use of bombs. The reality is that there is a capacity in the world to make atomic bombs. Great powers have not only the knowledge but also the capacity to make them and however saddening it is nothing will destroy that knowledge, however much we might work for the reduction in the arms race or the reduction of stocks. The knowledge of how to make an atomic bomb can be taught theoretically in a lecture hall or a laboratory. It cannot be driven out of men's minds. It is there and it will be worked on. Sadly it will be improved upon. The world must learn how to use the good things and how to prevent the bad things.

It is not good enough simply to knock the use of atomic power. In the first place one has to put it into the real context, that it is vital to the survival and living standards of mankind across the world. It is no good saying: 'We will do it better; we will use solar energy'. Is there any scientific evidence in the world to justify that statement? The best that can be said is that solar energy might, in 20 years time, provide about 8 per cent of our needs. Those are the scientists' figures and I will obtain details for honourable senators if they so desire. The figure of 8 per cent at the most is being reduced now.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a passive solar house has only 30 per cent of the power consumption of one that is not designed that way. A passive solar house is a solar device.

—If every house in the world had a solar array on its roof, on present knowledge scientists estimate that would provide 8 per cent of the required energy. I repeat, without in any sense denigrating solar energy, that the defect is that we are talking about only the energy that it saves in its journey and not the energy used in its creation. The sad fact is-we need research in this area at the moment-that the creation of solar collectors is an energy hungry process. It takes an enormous amount of energy to make the product that then sets out to save energy.
—Why? I cannot see that it takes that at all.
—Perhaps the honourable senator needs a lecture in the production of metals, the making and extrusion of copper tubing and the fabrication of solar collectors. In any case, the evidence is there-
—You are making a good speech. Don't spoil it by being sarcastic.

—I do not want to be sarcastic; I want to be helpful in what I am saying. Let nobody believe that I am being critical of solar energy. The world ought to carry out maximum research in trying to get renewable energy. It should look to see whether it can make ethanol from crops, from biomass and so on. But, as I said to Senator Mason, we have to be careful that there is no conflict between food and fuel and that we are not using land for fuel which we should be using for food. We have to be careful that in the growing of those crops we do not use significant energy so that the net advantage is small. With the distillation process of ethanol, the use of fertiliser to grow the crops, the running of the farm and the processing in the factory we may not gain much in the end. These are frontiers that we have to break through. We could take natural gas, turn it into methanol or gasolene and lose energy all the way. We ought to work on it so that we will get there in the end. But it is not a solution at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The solutions at the moment lie firstly with energy conservation. I have said in the Senate on many occasions that an affluent society like ours is capable of making an energy saving of between 20 per cent and 30 per cent. I would applaud such conservation, for its importance not only for the present energy crisis but also for the limited ecosystem in which we live. We should all be using everything sparingly. We have to face the fact that oil will run out. We will then have a choice between coal, gas and nuclear energy. Those who best understand these things believe that however much coal we use it will not be enough. If we use it in large volumes it will cause a massive health problem. That must be faced up to. We should see that the nuclear energy process is made as safe as man can make it. We should give it maximum protection. We are not protecting uranium against the present weapons system nations. They are awash with plutonium. They do not need it. Safeguards against the stealing of plutonium or enriched uranium are needed against terrorists, nations or societies that want to make a bomb on the side.

This report basically looks into whether it is feasible to enrich uranium in Australia. We export the yellowcake. Why not take the next step, which is to enrich it to a safe level, well below the weapons state? The British enrichment system has two quite separate factories, one to enrich uranium at a low level for peacetime power stations and the other to enrich it for the weapons system. Senator Mason asked whether we will provide enriched uranium for United States weapons. Does he really believe that the United States is short of fissile material to make weapons?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't we export 4,000 tonnes of uranium per year to the United States?

—I do not know the amount we are exporting. We export uranium for peacetime nuclear purposes. If the honourable senator is about to ask: 'What about the reprocessing?' I will come to that in a moment. America has an abundance of fissile material and plutonium to make its weapons. Australia will sell its uranium only if the whole cycle of reprocessing, including the reprocessing of the waste, is for peacetime purposes. We will confront a situation to the contrary if it should emerge. As I understand it, Mr Reagan said that he proposed that the reprocessing should be carried out on a commercial basis and that it should not be done by governments. We will ensure, wherever we provide uranium, that when it is reprocessed an equivalent volume comes out so that none is lost to weapons making. I make that point abundantly clear to honourable senators. There is no way in which we will willingly allow a system in which an audit would reveal that a gap existed. The world will build more and more power reactors because it says it must. It is using and enriching uranium for those purposes. The International Atomic Energy Agency is monitoring the situation. In Australia the situation is monitored by the Australian Safeguards Office.

SPEECH.PARA: We in Australia say: 'We will ship uranium from our shores only to those countries which conform with our safeguards and we will monitor that volume of uranium through the whole of its journey to its final waste product. In no way will we tolerate any of our uranium being used to make weapons. We will ensure that it is used entirely for electric power generation'. We believe that we have a duty to the world to contribute to solving the world's electric power shortages. That is the basis on which UEGA was set up and on which it has made its pre-feasibility report. So far it has said: 'We have looked at the world around us and the nature of an enrichment industry. We have said that by 1990 the world will have a market for enriched uranium, assuming that Australia makes it. We believe that Australia has the ability to have such an industry. It is an industry that creates jobs and encourages skills.' It is now busy looking towards a kind of technology that can best be used as a choice between a centrifuge, gaseous diffusion or chemical exchange and the possible markets. That is an important study.

As yet Australia has not made any decision as to whether it will have an enrichment industry. But if it should so decide it will not increase in any way at all the dangers to Australia or the world. If we enrich yellowcake and export it, that will not in any way change the shape of the world's general problem in the control of fissile material. That is all we are doing at this moment. Australia has not made any decisions to establish nuclear reactors. That may well be down the track. In any debate that we have on this whole question I would never deny risks of radioactivity. I am acutely sensitive to it in many ways and for many reasons. It is the responsibility of every Australian, certainly of every responsible Minister, to ensure that compulsory radioactivity , that is that forced upon people, is kept to an absolute minimum. I think that is our job. I do not agree-

TALK.START.PARA: —Also in countries to whom we sell our uranium, like the Philippines. Do we have a responsibility to them?

—We have a responsibility wherever we go to make sure that we do not contribute to the health risk of people in the world. I think Senator Mason said that there was no minimum dose of radiation that was recognised as not being bad. Whilst that extrapolation is argued-I could not deny it in its looser sense-we get down to the kind of minimum that we are talking about, electively and compulsorily we are absorbing it in huge amounts every day of our lives. Who would wear an illuminated wristlet watch and have the habit of fishing for a handkerchief without being warned?
—Ha, ha!
—The honourable senator may laugh if he wishes but if we are really going to understand these situations that is an elective risk of added radiation, as is an X-ray or a flight.

—At this stage we are discussing risks. What about that point of nuclear exclusions and the risk to society in the event of an accident? I did make that point and I asked you if we could have a comment.
—Nuclear?

—The fact that Australia's insurance companies have a nuclear exclusion clause in their policies. In fact Australians even with paid up policies do not have any compensation if there is a nuclear accident.
—They have many exclusions in their policies.
—But that is a major exclusion.

—This is only one of them. The fact of the matter is this: The risks in nuclear power plants are demonstrably lower in every way than virtually in any other manufacturing industry, certainly in any power generating industry. I can only hope that situation continues. Let me get that straight. I am not saying that Three Mile Island should not be studied and every precaution taken to see that a leakage does not occur again.
—But would the Government compensate people in Australia if that sort of accident happened?
—How do you compensate people in Australia if other large accidents happen?
—You can insure against it. You cannot insure against a nuclear one.
—Are you saying that because a judgment is made by insurance companies in this situation we should not provide uranium to the world ? Is that what the honourable senator is saying?
—What I am really asking is this: 'Would you say that the Government would consider covering that liability?'

—The honourable senator may put that question on the Notice Paper and we will put this matter under study, but it is irrelevant. The fact is that at this moment we are providing uranium to the world. The world is taking that uranium and enriching it. The process of taking yellowcake and making it into enriched uranium does not add one extra bit of radioactivity to the world or one extra bit of hazard to the world that was not there when yellowcake was being moved. There is a lot of misunderstanding-some of it deliberate-about the nature of yellowcake, the nature of conversion and the nature of enrichment. On that journey we have not added to the risks. Of course we do not want incidents such as occurred at Three Mile Island but, taking that into account, the fact of the matter is that over the past 20 years the health record of nuclear power stations in this world has been immeasurably better than the health record of power stations generated by other fuels such as fossil fuels, coal and oil. I do not want to say there are no risks, but I do ask honourable senators that when they debate these matters they do not do it in black and white or misunderstand the alternative risks, which are enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it perfectly clear that as far as this Government is concerned we will emphasise at every level that wherever the hazard may be, whether from coal or uranium, our job is to see that the health of the Australian society and the world outside is protected. Whilst this report has given us a chance to talk in the wider sense-I think that is good-it is simply a question of whether we change yellowcake into enriched uranium through the conversion process. That in itself has not altered any of the risks that lie around. It has not created an additional industry that will create more radioactivity. It has not added to the ability of the world to make bombs or weapons. It is utterly wrong to distort that. Of course, in that journey and at every step we should make sure that we strengthen nuclear safeguards, be it on the international level or the Australian level. I would always invite discussion and debate in this chamber and elsewhere on those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) for his contribution to this debate. I am amazed at the amount of knowledge he stores away and is able to produce. I say that very sincerely. I have sat here fascinated with the information he has given. I enter the debate hoping that I am not encroaching on precious time. If I am and if someone has a message to give to the nation before six o'clock I will shorten my remarks. I am impelled to stand because of a question that the honourable senator did not answer in response to an interjection that you, Mr Deputy President, so graciously allowed , namely that the uranium that Australia is selling to the United States now has been reported as being used in the nuclear weapons program of the United States. I say that it has been reported.
—I will get information for the honourable senator on that.

—Thank you. I know one cannot take as gospel truth the words of all writers but there is a very reputable fellow called Robert Milliken who writes for the National Times. I direct the Minister's attention to an article that he wrote in the National Times of 10-16 January of this year. In that article he says:

SPEECH.PARA: A move by the Reagan Administration to make nuclear weapons with plutonium from civilian power plants threatens to seriously embarrass the Fraser Government over its uranium export policy.
That is a bit of politics, but let us go to the gist of the thing that worries me. The article says:

The idea that plutonium from commercial nuclear reactors should be used in nuclear warheads comes from the US Energy Secretary, James Edwards. In a speech late last year to a research board of the Department of Energy in Washington he proposed that spent fuel from nuclear reactors be reprocessed and the plutonium extracted and used for both nuclear weapons and the proposed new fast-breeder reactors.

The Edwards proposal came soon after disclosures that research on the use of lasers to enrich uranium was also being directed towards extracting bomb-quality plutonium from waste in commercial reactors.
There it is again.

TALK.START.PARA: —This article is talking about an alleged proposal; it is not what is happening. I think that ought to be made clear.
—Agreed. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The revelations have sparked a furore in the US. One Democratic senator, Gary Hart, who is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, wrote to Edwards warning: 'The very consideration of such a plan undermines the historic basic assumptions of the Atoms for Peace program: that a clear distinction exists between the military and commercial applications of nuclear technology.'
I find it a little disturbing, notwithstanding the Minister's amazing knowledge that he has disclosed off-the-cuff today, that the Minister was not aware of these allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the allegations.
—You are?
—Yes. But they are suggestions that something might happen rather than facts of something that is happening. Those things are not happening at the moment.

—To save the time of this chamber, I could incorporate this article, but that will clog up Hansard. If I send a copy of the article to the Minister will he be gracious enough to have his Department prepare a paper and send it to me and perhaps to all senators?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am sorry, Mr Deputy President, if this debate has failed to go always through the Chair but it is because of the nature of the debate that this has been so. I congratulate honourable senators on the serious approach they have taken to it. I believe that it is important that what Senator Chipp requests is done. If he gives me a copy of the article I will have a paper prepared and with his acquiescence I will incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The work of the Special Broadcasting Service was a matter of some discussion in the Estimates committee last year. The Estimates committee in question was concerned that the report of this body had been considerably delayed. If I am correct, I think that the matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I think the first matter to draw attention to is the Auditor-General's report which appears on page 44 of the report of the Special Broadcasting Service. It notes a number of unapproved expenditures which were entered into by the Special Broadcasting Service in the course of the year ending 30 June 1981. I hope that those conspicuous expenditure tendencies of the Special Broadcasting Service will be curbed somewhat in the coming year as a result of the comments by the Auditor-General.

The report is a splendid looking document. In reading it, one would think that all was totally satisfactory in the world of ethnic and multicultural broadcasting in Australia. Anybody who knows anything about ethnic and multicultural broadcasting in Australia knows that that is not correct. For example, the report at page 11 states:

SBS firmly believes that in its first eight months of operation it has, through its programming on Channel 0-28, succeeded in substantially achieving the aims and objectives of the multicultural television service . . .

If the SBS seriously thinks that it can make a statement like that in its report without any qualification, it is rather a glib view of the situation because most people think that Channel 0-28 has a long way to go. It is, of course, a very low-rating television channel in Melbourne and Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good channel.

—Just let me finish the sentence. It is, of course, a very low- rating channel in Melbourne and Sydney. The reasons for that, I think, in fairness to the SBS, should be stated. There are a lot of technical difficulties particularly in Sydney in the transmission of SBS programs and getting a clear image on the television screen. Not as many people as ought to are receiving adequate reception from Channel 0-28, mainly in Sydney. Senator Sir John Carrick interjected a minute ago and said that Channel 0-28 is a good channel. I think there is a lot to be said for that view. Channel 0-28, for example, provides a news service which absolutely shames both the Australian Broadcasting Commission and commercial television in this country in the quality of the coverage and service which it provides. That in itself reflects a worthwhile and totally praiseworthy initiative and skill on the part of the SBS.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain difficulties arise. First of all there are technical difficulties of reception, which I have referred to, which greatly militate against the wider dissemination of Channel 0-28 programs. Secondly, while the programs are very good for a sophisticated audience, what one is, in fact, getting in Channel 0-28 is a sort of Continental cinema in one's own sitting room. That is to say one gets, on the whole, fairly high quality European or Continental films which used to be shown in picture houses such as the Savoy cinema in Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —That dates you, Senator.
—Yes, it does, but it is the best example that comes to mind.
—That is back in your duffle coat days.

—Let us say the Longford cinema in Melbourne. Having disposed as best I can of those interjections which really just reveal my long-standing interest in this problem, the point I am making is that Channel 0-28 probably appeals most to an Australian white Anglo-Saxon middle class audience. That group probably constitutes its largest viewing audience. Channel 0-28 is big in suburbs such as Eltham and Doncaster and on the north shore of Sydney.
—What about Warrnambool?
—Its programming is far too sophisticated for the people of Warrnambool as it is represented in this Parliament.
—I will tell the people of Warrnambool about that.

—As represented in this Parliament by those who interject when I am speaking on this subject. Of course it would be unfair to gauge the sophistication of the people of Warrnambool by the representation which they have from Senator Lewis, but I am not doing that. I am making the point that if the target and ambition of Channel 0-28 is to be a truly multicutural channel and, in a sense, an ethnic channel, which is a slightly different thing, it is probably not achieving that purpose. I am not condemning it for that. I am saying that this must be a matter of concern because I suspect that the basic audience of Channel 0-28 is the more highly educated section of the more traditional Australian population.

SPEECH.PARA: The other comment I should make is that one hopes that the very good qualities of Channel 0-28 will impinge and influence standards across the broadcasting spectrum generally. Multiculturalism should pervade all sections of the broadcasting media and it should not be segregated in one channel or one radio station. I think it is important that the value of Channel 0-28 is seen across a much wider spectrum. The comment I make really relates to the failure of the Special Broadcasting Service report to raise and discuss these issues other than to say that it is a pretty good service and that it has succeeded in achieving the aims and objectives of a multicultural television service. It seems to me to be a complacent statement which is not justified by a critical examination of what in fact is happening.

I point out also that Channel 0-28 is a very expensive service in broadcasting terms. One hopes that in the future in some rationalisation of government finance in regard to broadcasting more adequate arrangements can be made to accommodate Channel 0-28 in a new service of a somewhat wider kind. This is a view which we in the Australian Labor Party hold and, of course, which half the Federal Council of the Liberal Party, minus one, hold following debate on this matter at their council meeting in, I think, October last year. I was very disappointed to see that what I regard as a more sophisticated view was in a minority, but that may well change. I am not making any criticism in saying that .

I think the SBS report is also somewhat complacent about the ethnic radio side of its activities. I and other members of the Labor Party have always taken the view that ethnic radio broadcasting should be accommodated in this country in the public broadcasting sector. That is to say that it should not be segregated into the area where it now is-radio station 2EA in Sydney and 3EA in Melbourne, basically, plus a complementary scheme which provides subsidies for public broadcasting stations which provide ethnic programming. We see no reason why the broadcasting aspirations of ethnic communities should not be treated in exactly the same way as are other communities of interest which are accommodated in the public radio broadcasting sector. The cost of the two SBS stations, station 2EA in Sydney and station 3EA in Melbourne, is in the order of $4m a year. The SBS provides to public broadcasting stations which broadcast ethnic programs subsidies in the order of $400,000. If we examine the relative broadcast times in the public broadcasting sector-that is, on community radio stations-and the broadcast times of stations 2EA and 3EA we will find that the delivery of ethnic radio services through the public broadcasting sector is much more cost effective than maintaining the two stations 2EA and 3EA in those two cities of Sydney and Melbourne. I think they are matters which should be discussed in relation to any report of the SBS.

There are also a lot of rumblings of discontent in the ethnic radio stations 2EA and 3EA, largely turning on the question of the level of professionalism and the appropriate payment for professionals in those two stations. What we believe should be developed as a matter of policy is the notion of ethnic communities controlling their own ethnic broadcasting. In that sense we believe, as I said, that public broadcasting provides a much better model for future development than does the segregated 2EA and 3EA type of station. I have already commented on the cost effectiveness of that.

The sad thing is that nothing in the report on these matters lies at the eye of the storm of any proper debate about the future development of ethnic broadcasting in Australia. From recollection, I believe the Government has taken some steps-I think this is very important-towards bringing Channel 0-28 to Canberra and perhaps, in a very tentative way, to Wollongong. The sad thing about the development of ethnic broadcasting in Australia is that the emphasis, both for demographic and political reasons, has been very much on Sydney and Melbourne. There are significant ethnic communities in Canberra and Wollongong, as indeed there are in other cities of Australia, which should have the benefit of those services. Of course in Canberra there is a middle class, middle brow community which is not an ethnic community and which would be very interested in the other qualities of Channel 0-28. I regret, as I said, that there is nothing in the report on these matters which are the real issues relating to ethnic broadcasting and the role of the SBS. I repeat what I said in relation to the report of the Department of Communications earlier today: The fault lies with the Government in not having clear policy guidelines and not perhaps with the SBS. I think we as members of the Senate can all welcome the arrival of the SBS. That does not debar us from being critical about some of the issues which concern it and which concern the community which it purports to serve. It is in that spirit that I offer these comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to say very little about this report. The Government's decision on the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission chaired by Mr Dix will, I hope, come fairly soon. The report of the Dix committee has now been around for many months. For that reason it is perhaps not appropriate to go into a full analysis of the performance of the Australian Broadcasting Commission at this time. However, the Dix committee report was important in that it was, in my view, a very sound diagnostic approach to the problems and difficulties of the ABC. The recommendations arising from that diagnosis will be the subject of a great deal of discussion in the immediate future.

The Dix report identified many shortcomings in the Australian Broadcasting Commission and, I think, made an important contribution in pointing out that even if, as the Australian Broadcasting Commission claims, it has been starved of funds by the Government and has experienced a decline of 22 per cent in funding in the last five years, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has problems which are different and which are not attributable to the decline in funds from government sources. One would hope that in dealing with the recommendations of the Dix report the Government will deal particularly with the deficiencies in management. That should be the main area to be confronted by the Government when it takes decisions about the ABC and its future directions.

I believe generally that it can be said that the Commission has not been able to determine just what role it should play in a television and radio industry dominated in number, and presently in audience appeal, by commercial operators. We hope that the outcome of the Dix inquiry will be that the ABC will be put on a firmer footing and that its management and staff in the future will have clearer ideas about its direction and goals as a national broadcasting service. We hope that that direction, those ideals and those goals will be in the spirit of a great public broadcasting service as the British Broadcasting Corporation has been and remains and the ABC used to be but no longer remains. These goals, I hope, will include four areas that the Dix committee of inquiry drew attention to. There is, first of all, the suggestion that the ABC has a cultural bias in that it is too British looking; secondly, that it provides inadequate services to non-metropolitan areas; thirdly, that it fails to reflect the needs of important groups in Australian society such as Aborigines, non-Anglo-Saxons and women; and fourthly, that it has failed to decentralise its resources effectively in the States and regions to reflect the interests of the whole country. Four important points arise from the Dix committee of inquiry. In dealing with the recommendations of that inquiry we hope that the Government will face up to those four issues. I commend a study of the report of the Commission to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the House of Representatives without amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was speaking on the report dealing with the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and the comments that had been made as a result of the United Nations Mission visit to that group of islands which comes under the jurisdiction of Australia at this stage. The mission has made a number of points about the need to assist in the cultural, political and social development of the people who make up the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and the need for them to have a diversified economy, particularly to involve them perhaps more than has been the case in the past in the establishment of a quarantine station as a result of our legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The mission refers substantially to the judgment that the people of that group of islands have to make shortly in respect to their future. They have three options available to them. Firstly, they could be integrated with Australia. Secondly, they could have a free association; that is, they would determine their own affairs with some assistance from Australia in respect of foreign policy, defence and so on. Thirdly, they can opt for the ultimate which is so much a part of the changes in the post-war years of independence, and establish themselves in their own right. The suggestion has been made that this may be a judgment which the people will have to make some time during 1982. Having read the report that we are discussing, the comments of the United Nations Mission and the comments of the Australian Government representatives on that mission's report, I wonder whether the people there are yet able, on the basis of their evolution, their thought processes and their participation in day to day affairs , to make a proper judgment in respect of their future. I am encouraged in that belief by an article written by Cyril Ayris which was published in a number of newspapers. I am referring particularly to an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald which states:
There is certainly some anger by the council towards the Australian Government because of its failure to remove from Home Island their former ruler Mr John Clunies-Ross.
Whichever of the three choices the Malays take the future of Mr Clunies-Ross appears to be in jeopardy.
The Malays have the bargaining power to force his removal and unless there is a change of council, they will undoubtedly use it.
One does not have to stay long on the islands to realise that the happy-go- lucky Malays are sitting ducks for exploitation.
They have only just started earning Australian dollars for their labour and they have come close to worshipping its buying power.
Yet they receive less than $30 in hand for their week's work. The rest goes into the co-operative society to pay their rates and power.
It is a true socialist system.

That is what the correspondent, who wrote that article for the Fairfax organisation in Australia, had to say. Whilst I applaud that that is the summation of his concept of the way in which the islanders are conducting their affairs, it is clear that they need a great deal more assistance and perhaps time to make that value judgment on whether they should be involved in the process of independence, integration or partial integration with Australia. One has to have some regard to the proximity of these islands to one of our powerful neighbours-Indonesia. For those who express the view that Timor should have been part of Indonesia, if that were a logical argument, certainly these islands should be integrated with Indonesia. But of course that may be a convenient way out at this point in history. It might not necessarily be a satisfactory arrangement. So some strategic influences are involved in the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands area.
