PROCTEXT.PARA: That consideration of General Business, Notice of Motion No. 54, relating to the Australian Constitutional Convention, be postponed until after consideration of General Business, Notice of Motion No. 1, relating to natural disasters insurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes with concern the inadequacy of existing insurance and/or compensation arrangements in the event of a natural disaster and is of the opinion that a joint parliamentary committee should be established to re-examine the whole question of natural disaster compensation funding and that the terms of reference of the Committee should be-

(a) to make recommendations on the establishment of a natural disaster fund, the methods of financing such a fund, the guaranteeing of appropriate grants in the event of a natural disaster, and other related matters;
(b) to specify what constitutes a natural disaster, so that the history of doubt and uncertainty surrounding the admissibility of insurance claims in the event of disaster can be eliminated;
(c) to define the benefits that should be payable to victims of the various categories of natural disaster; and
(d) to recommend the composition and nature of an appropriate administrative authority to operate a natural disaster scheme, and all related matters.
I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This question has now been before the Parliament in some shape or form for several years, yet the Government has done nothing about it. In particular, in May 1976 the following motion was passed in the House of Representatives:
That in the opinion of this House, the Government should implement as soon as practicable, a natural disaster insurance scheme.
This was followed in December 1976 by the tabling of a discussion paper on 'A Natural Disaster Insurance Scheme for Australia'.

I do not need to remind honourable senators that Australia is subject to a very wide range of natural disasters including bushfires, floods, cyclones, droughts, storms and even some earthquakes. Many of these stand out in memory, such as the Tasmanian bushfires of February 1967 which cost insurance companies $14m and drew Commonwealth grants and loans of $10m; the 1968 earthquake in Meckering, West Australia which cost insurance companies $2m and drew Commonwealth grants and loans of $250,000; cyclone Althea in Queensland, 1971 which cost insurance companies $22m and drew Commonwealth grants and loans of $2.6m; cyclone Wanda in Brisbane 1974 which cost insurance companies $88m and drew Commonwealth grants and loans of $54m; and, of course, cyclone Tracy which hit Darwin in December 1974 and cost insurance companies $220m and drew Commonwealth grants and loans of $224m.

It is time that the present ad hoc system of compensation was replaced by some form of planned national scheme. As long ago as 1974, the Insurance Council of Australia pointed out that, 'the potential for natural disaster damage in Australia is enormous'; and that, 'if a major earthquake were to occur in a major capital city the damage could run into several hundred millions of dollars '. That was in 1974. The figure would now obviously be in the billions of dollars.
I quote further from the Insurance Council's 1974 report:

'Evidence suggests that the potential risks of earthquake in Australia are significant . . . and increased awareness by some insurance companies of these risks is leading them to reassess their ability to provide cover against this hazard without unduly risking their solvency . . . the possibility exists that one single event could bring about a catastrophic loss'.

It is true that no one has yet been killed by an earthquake in Australia and that property damage caused by earthquakes since 1950 has only been about $10m. But Brisbane, Sydney, Canberra, Adelaide, Melbourne and Perth are all subject to a degree of earthquake activity, and now is the time when we should be making plans for the future handling of compensation requirements.

Private sector insurance companies find it very difficult, if not impossible, to provide adequate insurance cover against natural disasters, for a variety of reasons. The infrequency of these disasters lulls most people into a false sense of security. Figures show, for example, that prior to the 1974 Brisbane floods, only 10 per cent of domestic policy holders had arranged any form of flood insurance, even though they knew that large areas of Brisbane were flood prone. In these circumstances, the Commonwealth is virtually forced into providing support.

In the case of some types of natural disaster, potential losses are so large that they would eliminate or exceed a private insurance company's reserves. Cyclones often fall into this category. In 1974, for example, the combined impact of cyclone Tracy and several floods in eastern Australia placed the insurance industry in a situation where they were looking at losses from those two occurrences totalling some $400m against an annual premium income of only $ 340m. Fortunately, most of the $400m was met by reinsurers from the world market ; but reinsurance is now becoming increasingly expensive and Australian companies would be much harder hit in the event of another cyclone Tracy. This is yet another reason for Australia to adopt a comprehensive natural disaster compensation scheme.

The joint parliamentary committee which we propose should be set up will have many important questions to answer. One of these obviously relates to the question of compulsory insurance levies. Should the public be obliged to contribute a certain proportion of their incomes to a natural disaster compensation fund? Should some form of reserve system apply? What role should private insurers play? What exactly is meant by the term, 'natural disasters'? What kind of authority is most suitable for administering the scheme? These are all questions which are best left to the expertise which would be available to a joint parliamentary committee.

In conclusion, I would urge honourable senators from both sides of the chamber to support this motion. This matter has been placed on the shelf or in the too- hard basket for far too long. It is a problem which will not go away and it is one which affects a potentially huge number of Australians. Do we need another cyclone Tracy to remind us of our responsibilities to fellow Australians who, through absolutely no fault of their own, find their homes irreparably damaged or even totally destroyed? A promising start was made in this area with the House of Representatives motion and the discussion paper of 1976 which I referred to earlier. Let us now set up a joint parliamentary committee which can finish the job.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate supports the holding of a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide this year.

I am indebted to the Senate for allowing me to bring this matter on for debate tonight. The reason for seeking to do that is, of course, obvious in that the Premiers Conference will be held tomorrow and this will be an item for consideration. One hopes that a resolution of the Senate, particularly if it can be a unanimous resolution or one without dissenting voice, will be taken seriously and influence the deliberations of the Premiers accordingly.

It ought to be possible for unanimous support to be achieved tonight on this motion. The motion does not in terms refer to any substantive issue. There is nothing remotely tendentious about its terms. It simply affirms that the process of constitutional review which has been so laboriously pursued now through the meetings of the existing Constitutional Convention on four occasions since 1973 should continue. It simply proposes-putting it another way-that the momentum which has visibly been gradually developing in the community in favour of rethinking the terms of our Constitution, especially in the light of the forthcoming bicentenary year in 1988, should get some further assistance. It is clear that there is a desire for constitutional change from a really quite extraordinarily diverse collection of viewpoints. The desire for constitutional change is by no means confined to the radicals or Left Liberals in this community and by no means confined to those who are obsessed, it might be said by others, with the events of 1975 and the desire to change or to amend the institutions and procedures which gave rise to that trauma.

There are in fact a really quite extraordinary number of different people from a number of different perspectives who are arguing in one way or another for constitutional change. There are those who, from a variety of perspectives, want a more rational distribution of power between the different levels of government -a distribution of power which reflects perhaps more adequately than was the case with the distribution worked out at the turn of the century the changing socio-economic character of the Australian environment, the fact that among other things we are now an integrated modern economy with all that that demands in terms of macro-economic management, business regulation and so on. There are those who are unhappy often from a quite different ideological perspective with the present system of Federal-State relations, especially Federal-State financial relations. There are those who perhaps may be seeking a more fundamental restructuring of the Federal system-to do away with the States altogether, to create a regional system or a unitary system or something of that kind. There are those, not all of them radicals by any means, who would like our Constitution to reflect more specifically Australia's independence from Britain. There are those who might not necessarily want any change at all in the actual institutional arrangements of the present Constitution, but who would want it to describe more clearly the institutions of government and the way they work in practice, who would want it to talk specifically in terms of the Cabinet, the Prime Minister and so on rather than employ the circuitous language of the Executive Council and rely on 'conventions', to fill out arrangements not described in the text of a constitutional document.

There are those who want more stability or certainty in the institutions of national government-the Senate, the Governor-General and the other institutions which have caused difficulty of one kind or another in recent years. There are those who want a more rational system so far as the administration of justice is concerned, who are upset at reading, as we all have in the last day or two, about custody cases being dragged on for 12 months or more through three separate courts, the High Court, the Supreme Court of New South Wales and the Family Court, because of doubts, uncertainties and problems in the division of power and in the administration of court responsibilities as between the Commonwealth and the States. There are those, from a variety of political perspectives, who want more protection for individuals against the misuse of government power than is contained in the present document. There are those again who want flexible machinery for constitutional change without perhaps being clear at all as to what change might be required here and now but who think that at least the kind of machinery for initiating and implementing proposals ought to be more flexible than the existing section 128 which has proved such a difficult barrier over the years to those who want to work fundamental change.

The things that all these different kinds of people, different kinds of interests, want to achieve can perhaps be summarised broadly in four categories. Those in the first category of issues, if we relate to the institutions of national government-the position of the Executive, the position of the legislature and the position of the judiciary, and the various interrelationships between them. I do not think I need do any more here than simply refer to the multiple questions that have been the currency of public debate, of community interest, particularly in the last six to 10 years, about the powers and position of the Senate, about the position of the Governor- General, about the nature of our institutional relationship with the United Kingdom and in particular the monarchy, about whether we should be a republic in the sense of severing our monarchical connection and about whether we should be a republic in the American sense of developing a presidential rather than a parliamentary system of government. There are varying degrees of difficulty in the issues which have been identified under those various heads. There are varying degrees of reality about them in terms of the likelihood of their acceptance by the Australian people. But there can be no doubting that they are issues, and issues which are of quite fundamental importance, many of them, although some of them are merely of symbolic importance, in the way in which we conduct our nation's affairs.

The second category of problems relates to the operation of our Federal system of government. At one level the problem might be perceived in terms of the structure of the Federal system itself-the existence of Federal, State and local governments involving 950-odd full-time parliamentarians and over 11,000 politicians altogether; if one includes local councillors; all serving a population of less than 15 million people. Is this, many people are asking, the best, most rational way of governing the affairs of an economically integrated modern society such as Australia? At less radical level, and a perhaps more realistic perspective, there are those who, on looking at the Federal structure, say that maybe it is unrealistic to think in terms of any of our present lifetimes about changing the elements of that structure but that certainly it may be possible to devise a more rational and workable division of legislative powers and financial responsibilities between those existing levels, especially in the areas of overall economic management, of business regulation, in relation to questions of national development and the administration of welfare and in relation to questions of human rights and law reform generally.

The third category of problem relates to the whole question of whether or not our Constitution should contain guarantees, which it does not at the moment of course, of individual rights and liberties. Our Consitution is very different in that respect from most other constitutions of other countries and there are many people in the community, from a variety of perspectives as I said before, who would support changes of that kind. And the last category of problem, I suppose, relates to the question of the machinery of constitutional change itself. Has the section 128 formula enabled the responsible reaction of our constitutional arrangements to the changes that have been all so visible in the course of this century? More than that, is the process that presently exists for the initiation , the generation of ideas and proposals for constitutional change, not just the final implementation but the initiation, to be approved?

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not even allowed appropriate questions to be put.

—That is a very fair point. Because of the way in which the Constitution is drafted at the moment, the question of what goes to the people is essentially in the hands of the government of the day in the Commonwealth Parliament only. That is obviously a very narrow potential funnel through which constitutional ideas abroad in the community can be channelled. So there is a very quick check list of the basic categories of people who want change, the basic issues which demand to be resolved in any systematic attempt at constitutional reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The question before us now is a rather less extensive one: How would the holding of another session of the existing parliamentarians Constitutional Convention in Adelaide later this year-I mention Adelaide because I understand that there is a standing offer on foot from the State Government in Adelaide to host the next session of the Convention there, whenever it may be-advance the cause of constitutional reform? I think there are two levels on which we need to approach this question. One is in terms of the actual substantive change which might be accomplished by another series of sessions of the existing Convention. A second perspective through which we ought to look at what might constructively emerge from such a session is in terms not so much of a substantive change but in terms of the procedural issues which might there be debated and what might be determined so far as the process of reform for the future is concerned. At the level of substantive change one could, of course, be forgiven for perhaps demonstrating a degree of cynicism about the extent to which achievements have been accomplished in the four sessions of the parliamentarians Constitutional Convention that have been held to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you say pessimism or cynicism?

—Well, cynicism, I suppose, to the extent that I for one, having attended all four sessions of the convention, wearing a variety of different hats since 1973, have been moved on various public occasions to refer to the grinding inconsequentiality of it all. That is the way it tends to seem when one is sitting there for five days at a time and nothing very much seems to be moving compared with what we all know to be the gigantic array of major issues which are in fact on most people's mental agenda of things requiring constitutional reform and attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is clear, when one exercises a bit of objectivity about it and looks back perhaps a little less cynically, if one can, at the record in the past, that a momentum of a kind has in fact developed. It is true that at the first session of the Convention in Sydney in 1973 the Convention was essentially devoted to rhetoric and to the assignment of matters to various committees for further detailed consideration. The substantive achievements from that point of view were negligible, although a lot of issues were raised. In Melbourne in 1975 , at the rump session of the convention, if it can be so described because for political reasons prevailing at the time it was not fully attended by one section of the delegations and as such the deliberations were not substantial, it was very difficult to see at that time that any achievement was made at all. But then again, when the Convention met in Hobart in its third session in October 1976, there was a rerun of the Melbourne Convention, this time with a full set of delegates, and in fact, what had transpired at Melbourne was very much taken on board by the full array of delegates and there were a number of achievements, including an agreement to recommend to the Government that four matters at least be put to referendum. They were, of course, the matters that went to the people in 1977, three of which related to the retiring age for judges, Territory voting rights and casual Senate vacancies, and all three of which were passed by the Australian people. That brought the total number of measures passed up from five to eight in one fell swoop, which is a significant arithmetical achievement, if not otherwise.

Another proposition agreed to in Hobart relating to simultaneous elections of the House of Representatives and the Senate was in fact approved of by 62 per cent of the Australian people even though it failed by reason of not satisfying other elements of the constitutional formula. Then in Perth in July 1978 further I think significant achievements were recorded. There was on the agenda in Perth a mixture of both highly technical and highly contentious items which at the time were not such as to make one believe that anything very much was happening. But there were a series of matters relating to the appointment of High Court judges, the appellate jurisdiction of the High Court, advisory opinions of the High Court and the closer integration of Federal and State courts which, although it is boringly technical to recite them in that way, were of quite fundamental significance for the more rational distribution of institutional power in this country in the future. Although there was a massive fight over the question of Senate powers at that stage which was only very narrowly resolved in favour of one formula rather than another, at least the air was cleared, I suppose it might be said, and the ground rules for the warfare were established. As a result, a lot of people were minded to think more seriously about what the final institutional solutions had to be.

Looking at it from a substantive point of view, the agenda for this year, I believe, could contain many items of really quite substantial significance on which it might well be possible to make a significant advance-to make substantial strides. Apart from the vexed question of the relationship betwen the two Houses, on which I personaly hope that there may be some movement in the context of the fixed term parliament proposal in the next few weeks, there are several other categories of matters which have been the subject of very extensive discussion in one of the standing committees of the existing Convention and on which it is very evident from my perspective as a member of one of those committees that a process of consensus is gradually coming about. I am referring to the possible insertion in the Constitution or in an associated declaratory document of a statement of conventions that govern the role of the Governor-General and a whole series of other areas that determine how the Constitution works. It is evidence that there are a number of issues relating to the constitutional role of Parliament-the length of parliamentary terms, questions relating to classification qualification of members and questions of Territory representation-which could I think be resolved were they to be put on the agenda. There are matters relating to the court system-advisory opinions, the jurisdictional questions that we have been talking about in recent weeks in the context particularly of family law-which are looking far more capable of solution than anyone could have believed only a year or two ago. There are some basic questions of the distribution of constitutional power in the area of family law, of industrial law and in terms of the operation of section 92 which are also very viable items for rational discussion at a Convention this year because there is already a foundation of quite extensive discussion and consultation on which to build.

Quite apart from substantive issues of that type which I think in themselves would justify the holding of another session of the existing Convention, I think by far the most important item on the agenda for any session of the Constitutional Convention that might be held this year, if it can be brought together, is a re-evaluation of the process of initiating proposals for constitutional change. The present model, as we all know, is a representative assembly comprising delegations from Commonwealth and State parliaments and from local government. It is a model which has not worked especially well, it must be acknowledged, in terms of capturing the imagination of the community. It is not a model that has worked especially well in terms of divorcing the attention of the delegates at the conference from considerations of day to day partisan warfare and elevating their minds to higher things. The question arises whether the existing mechanism is the best way of dealing with a fundamental rethinking of where we are in terms of our Constitution and what could be done to improve it.

Is it possible, I think this session of the Convention should be explicitly asking itself, to devise machinery which will deal in the future more systematically and less superficially with the array of problems I have mentioned, which will perhaps involve a much wider group of people in the community at large in the process of discussion and implementation of recommendations, which will create more awareness in the community of the desirability of certain kinds of constitutional changes and which will create as a result more confidence in the breasts of the decision-makers that propositions that are put to the community will in fact be passed ultimately at referendum because people will have had the opportunity to familiarise themselves with what is involved? It is worth asking, and I hope this Convention would ask, whether it is possible in some way to devise a machinery for the future which could catch the wave, which could develop further the kind of momentum which I believe is gradually developing in the community around the idea of a major renewal of our Constitution by the 1988 Bicentenary year. One such mechanism that one hopes would be discussed by such a Convention is the idea of a 'Popular Convention', a directly elected assembly with the Australian people having not just a representative voice through their existing parliamentarians but a direct voice through some electoral process in establishing the composition of the body. That is not nearly as trendy an idea as it sounds, to the extent that in 1897-98 that was the model which was adopted, which lifted the whole federal movement out of the apathy into which it had rather sunk in the middle 1890s and which created the degree of popular involvement that was crucially important in bringing about the Australian federation by the turn of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not get any support from the loquacious lawyers in the land.

—The loquacious lawyers in the land are an obvious category of persons who would stand for election. Whether they would be elected would be something on which Senator Haines and I may bet rather differently. It could be expected that the respective parties would run their own tickets just as the Age and Argus newspapers ran their own tickets for rival factions in the 1890s. Of course, that would be so. But at least it would open up the process. I do not go into that now. There will be ample opportunity in future to talk about potential models. It is possible that that is too grandiose, too expensive, an idea to be capable of realistic application. It is equally possible though, even if one adopts that point of view, that there are compromise positions that can be thought about seriously and debated seriously at some session of the Constitutional Convention-for example, some model whereby the exisiting composition of the Convention was retained but added to it was some smaller electoral component or even some appointed component, with the respective parliaments nominating their own additional delegates from outside the category of parliamentarian. There are all sorts of possibilities. I simply raise the larger issue that it is important, I think, if we are really serious about addressing the whole series of problems to which I have briefly referred, that we consider ways in which the structure of the constitutional reform process can reflect the variety of interests that are involved and the diversity of people and interests that need to be accommodated if something is really to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important that a structure be evolved which is capable of actually doing some hard work. It is not really apparent that a session of the Convention occupying four or five days every two or three years is really going to be able to do much more than inch forward the process of constitutional reform. If we are serious about any fundamental or systematic rethink, obviously we have to be thinking in terms of some Convention model which involves delegates meeting together for weeks, perhaps even a couple of months, at a time over a period of three or four years to do the really hard work. I simply raise these as the questions which seem to me to be the most fundamental and the most important- more important than any of the immediate substantive issues which might otherwise be on the agenda. I believe it is possible then for a Convention held this year, structured on its present lines without any radical change in its composition before then, to take all these matters forward. I believe it is possible with a degree of good will and cross-party support, particularly if it is demonstrated in this chamber tonight.

There is a momentum abroad in the community. We would not be going out on a limb in expressing this view tonight. We would simply be reflecting a view which I think is very visible. One demonstration and indication of its visibility is the New South Wales Law Foundation project which I described in this chamber on 24 September in the context of replying to a constitutional statement which Senator Durack had then put down. The consultative committee for that project met in Sydney last week-on Friday, 12 February. It really was an extraordinary occasion. Gathered around the table were a number of very distinguished Australians from most political parties-certainly from both sides of politics- from every State in Australia. I will mention alphabetically those who were there. They were: Franca Arena from New South Wales; Bob Hawke; Donald Horne; Justice Michael Kirby; John Maddison, former Liberal Attorney-General of New South Wales; Senators Kathy Martin, Alan Missen and Peter Rae; Sir John Moore, President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; Paul Munro, a very prominent white collar trade union leader; Jack Richardson, the Commonwealth Ombudsman; Dr Ella Stack, the former Mayor of Darwin; John Valder from the Institute of Public Affairs and the Sydney Stock Exchange; Sir Clarrie Harders, former Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department; and Ronald Sackville, Chairman of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission.

From all parties and none, from all parts of Australia, these people came together, sat down around a table for four hours and in a very constructive set of discussions committed themselves to support for this process of constitutional reform. They did not agree upon any particular substantive change ; agreement about that is obviously a long way off, but agreement about the process of change and about the desirability of re-thinking where we are at is very close to us. Of course, there were many other people on that consultative committee who could not attend that particular meeting but who have also associated themselves with that project. They include Robert Holmes a Court, Don Chipp of the Australian Democrats; John Hyde of the Liberal Party; Sir Laurence Muir; Professor Geoffrey Sawer; Frank Walker; Graeme Miles from the Local Government Association; and Haddon Storey, the Victorian Liberal Attorney- General who has been very active on the supervisory committee for the project. I mention these names because it is a demonstration that it is possible to bring people together to talk rationally, systematically, coherently-and idealistically-about the options for change in this really very lethargic community of ours. So long as this is happening, so long as there is a willingness to talk across party lines and across geographical boundaries, so long as there is this willingness to try to build together a concensus for change, I believe that major constitutional reform this decade-by 1988-is not a pipedream.

The Attorney-General wrote a very lucid and interesting article in 1967 before he came into this Parliament about the necessity for constitutional change and the desirability of there being a constitutional convention. The reference is Durack and Wilson 1967 Australian Law Journals in an article entitled: 'Do we need a new Constitution?' He answered the question in the title 'No, but we do need to rethink the present one very substantially and we should have a convention to do it'. There are people in the present Government who appreciate these difficulties. Many people on all sides of politics are prepared to work to solve them. I believe that we can take a very significant step along this path together by voting-I hope unanimously, without dissent-in support of the motion which is before the Senate tonight, supporting in this way the idea for a further session of the existing Convention this year and thereby conveying our view to the Premiers Conference tomorrow that from all sides of this Parliament there is a belief in, and a commitment to, the idea that the process of constitutional rethinking should continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a statement which I made to the Senate on 24 September last year entitled 'Constitutional Review' I acknowledged the resurgence of interest in the possibilities of constitutional reform. I think there was some momentum in this regard in 1976 and 1977 when, the Senate will recall, a Constitutional Convention was held and followed by a referendum which was, one might say, surprisingly successful, certainly in the context of the general history of referendums in Australia. In that atmosphere another Constitutional Convention was held in Perth in 1978. I think it is fair to say that that Convention was not a successful one. Nothing seemed to emerge from it. There was no concensus which would have encouraged any referendum proposals. There may have been some value in meeting, but by and large nothing very specific or encouraging emerged from that convention. However, it is true, as I acknowledged in September and as Senator Evans has emphasised in his remarks tonight, that there is now a renewed interest in the subject. I welcome that interest, which indeed I made clear in the statement I made in this chamber on 24 September. I stated then-I think all I can do tonight is to restate it-the Government's attitude in relation to the holding of another Constitutional Convention. Certainly, that possibility has been considered by the Government but the view of the Government is that there should be another plenary session only when there are substantial proposals which have been sufficiently developed and digested to form the basis of a successful meeting. Furthermore, we need to have the views of the States in relation to holding another Convention. They form a very important part of the Convention and therefore it is not much use having another one unless they are prepared to co-operate and show some enthusiasm towards having one.

SPEECH.PARA: One standing committee of the Convention has been working since 1978. That committee last met towards the end of last year and commissioned some further work to be done. Some of the sub-committees that were set up then are working now. A number of papers have been commissioned by various constitutional experts , most of which probably have now been finalised and submitted. I believe that there is still quite a bit more work to be done before sufficient material is digested, along with other subjects for debate, some of which have been suggested by Senator Evans tonight. Others may come to mind as a result of further considerations in Committee D or further suggestions that may be made. However, undoubtedly quite a number of positive steps are being taken along the path of constitutional review which may give some encouragement to the idea that a further Convention would be justified and might be successful.

However, at this stage the Government has an open mind. We take a neutral position on the motion before the Senate tonight. As I have said, we are interested in the prospect of another Convention but we believe that it is no good holding one unless sound preparation has been made for it, there is a willingness and spirit of co-operation about holding it and there is a prospect of success. Senator Evans has suggested-I said this in my statement-that the Government should take an opportunity to consult with the States. That matter is fact has been put in train. On the agenda for the Premiers Conference to be held tomorrow is this question of the attitudes of the States to the holding of another Constitutional Convention. We will be particularly interested in what the States have to say. We will be interested in what is said in the Senate tonight. We will take into account the views expressed and we will have regard to the progress that is taking place in Committee D. I hope that in the not too distant future we may be in a position to reconsider the question of holding a convention. Whether it should be held later this year is a matter which will have to be considered in the light of the circumstances at the time the matter comes before the Government again. As I said, the Government is in a neutral position on this motion. We are interested in the debate here and the views expressed. We will be consulting with the States tomorrow at the Premiers Conference. I hope that the work of Committee D will progress to a stage where there may well be a number of sufficiently well researched, well prepared topics to form the basis of an agenda for any future meeting of the Convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it will warm the cockles of Senator Evans's heart, always assuming he has one, to know that the Australian Democrats are a little more than lukewarm, as was the Attorney- General (Senator Durack), in our reaction to his proposal. Senator Evans should enjoy it while he can.
—You have to lift your constitutional purity.
—Actually I have high hopes of our presence lifting the constitutional purity of the Constitutional Convention but I will get to that a little later.
—Provided you do not change your minds.
—That is not a monopoly we have and, furthermore, I have not changed parties.
—That is a good one. I have no reply to that, none at all.

—That is not particularly relevant to this debate although it may be relevant to other elements of Senator Martyr's lifestyle. The Australian Democrats support quite strongly the concept of a constitutional convention. Furthermore, we support equally strongly, as I said, Senator Evans's motion that a further session should be held in Adelaide this year. It is a concept that Senator Chipp is particularly keen on. The Leader of the Australian Democrats in South Australia has been involved in previous constitutional conventions. That was inevitable, since he is a lawyer and lawyers seem to find it extremely difficult to keep their noses out of constitutional matters-something which has caused most of the problems.
—Someone has to be interested.
—I think many people are interested. Unfortunately, lawyers carry their interest to absurd lengths and turn the constitutional conventions into self-perpetuating litigation exercises.
—That is politicians, not lawyers.

—Perhaps it is a fatal combination of both. That applies to politicians of all political parties who are lawyers at the same time. What we are at least unanimously agreed on, from lukewarm to red hot, is that the Constitution that this country has at the moment is seriously out of date and is in need of change. Unfortunately, the parties, the individuals and the community organisations involved are not as ready to agree on the direction and the detail that the constitutional changes and the considerations of constitutional amendments should take. For all Senator Evans's optimism, this disagreement and the acrimony involved on occasions has considerably impeded the progress of previous conventions. I attended as an observer the 1978 Convention in Perth. If it seemed pointless to those, like Senator Evans, who took part in it, it seemed absurd to those of us who were simply watching it.

SPEECH.PARA: Sentor Evans-You could be forgiven for that response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Evans. You are too kind. I am not saying that disagreement amongst delegates is a bad thing any more than disagreement on the different sides of this chamber or within parties, as Senator Missen would know, is necessarily a bad thing. I am saying that it has in the past caused problems because of the intense partisanship of some of the delegates to the conventions- a partisanship which, very clearly, has increased since 1975 despite what Senator Evans asserts about the concensus being achieved in the 1976 and 1978 conventions.

SPEECH.PARA: Compounding the problem of amending the Australian Constitution has been the fact that, over the years, referenda in this country have been turned into mini- elections. That applies regardless of whether they have stemmed from constitutional conventions or not. Of the 38 items presented to the people of Australia between 1901 and 1977 only eight have been agreed to. This proportion will have to change dramatically if the results and benefits jof the constitutional conventions that are held in the future are to be readily effected. The dismal record of the response of Australian electors to the various referenda that have been put to them has not been helped by the Constitution's own requirements-somewhat straight jacketing requirements they are-that ratification requires not only a majority of voting support but also a majority of State support. It is not always easy to combine the two.

Quite clearly, it was never envisaged in the early determination of the Australia's Constitution that partisan politics would develop as bitterly as they did so soon after the drafting of the constitution initially. That is not to say that ideological differences did not exist before the turn of the century , merely that considerably less vitriol and considerably more desire for compromise were present in debates and decision making than appear to exist today, at least in some areas. What some members of this chamber like to refer to as a spirit of friendliness and co-operation certainly was more apparent during the making of our original Constitution, it would appear from all the records that have been kept, than has been evident in any constitutional convention that has been held since then. This no doubt, had a lot to do with the composition of the group and with the sorts of men who attended the 1891, 1897-98 conventions. They were predominant small Liberals although there were some hard line conservatives. I think-Senator Evans will correct me if I am wrong-ther was only one Labor delegate. These people, because basically they were small 'l' Liberals, were much more open, I think, to compromise and conciliation than might have been expected.

Their flexibility and determination to look to the future and put aside rigid ideologies made them much more ready to look to the needs of the coming Federation and the requirements that its people would face. This is certainly something that some delegates in more recent conventions could learn from: I suggest this means that what we need in future constitutional conventions are more middle of-the-roaders and fewer extremist elements so that, while there may still be divergences of opinion over emotive issues, such as the power of the chambers and what the High Court of Australia should or should not be allowed to do, there is much more likely to be some spirit of conciliation and compromise. The fact that the 1978 Convention consisted very largely of some largely rather bitter debating on the powers of the Senate and the relative strengths of the upper and lower Houses indicates only that some things never change. One wonders , for instance, whether, under present day conditions, a man like James Henderson Howe would have succeeded in what in his day was an extraordinary achievement in getting age pensions included in Part V. of the Constitution or whether men like Kingston and Higgins would have had their way on the still contentious matter of industrial arbitration powers. I suspect not.

Even something as apparently trivial as Abbott's inclusion of astronomical and meteorological observations has proven of great value to Australia. For instance , if Reid had his way in 1897-98 it is quite likely that Australia would not have achieved what it has in the field of radio astronomy. However, notwithstanding all that it is an unarguable fact that the serious obstacles placed in the way of altering the Constitution, and placed there for the very best of motives by the original drafters, have impeded attempts to bring the Constitution up to date or in step with a rapidly changing world. A lot of the problem stems from the fact that there is no permanent, truly independent body in existence which can look regularly at the Constitution and recommend changes which can be put directly to the people without the added circus of partisan political interference. Senator Evans suggested a sort of popular convention. It has been suggested by John La Nauze that this very idea of a permanent independent body which constantly looks at the Constitution for anomalies and needs for amendment would be the best way of going about it. Unfortunately to date all that we have been able to come up with has been a Convention which is made up of members of parliament, largely lawyers, local government officials and community representatives. The last two groups have tended to be swamped by the rather loquacious nature of the legal delegates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the lawyers.

—Most legal delegates are lawyers. I am not saying that none of the Conventions that have been held during the 1970s have achieved anything because I do not believe that that is true. In fact, considering the obstacles, I make the point that they have achieved a great deal. Judges of the Federal Court of Australia now no longer hold office until they die, regardless of their ability, effectiveness of incipient senility. Territorians are no longer non- people and are able to vote at referenda for constitutional alterations. Housekeeping amendments of one sort or another, which relate among other things to the numbers of Ministers and their salaries, have been made. However, we are still awaiting implementation of the 1976 Hobart resolution on the question of defamation. We all know what problems have been caused by section 15-the section that relates to casual Senate vacancies-both before and after its amendment in 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the pleasant things that Senator Evans had to say about the 1978 Convention in Perth, it was turned into a three-ring circus because of the security arrangements that prevailed at the time. This was partly due to the fact that there was a Cabinet meeting in Perth at the same time and partly because of reaction to the Hilton bombing. In adition, that Convention spent the largest part of its time bickering futilely and acrimoniously about the powers of the Senate and the referral or otherwise to the High Court of questions regarding the validity of federal parliamentary legislation.

Nevertheless, despite the problems inherent in expecting a convention consisting largely of members of Parliament to settle their ideological differences long enough to concern themselves with what John La Nauze called ' the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth of Australia', these Conventions are better than nothing. For that reason the Democrats support the motion before the Senate. I agree with Senator Durack that we do need details of proposals, that it does need to be well organised, that the States do need to approve them and that we do require their co-opeation because otherwise the great deal of work that is done in preparing papers and treaties and so on is simply wasted.

However, I am disturbed about one other factor that is involved in future Conventions and that is that the resolution defining the composition of the Senate delegation remains the same as the one moved by Senator Withers in 1978. If that was not the same it was very similar to the composition of the Senate delegation in 1976. It makes no allowance for the fact that there are other members of Parliament other than Labor or Government members. It seems to me-I made the point in 1978-a rather extraordinary action by any government to ignore the existence of senators who do not represent either of those two party affiliations-either Labor or Government members-but do represent a not inconsiderable number of voters. In the case of the present Senate that amounts to well in excess of one million voters. I do not think it unfair to suggest that perhaps one of the 16 Federal parliamentary delegates should come from a senator who is either an independent or a member of a minority party.

In 1978 I suggested an amendment to Sentator Withers' motion which, for a variety of reasons, including, I suspect, a certain amount of lily-liveredness on the part of senators on both sides of the chamber, lapsed for want of a seconder. The amendment that I moved in 1978 is, I think, still pertinent now. I ask senators from both the Government and the Labor party to consider the merits of the amendment which was moved on 26 May 1978. It is readily available for perusal. In effect it simply removes any mention of party affiliation with regard to the composition of the Senate delegation. Instead of mentioning two Liberal and one National Country Party senator and three Australian Labor Party senators, it refers to three Government delegates and three non-government senators as delegates. I do not think that is an impossible request for this Parliament to consider. It leaves room for the Senate, rather than the Government, to decide which, if any, independent senators or senators from minority parties may be included amongst the delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think the number is much too small?

—Unfortunately it requires a motion passed by both Houses of Parliament. This is rather incredible because it implies that the House of Representatives is involved in Senate business. It is therefore not practicable for me to amend this motion. If Senator Missen is obsessed by the number of senators on this side of the chamber, in either independent or minority groups, who would care to be incorporated as part of the delegation, I suggest that he consider the reason for one National Country Party delegate out of three National Country Party senators coming from the Government side. I suggest that, since non-ALP members make up twice that number on this side, we have at least equal right to some representation. If this idea is unacceptable to the major parties, one wonders just how serious they are in their attempts to change the Constitution by consensus for the good of all and how much they are simply bent on point scoring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak but briefly in a debate that has gone for some little time now. I support the motion moved by Senator Evans, namely, 'that the Senate supports the holding of a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide this year'. However, after less than one hour of debate on this motion in the Senate, I am not sure why we have inflicted it on ourselves. Nevertheless, there are some serious issues that need to be considered. I do not intend to canvass those issues in any detail tonight. Senator Evans gave us a pretty thorough rundown on the issues that may or may not be involved in any constitutional review. I do not want to canvass those issues; I will just make a couple of points from a slightly different point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: The lesson of past constitutional conventions is that if the object of the exercise within the Convention is either grandstanding by politicians or compromises that are hammered out between politicians, without due regard or sensitivity for the people who will finally determine the outcome of them, then they are a waste of time. In the hope that some lessons have been learnt from experiences with the Constitution in recent years, I would support the holding of a further constitutional convention in an attempt to get some momentum into the issue. It is very important that we do not just shrug our shoulders about very real difficulties that exist under the present Constitution. However, we ought to bear in mind that it is possible that after as thorough a review as we may make of our Constitution we may find that, in fact, very little change is either necessary or practicable.

Much reference has been made to what is happening in Committee D of the Constitutional Convention, which is, of course, the Committee with which the Senate would be the most concerned. It is my very earnest hope that those who work in Committee D review the lessons of the fate of the first issue in the 1977 referendum. I do not intend to review the issues of that referendum, but lessons should have been learnt from them. One of those lessons, and one of the most salient lessons, of the 1977 referendum is that it is not enough for political leaders to agree in a way that suits the leaders if they have overlooked fundamental factors in the electorate and in the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —And if they try to gag them through this chamber.

—I understand the honourable senator's depth of feeling. I was being very restrained in trying not to re-raise those issues. On the one hand, we cannot be complacent. We must recognise that there are real issues related to our Constitution that deeply trouble a large number of people. On the other hand , I think it would be as well to realise that there are a large number of issues which may deeply trouble two or three people here which are of no import at all to the general mass of people. That does not necessarily mean that we know better; it may well be that the people know better than we do about what is important to them. In that context, one should always ask the question: What is the purpose of a constitution? It is a legal document that the people of this country live under.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, of some of the instances that have been raised the most notable one is that of courts and jurisdiction. In that case a lot of average people who do not consider that something as esoteric as a constitution, something as perhaps awe inspiring as the courts and something else called Parliament, has much relevance to them in their day to day lives. They receive a rude shock when, through an unfortunately common personal circumstance they find that they and their children are put through quite harrowing situations because of this particular quirk of the Constitution which relates to jurisdiction of the courts . More people will be aware of that; that is an outstanding example. For that reason I think we need to show a willingness to continue to look and attempt to improve things where we believe they can be improved and should be improved.

Whilst there are some areas that clearly cause problems that must be resolved, it must be clear also to Australians that the motive of seeking a resolution through some change in the Constitution is not a political one. There is, we must face it, in this chamber a basic distrust of the motives of politicians when they start to rearrange power in a legal document. One of the lessons of the 1977 referendum, I believe, was a reaction on the part of many people to just that issue. Without the people necessarily wanting to hear great arguments about the technicalities of what the power of the Senate ought to be and what the power of Prime Ministers ought to be, there was in my experience-it was not part of a campaign-there was a totally spontaneous response within the electorate. It was not a very flattering one, but I cannot deny that it is a fact. A number of people said to me: 'If Mr Fraser and Mr Whitlam want to do this, something is wrong; so I will vote no'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Evans laughs. In a sense, I suppose it is amusing but those people who had that hunch were right: There was something wrong when an ex -Prime Minister and a current Prime Minister were so enthusiastic about the subject of their powers versus the Senate. I do not want to canvass that issue. That is an illustration of why we have to be enormously careful. For that reason there are good arguments for making sure that a lot of people are involved, that the best possible advice comes forward, that all the important angles are canvassed, that all the relevant material is brought up and we are in a better position to judge it. We can stand here tonight and debate the Constitution. We can push our little barrows on this and that. But, in fact, what we say here tonight might be utterly irrelevant to the Australian electorate. For all we know, after undertaking this process and perhaps working on it very hard over several years, we might find that the ultimate judgment from the Australian people for all our labours is that they really do not want it changed. That would have to be a verdict that would have to be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we need a broad involvement and a wide consultation. However, the last thing I want to say is that in all circumstances, whoever is doing this , whether it be the Constitutional Convention or some review committee, whether it be a convention broadly-based or narrowly-based, whether it even has the Australian Democrats-if it is that broad-whatever the composition of the people who are talking about it, it must always be in the context of reality. One has to be a little careful here when making comments on the Senate and the Senate's powers because the purpose of tonight's exercise is not to open up a debate about the Senate's powers. But as a Queensland senator I want to put one caveat on this entire thing. I hear people saying all the time: 'The year is 1982. It is 80 years since Federation. We have a document that is 80 years old. It is irrelevant in large part and we must rewrite it so that it is relevant to Australia of the 1980s'. They may have a point. Nobody is suggesting that the principles of Magna Carta are irrelevant just because they are old. Principles that have been established for some time are not necessarily wrong because they come from a previous age. It is very important in this context that people do not delude themselves on this point. The very specific instance I am given over and over again relates to the Senate and to division of powers.

I invite any Victorian or New South Wales member of parliament who has this view to spend a little time in my State, not because there is anything peculiar about my State-not at all. They would have a good time, but they would learn a lesson. They would learn that the fundamental free trade versus protection debate that had so much to do with the present structure of the Senate is as strong and as real in terms of day to day life and in terms of its real effect on the citizens of Queensland as it was 80 years ago. Those people, recognising the reality of a particular economic program and of particular policies, still would look to a situation in which there is some balancing factor in power. I mean no offence to any New South Wales or Victorian senators here tonight. But protection policies favour them more. They are not aware of the sharp effect in terms of political reaction that they have in a State such as Queensland. They are not aware of the political reality that that throws up for anyone within Queensland attempting to move through the political process.

That does not mean, of course, that I am saying that Queensland politicians are crass and that they capitalise on it. I am one who will continue, on behalf of Queenslanders, to speak on the subject of protection and free trade and all the issues associated with it, not because I must just because I am a Queenslander but because it is in the national interest. It is important that most, if not all, of our citizens feel that on the whole they are getting a fair deal, that there is some sort of safeguard there for them and that, if there is one area of government policy that clearly is not in the interests of one region, there is some balancing factor. That is an essence of what our nationalism is about and I believe that is an essence of the debates of the founding fathers. In my opinion very substantial parts of the Constitution are still relevant. If we discover through the process of debate only why those parts are still relevant and exactly what they are we will have moved a step forward because we will have brought a little more enlightenment and understanding to those who lead this country as to what those factors are.

I am sure that in the next few years there will be many occasions on which we will discuss this matter at great length, and I am sure that in the near future there will be some occasions on which we will discuss them at some length. I think there has been some value in saying a few words to Senator Evans's motion tonight. I am pleased to support it. I do not support it in any half-hearted way . I appreciate that it may happen that the Constitutional Convention is not necessarily held in Adelaide and that it may be held on 2 January next year. I note that Senator Evans is nodding his head. Nevertheless, the Senate is making its intent clear: To proceed rather than to put aside the fact that there are real concerns about our Constitution is the far wiser event. I hope that those who proceed will proceed with some courage and some vision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make the shortest speech on this subject tonight and I do not think I will have much trouble doing that. I got the impression that the approach of those on this side of the chamber who spoke earlier was perhaps a little lacking in great enthusiasm for the proposal and, as one who is very keen on the idea that there be a Constitutional Convention, I think I should say so. I believe that it is important that the momentum of constitutional change be kept up. The fact that we have not had any meeting of the Constitutional Convention for approximately four years is rather serious and I think it is important that we close that gap as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not to be taken as necessarily being happy with the idea of a parliamentarians' convention as perhaps being the solution in the long run. I think it is important that we meet again and look at the functions of these meetings and the way in which they will be held. I am a strong supporter of a popularly elected convention. I think ultimately that will be required. At least it may require the addition to the membership of the present Constitutional Convention representatives outside the present ranks of Federal or State politicians. At the moment it is really a State members' convention. The great mass of them-I think some 78-are State delegates, and the Commonwealth has some 16 delegates. Senator Haines was upset tonight about not getting on the Convention. She is not alone in that. Various others of us have had the greatest of difficulty trying to get there by some device or other. In fact back bench members of this Parliament generally have a tough job trying to get any involvement in these conventions because the Commonwealth component is very small. Maybe the Commonwealth component ought to be increased. I think it certainly should be. Irrespective of how it develops, I think it is important that we maintain an interest in constitutional reform. The results of previous conventions have been useful in the context of the relatively mild successes which we have had. Even the unsuccessful constitutional change of 1977, to which Senator Martin referred, won 62 per cent of the vote throughout the whole of Australia. Unfortunately in some of the more extraneous areas of Australia the message did not get across. I think it was badly handled in the early stages. A number of us said that at an early stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy per cent of Tasmanians made their decision-
—Yes. There is one per cent of Australia on one side. Unfortunately Tasmanians have not voted for constitutional amendments much.
—Yes, they have.
—No, I do not think their record is too good. We will take that matter up later, but I will be very delighted to hear that I am wrong.
—You are not, Senator.

—I thank Senator Evans. Tonight has presented an opportunity for people to produce their own pet ideas in regard to constitutional change. That is not very relevant to the current motion. The current motion states that support should be given by this Senate to the holding of a new convention and that we should encourage this course in the meetings that take place in the next few days. I certainly strongly support that motion and I hope it will get strong support around this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support-I hope relatively briefly-the motion moved by Senator Evans and supported by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I do so not because I support the words used by Senator Evans when he talks about constitutional reform; I prefer to use the term ' constitutional review'. I do not think we have an argument except that Senator Evans is more enthusiastic about reform and I am more enthusiastic about review, but perhaps they both amount to the same thing.
—Perhaps we can agree on 'rethinking'.

—I accept the suggestion. I regard the Constitution as an extremely important part of the life of every Australian, of every aspect of Australian life. We ought to consider constantly whether we have a need to change the Constitution, whether we are satisfied with what is happening, whether we understand what is happening and whether we are making the most use of what we have. It is for those reasons that I support totally the idea that we ensure that there is a reasonably regular review in a society, in an economy and in a world which is subject to rapid change in every way. I do not think we can sit back and say we will let one of the most fundamental things governing the whole of our society, outside natural laws, sit there without giving thought as to whether it is adequate. Even if the process does no more than create an awareness of what is, it is worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that what is must be is a philosophy which we should adopt. I do not suggest that simply because we have a Constitution we should say that that Constitution must remain for ever and a day unchanged. Nor do I say that because it is, it ought to be changed simply so that we can have the face of change. Somewhat jokingly the other day I took up a suggestion made by somebody discussing this subject that the problem is to get the apathetic mass to consider the Constitution and to talk about it. I suggested that perhaps I could be described as being on the radical wing of the apathetic mass in that I was prepared to talk about it. Whilst not regarding myself in any way as a campaigner for reform, I am a campaigner for review. I think that that is a legitimate position to take along with the others who would like to see a republic of Australia, along with others who would like to tear up the document and along with others who would like to leave it absolutely untouched and never discussed. There is room for those views. My own view is that we should constantly be reviewing, debating and understanding the processes.

I can hark back only to the sort of jolt that we can get in relation to the Constitution. I am a very firm believer in the preservation of our Federation, in the preservation of States' rights and in the preservation of a clear division as to who in this country fulfils one function and who fulfils another. I have taken a particular interest in the development of what I should have thought, in the view of our founding fathers, was clearly intended to be a national function and not a State by State function. That is something which you , Mr Acting Deputy President, also had some views on and interest in. One of the things that were clearly in mind at the time of drawing up the Constitution was that we should have one national approach to trade, to transport, to communications and to the essential controls in relation to trade, including company law.

After years and years of work we at last got to the stage of having round two of a national approach. We got a uniform Companies Act at the end of the 1950s, a decade after the Second World War had given a whole lot of people the idea that perhaps we needed some changes in some things like that. We found that within a year the uniform Companies Act was the non-uniform Companies Act. Now we find that before we have finished passing the package of legislation under the co-operative federalism approach in relation to the new system for a national companies and securities code and the creation of a national commission , all of which has been accepted by the whole of Australia, we have been double- crossed-there is no other word-by the States. Whilst we solemnly passed legislation agreed to by the Ministerial Council and presented to this Parliament as the product of the Ministerial Council, giving powers to the national commission which the legislation which we had to pass would create, when the States came to deal with it they revised the powers and reduced the powers in relation to hearings. They reduced those powers to make ineffective the work of the National Companies and Securities Commission, to the degree that that commission has now been very substantially denuded of its powers by the judicial decision in Queensland. Unless amendment is made it will, I believe, remain a neutered body without the most essential power for which it was created and for which it should exist. If that is to be federalism then I believe there is a very strong argument for constitutional reform as opposed to constitutional review.

I go back to the way I started. I have been-I think people who know me would accept this-a States righter in most ways in the preservation of the rights of the small States in particular. I have objected particularly to what Senator Martin was talking about-the protection racket which as I see it is imposed by a populous majority of Australians against the interests of the more economically productive areas of Australia. That may be justified. But when there are people who solemnly enter into a co-operative federalism approach, who then surreptitiously change what has been agreed to the stage where without informing this Parliament and in breach of the arrangements, the understandings, which are the fundamentals of the Maroochydore agreement in relation to the whole of the companies and securities agreement, they introduce legislation which has an entirely different effect, then I believe there is every case for constitutional review if not reform.

There are many matters for discussion. I do not propose to attempt to discuss them all. Senator Martin mentioned one of the matters of great concern-the protection racket-whereby the populous States are seen by many as ripping off the resource-based or more industrious States. We have a situation where industrial disputation and inflation inducing and international trade complicating disadvantages tend to be generated under the protection of the protection umbrella to the disadvantage of the remainder of Australia. These are matters that need to be taken into the balance. There are questions about human rights. There are suggestions that we should have a human rights Bill. There are questions in relation to that that are often talked about. One of these is not often talked about; that is, the right to work. Have people a right to work within a free society? What are the legitimate constraints upon someone's right to continue to work? I am not anti-union. Having had a long experience of being a legal counsel for a whole series of unions I hope that I would be regarded not as a union basher for mentioning this. But I think this is an important issue.

What is the nature of the right to work? What is the legitimate extent to which someone's right to work can be curtailed? Under what circumstances should it be curtailed? What is the degree of accountability? We have talked often about accountability in relation to ministerial responsibility. We talk about accountability in relation to statutory authorities-the quangos. What is the accountability of somebody else who can significantly affect the ordinary operation of our society, the ordinary operation of the individual rights and opportunities of our citizens? Is there a need to provide for some system of acccountability in relation to the trade union movement and what might be described as its ministerial equivalents, the leaders? If ministerial responsibility is to mean something is there some requirement that other people who have similar responsibility entrusted to them should have some greater degree of public accountability than appears to exist at the moment?

There is the matter of the popularly elected convention. I believe that that, too, must receive further consideration for a number of reasons, some of which have been canvassed tonight. I do not pause to develop them at this stage. It may be that what we ought to look to is a two-tiered discussion of constitutional review or constitutional reform, whichever term one chooses to adopt. I doubt that we will get the answer by having a whole lot of executive appointed representatives from the parliaments of Australia. I doubt that we will get the answer and its implementation by simply having people at conventions who are nothing to do with the exercise of executive power in Australia. Obviously for implementation of the responses from a constitutional convention or constitutional discussion one needs to have a relationship with and some sympathy from those who hold current executive power. It may be that we can work out a way, a sort of electoral college concept, of having a broad-based discussion about the areas of concern and the areas which people believe need some change and then bring together something closer to the representatives of the executives, or at least the representatives of the parliaments, for some form of implementation.

A broad cross section of questions need to be addressed if this nation of ours is to obtain the greatest advantage from a working, operating constitution. I warmly support the idea that it is not in any way a waste of time or a waste of effort to join together to debate issues related to the Constitution, however frustrated one may feel at times at the lack of progress which appears to be made in resolving one way or another what the result ought to be. If it does no more than turn people's attention to the questions, if it does no more than remind people of the importance of the Constitution, I think it serves a useful purpose. I am glad that Senator Evans has brought on this motion tonight. I trust that tomorrow the Premiers Conference will have regard to the debate which has taken place. I am delighted as a member of the Government parties here to be in a position to support the motion. I hope that we will be seeing a further constitutional convention in the near future; I make it no more limited than that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
