TALK.START.PARA: —I looked very closely at it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, that says something for the way General Business is conducted in this chamber.
—I hope it is not the same speech.

—I do not propose to repeat that speech, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would not inflict that upon the Senate. But there are one or two brief points-I stress the words 'brief points'-which I think are worth saying on the subject and which I did not say earlier. I will take the liberty of doing so now. I will not be very long about it because we had a very lengthy debate on this matter earlier in the day. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I repeat that we perceive the enrichment of uranium as being definitely the first step on the path towards proliferation of nuclear weaponry. This is a move to which all Australians would not really want to contribute. Indeed, the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation Conference, which was composed of representatives from over 60 countries, reported that the proliferation risk is inherent in enrichment technologies. The earlier report of the Uranium Advisory Council which we are considering here recognises this and speaks of the need for the application of effective international safeguards to enrichment facilities so as to have accurate material accounting and effective surveillance measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) dealt briefly with this matter. At this stage I draw attention to the fact-I think the Senate should note this-that the Uranium Advisory Council has mentioned the need for upgrading the functions and status of the Australian Safeguards Office, implying that that Office is restricted in its capabilities at present. I think the more complex the situation becomes on the supply of Australian uranium the more tangled the skein becomes overseas. Of course, it is becoming more and more tangled with every day that passes. If we are to honour our obligations and do the things which Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned earlier as those we wish to do, we have to beef up the Australian Safeguards Office and give it all the facilities and staff that it needs to carry out its very important functions. That is one of the additional points that I would like to make.

A further point is, of course, the costs and market for enriched uranium. The present operating capacity for enriched uranium is 48,300 tonnes in the Western world and another 12,000 tonnes is planned to be ready by 1985. But according to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, among many other expert groups in this region of the world, the expected world demand for uranium hexafluoride will be much less than supply right through until the 1990s. In other words there is already much more in the world than we can consume. In short, there is an international over-supply of uranium hexafluoride. This will continue for many years to come. Is this the climate in which there is any sense at all in Australia considering setting up a uranium enrichment industry? Indeed, every year since 1974-75-some way back now-the AAEC has reduced its estimate of world uranium demand. In 1978-79 it began reporting that there was no requirement for further enrichment capability world wide.

It has been said that the uranium enrichment plants have had a better safety record than the remainder of the industry. Senator Sir John Carrick made this point earlier. I point out that this is only because the small number of enrichment plants distorts the statistics. Let me illustrate examples of what has happened. On 2 July 1977 the security personnel of the COMURHEX plant at Pierrlatte, Southern France, sealed a major leak of highly corrosive uranium hexafluoride gas. The accident was caused by 'an error on manipulation by a staff member'. Quite simply somebody made a mistake. I suppose we might almost say that someone made an error of judgment. The accident caused the local area to be sealed off before the materials pollution could be contained. Nevertheless , it happened. The same thing happened again--

TALK.START.PARA: —They can insure against that.

—Yes, they can insure against that. That is an excellent point, Senator. The same thing happened again at the same plant in November of the same year, only four months later. On 6 December in that same year uranium hexafluoride gas was spilled into the atmosphere from a test rig at Capenhurst enrichment plant in the United Kingdom. There were three major incidents in that year when the whole of the Western world had only four enrichment plants.

SPEECH.PARA: I merely want to make a final point-a bottom line as it were. When the bottom is falling right out of the future market for uranium, and one can look as far ahead as one likes to go and the projections are all bad, what is the sense of even taking up time in considering this highly expensive, complicated and dangerous industry for establishment in Australia? The Australian Democrats feel that it is a pity that the Uranium Advisory Council has not grasped the nettle in its final report and made it quite plain to the Government that the facts will demonstrate that we should say no to any uranium enrichment in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that Senator Mason cut his remarks short tonight because those of us who heard the debate this afternoon in which the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, participated, would have heard all of the arguments that Senator Mason used during that period decisively and conclusively demolished. I can only conclude that the Australian Democrats are taking so many somersaults that they have become quite giddy. They are losing their touch with reality. I suggest that while they want to win the seat in Western Australia that they are seeking so hard, they are moving further and further away from that possibility with the line that they are taking. Even the Australian Council of Trade Unions has recognised that its view is quite different from that taken by the Democrats. I point out to Senator Mason that the trade union movement generally, in Europe in particular, constitutes the leading resistance to the anti-nuclear groups. If Senator Mason and his party would like to get on to a popular issue I suggest that they abandon this one as quickly as possible. As I said, they are being left behind.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason mentioned that the Uranium Advisory Council report, which is the subject of this debate tonight, suggested that by 1990 the world will be needing much more enriched uranium. I point out to him that that is only eight short years away. I suggest to him also that the technology which is used for the production of enriched uranium is being developed at a rapid rate. There are two established processes already. Work is being done using the laser beam; that is more advanced technology. Even the lead time to build the structures would be at least eight years if we started today. Senator Mason's suggestion that we should not start thinking about this issue until the time comes when the world is short of uranium shows that he is keeping his head totally in the sand. I wish to outline some of the conclusions reached by the Council. The first conclusion is:

The Council accepts that the AAEC possess the necessary technical skills and experience, as a result of the research that it has already conducted into the centrifuge process, to advise on and if necessary participate in the planning, construction and operation of a plant, and that the Australian industrial structure provides an existing basis for the manufacture of some of the necessary component machinery for a centrifuge plant.

That is encouraging news. The Senate Committee on National Resources, that I happen to chair, did some work recently on solar energy. That was one of the bases of Senator Mason's arguments this afternoon in a previous debate. It was demonstrated very clearly during that Senate Committee's inquiry-a view which was supported by three members of the Opposition-that apart from some areas of industry application the wide and broad use of solar energy is a long way off; also that the amount of energy needed to construct some of these more advanced technologies in solar energy is greater than is ultimately produced. The second conclusion was that:
The Council does not regard itself as competent to offer a valid judgment as to the economic viability of an enrichment project.

That second conclusion can be understood if one goes back to the Fox report which recommended the establishment of this Council. The Council was to be made up of people not closely involved with the industry. If we look at the members who make up the Council we see that there are none who are expert in the area of high technology. So that second conclusion is perfectly understand- able. The Council's third conclusion states:
The Council notes that while certain of these effects-
That is, the chemical and other waste discharges at the constructional and operational stages of an enrichment plant-
would need to be assessed in respect of specific conditions at a particular site , the normal routine operation of the plant would be such as to have little or no effect on the environment.
The fourth conclusion reads in part:

The Council must assume that the Commonwealth Government would not authorise the establishment of a commercial enrichment plant without ensuring that it was subject to the effective international safeguards, institutional controls and surveillance measures that the INFCE Working Group believes can minimise the risk of diversion of low enriched uranium for production of weapons grade material.

That leads me to the first point that Senator Mason made in his contribution. He sees a definite link, a complete link, between uranium enrichment and the production of atomic weapons. That view was demonstrated by Senator Sir John Carrick this afternoon to be totally invalid. There is no connection whatsoever. In fact, the Council, in its report, says so quite clearly. It says that the quality of the enriched uranium produced is no closer to the atomic weapons process than ordinary yellowcake. The final conclusion reached by the Council is that:

. . . it can see no valid reason against the Government's proceeding with a study of the feasibility of, and perhaps participating in the establishment of, a commercial uranium enrichment industry in Australia.

Finally, I wish to repeat the point that if, as the Council suggests, by 1990 the world will be needing more uranium, Australia, as potentially one of the cheapest producers of uranium, has a duty not to ignore the fact that the lead time between now and 1990 is so close that we need to be working very hard now so that we are ready by then to produce this enriched uranium.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate views with grave concern the double standards of the Prime Minister in continually refusing to answer repeated calls from Senator McLaren since 1976 to provide the Parliament with the cost to the Australian taxpayer of his, Mr Fraser's, occupancy of the Lodge, when he so readily provided the costs of occupancy of the previous Prime Minister in answer to a 'Dorothy Dix' Question in the House of Representatives on 24 March 1976.

I had to give notice of that motion on 26 November 1980 because I found myself frustrated over a long period in trying to ascertain from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) what it was costing the taxpayer to keep him in residence. Had the Prime Minister been an honest man, as he claims he is, he would quite readily have made that information available. He did not want to do so because it would have been of some embarrassment to him. But after coming to office he was very smart in trying to embarrass the Labor Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. I will quote from the Senate Hansard of 16 September 1980, a date on which I raised this matter. That was only one of the very many times I raised this. In dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1980-81, I said:

I am also concerned about the costs incurred to run the Prime Minister's Lodge. Whenever I raise this matter I am told that it has been the practice of all governments not to divulge the costs of the official establishments. Again this year I asked about the cost of official establishments. An answer came back, no doubt from the Prime Minister's Department. Again, it was stated that the traditional principle is not to supply cost figures for individual establishments.

I raised that question because the honourable member for Barker, Mr Porter, after the Liberal-National Country party coalition came to office in 1975, put a Dorothy Dix question to Mr Fraser on official residences of the Prime Minister. At page 1084 of the Senate Hansard of 16 Sepember 1980 I quoted that question. I said:
A Dorothy Dix question was addressed to the Prime Minister on 24 March 1976 by Mr Porter, the Liberal member for Barker. It was headed 'Official Residences of the Prime Minister'. It stated:
My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House of the cost last year of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House?
Off the top of his head, Mr Fraser was able to say:

I do not have the figures for the whole of last year but have them for the last part of the year for both places. In the last six months of the last year the Lodge cost the Australian taxpayer $64,941.

I was quoting from the House of Representatives Hansard when I used that information. Mr Fraser went on to talk about the cost of Kirribilli House, but I am not concerned about the cost of running Kirribilli House and I was not at that time. Mr Innes, one of the Victorian members, interjected:
Tell us about Manila. Tell us about Singapore.
Of course, as I said on 16 September, we all know what that interjection referred to. My colleague, Senator Walsh, interjected:
It is Question No. 3381 on the 1975 Notice Paper.
In reply, I said:

We cannot get an answer to that; yet we can get an off-the-cuff answer about the cost of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House when Mr Whitlam was the occupant. After the interjection Mr Fraser said:
Honourable gentlemen opposite do not like the facts of life about their leader. That is why they keep on trying to hide them. But I think that a few people have a right to be able to understand.

That illustrates the double standards of the Prime Minister to which I have referred in the motion before the chamber tonight. He had all those figures available at his fingertips very early in his life as Prime Minister in an endeavour to embarrass Mr Whitlam. He said that Opposition members did not like the facts of life about their leader being revealed. He said that he thought quite a few people had the right to know and a few people had the right to be able to understand. If the Prime Minister made that statement on 24 March 1976 why did that same principle not apply every time I asked a question about the running of the Lodge since he had become the occupant? Of course I could not get an answer.

At that time I had to resort to the method I have now used, that of giving notice of a motion to this Parliament to see whether we could flush him out. However, following the effluxion of time, during an Estimates debate in this chamber after the Australian Democrats were elected and the Goverment no longer had the numbers, Senator Chipp entered into a lengthy debate in which I was engaged in an attempt to get this information. He gave a warning to the Government that if it did not produce these figures the next time they were asked for the weight of numbers in this place might hold up the workings of the Senate until they became available. What was the outcome? Lo and behold, when I asked a question during the hearings of Estimates Committee C, of which I am a member, on Tuesday, 15 September last year, some of the figures were made available. The Prime Minister was not game to let the Senate take him on because he thought it might delve into a lot of other things. We got some of the costs of running the Lodge. But what has to be borne in mind is that included in this figure of $64,941 quoted by Mr Fraser for the running of the Lodge for the last six months of Mr Whitlam's occupancy would have been the cost of all the foodstuffs, the refreshments and drink of all kinds. Everything would have been included. What do we see in the figures that were given at the meeting of that Estimates Committee on 15 September of last year? There was nothing at all about foodstuffs, drink or refreshments. All the figures referred to are general maintenance, mechanical maintenance, electrical maintenance, bathroom and toilet fittings, carpets, furniture, shelving, hire of equipment, glassware and all sorts of other things in the nature of repairs and maintenance or flash furniture and crockery purchases for the Lodge.

Let us look at the figures. The actual expenditure in 1980-81 was $121,065, excluding all the foodstuffs and drink. The estimate for 1981-82 is given as $ 135,000. There we have an increase of $14,000 from one year to the next just for capital equipment-for repairs and maintenance and for whatever the Prime Minister might want to spend on bringing the Lodge up to his standards. But there was nothing about foodstuffs. Of course, that is something that we will be pursuing when we consider the Estimates after the Appropriation Bills are introduced here in a week or two. While Mr Whitlam was in office he put on a party at the Lodge every Christmas for every person who worked in Parliament House. Of course, the cost of all that was included in the answer Mr Fraser gave . Mr Fraser is known to be a very wealthy man, but he is rather mean in many respects. He does not ask the staff of Parliament House to the Lodge every Christmas as Prime Minister Whitlam did to show his appreciation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be doing it again very soon too.

—Of course we will be doing it, and the Lodge will be open to those who serve the people in this Parliament. Furphies were put around the place that one of the rooms at the Lodge was full of intoxicating liquor. The Prime Minister was trying to imply that Mr Whitlam was a person who over-imbibed . Those of us who have known Mr Whitlam for many years know full well that his main drink would be orange juice or cordial.
—He kept that booze there for when Kerr came calling.

—Of course, he was not game to have it there; he had to have it locked up when Kerr was about the place. The point is that, although Mr Fraser was able to get that furphy going around the place that Mr Whitlam was a boozer and that all the taxpayers' money was being spent, Mr Whitlam was not spending anywhere near as much, including what was spent for the benefit of the staff of Parliament House and any member of parliament who wished to go to the Lodge and have a Christmas drink with him. As I said, Mr Fraser does not put on any of those things for the staff of the Parliament because it would be beneath him to have ordinary workers go inside the gates of the Lodge; he would not suffer them .

SPEECH.PARA: The Ombudsman has now pointed out that, with the passage of the Freedom of Information Bill in this Parliament, we have the wherewithal to take some action . The Government will not be able to hide this extravagant expenditure which it tries to hide. It kept it hidden for years until, with the assistance of Senator Chipp, we were able to force it to give us the information about Government House, Admiralty House, the Lodge and Kirribilli House. It is all set out in the Estimates Committee Hansard of 15 September 1981 for the people to see. Yet for many years Mr Fraser said that those figures could not be separated. Now they are separated, but I warn the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who is in charge of the Senate tonight, that the next time we go before an Estimates Committee we will want to know just what it is costing the taxpayer to feed Mr Fraser and what it is costing Mr Fraser to entertain his colleagues from high places every time they come to Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a millionare.

—Of course, he is a millionaire many times over, but the more money he gets the more money he wants and the more he wants to rip off the poor people. We know that pay-as-you-earn taxpayers are the ones who cannot escape one cent of income tax. But people like Mr Fraser, primary producers, have many avenues to do so. I know, because I was a primary producer at one time. The Taxation Office publishes a booklet to tell primary producers of all the lurks and perks by way of claiming income tax deductions. It is there in black and white for those who want to read it. I have made my point. I warn the Government of what the Ombudsman has said. I will quote it for the information of people who were not here earlier today. He talked about the extensions of the function of the Ombudsman's office and then said:

SPEECH.PARA: A third likely extension of function is to be found in the Freedom of Information Bill which passed in the Senate shortly after the close of the year. The Bill provides that a person unable to obtain access to information may make a complaint to the Ombudsman under the Ombudsman Act 1976. In this fashion a person will have an alternative avenue of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The establishment that I am most concerned about is the Lodge. I used to accept what the Prime Minister said and what my own leader said about not revealing those figures. Had Mr Fraser not got someone to do some homework and separate the cost of running the Lodge for the last six months of occupancy by Mr Whitlam , I would not have pursued the matter. But because he took that opportunity to belittle the Labour Prime Minister he deserves to be pursued and made to eat his words. I quote them again. These are Mr Fraser's words:

Honourable gentlemen opposite do not like the facts of life about their leader. That is why they keep on trying to hide them. But I think that a few people have a right to know and a few people have a right to be able to understand.

Those words are very much applicable to the present Prime Minister. They are words that he uttered himself, and I throw them back at him. We have a right to know and the taxpayers have a right to know what it is costing them to keep that gentleman in luxury at the Lodge. The sooner he comes clean and tells us, the sooner he will not be criticised in this Parliament. The reason I had to resort to giving a notice of motion on 26 November was to try to get the support of the honourable senators opposite to ensure that when members of this Parliament, no matter which side they are on, ask for details of expenditure of taxpayers' money we will be given an answer. All we want is an answer. If honourable senators opposite do not deem it fit tonight to support this motion, I think it can be safely said that they are in agreement with the action that the Prime Minister has taken over the years. He is quite prepared to reveal what the costs of the Lodge were when the Labor Prime Minister was a resident there, but honourable senators opposite are prepared to support their Prime Minister in a big cover-up by not allowing the taxpayers of this country to know what it is costing to keep the present Liberal Prime Minister in office. I commend this motion to the Senate and I ask for full support for it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate views with great concern the continued refusal of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, to answer repeated calls from Senator McLaren for information as to whether he has provided the previous Governor-General with a free telephone service between Great Britain and Australia, and, if so, what has been the total cost to the Australian taxpayer.

I will not speak for long to this motion because this is another typical matter to which I cannot get an answer from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). It again gives me great satisfaction to know that the Ombudsman in his report has pointed out to us another method by which we can get information. Ever since the previous Governor-General was exiled from this country I have been trying to find out what it cost the Australian taxpayer to have him installed in the United Kingdom and particularly what it is costing the Australian taxpayer for his telephone. There is no doubt that he has an office because I received last year an answer from the Department of Administrative Services telling me that that Department provides him with an office. My belief was reinforced by an answer given to my colleague Senator Keeffe when on 11 November he asked for some details about the office. Senator Carrick sent the following answer to Senator Keeffe during the recess:
On 11 November 1981, (Hansard, page 2007) Senator Keeffe asked me as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question without notice, concerning the cost of facilities for Sir John Kerr.

The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

It has been the practice of successive governments to provide former Governors- General with office facilities, a secretary and access to car transport. The expenditure is covered by parliamentary appropriation. In London, Sir John Kerr has facilities available in line with this practice.

So there we have it in black and white. Not only did I get an answer from the Department of Administrative Services but also my collegue Senator Keeffe now has an answer from Senator Carrick to the effect that the former Governor- General in exile does have these facilities in London. We will then be able to flush out the whole cost to the Australian taxpayer of keeping this man in London and particularly the cost of the telephone. We are entitled to know the cost; it is public expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fred Daly wants to know.

—Yes, Mr Daly wants to know. The King of Canberra certainly would like to know. He could write a good book about it if he got the information. As we are told in the answer to Senator Keeffe's question, the expenditure for all the facilities for the ex-Governor-General in exile is covered by parliamentary appropriation. Yet when we have the Appropriation Bill before us and we ask questions about this expenditure we are told, as we were told about our request to have separated the costs of the Lodge, Kirribilli House and Admiralty House: 'It can't be done'. As I have said, the Commonwealth Ombudsman has given us a clue as to how it can be done. I warn the Senate now that if we cannot get the answer when we are dealing with the Appropriation Bills very shortly it might be in for a torrid time. I give that warning. In all fairness to the taxpayers of the country who are being squeezed to death at present by high income tax and high interest rates, I think that they have a right to know. I commend my motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate in discussing this matter. As often happens in this place one is caught unawares by the calling on of a motion which appears on the Notice Paper. I put this motion on the Notice Paper on the 26 November 1980. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into poverty in Australia and the additional information required to determine changes affecting the nature and extent of poverty since the publication of the reports of the Australian Government Commission of Inquiry into Poverty.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

That inquiry was the well known Henderson inquiry. Normally when caught in these circumstances one would have debate on this motion delayed but in view of the discussion that has taken place in the newspapers and on the media in the last couple of days about social welfare expenditure I believe that it is worth saying a few words, initially at least, in support of this motion. Since the production of the Henderson inquiry's main report in 1975 there has been some discussion-I believe it has not been adequate discussion or discussion on a high enough plane-about the incidence of poverty in this country, what we have done about it and what we could do about it.

Very few changes have been made to the social security system since the thoughtful and careful recommendations of the inquiry headed by Professor Henderson. Professor Henderson has continued to be active in the field and to take a great interest in the subject, but it seems that too often the Government has found the problem too hard. One thing that the Government did was to establish an inquiry into the measurement of poverty in the country. It was embarrassed by the fact that social security payments and welfare payments in general resulted in large groups of people being consistently below the poverty line as established by Professor Henderson and his co-commissioners. The Government, rather than increase expenditure or redirect funds to these people to get them above the Henderson poverty line-the only acceptable and recognisable poverty line that we have-decided to conduct an inquiry into the subject. The result of this inquiry was, in the minds of most of us, very disappointing. The inquiry seemed to come to the view in its rather general findings that poverty was something that was subjective, that it was in the eye of the beholder and that we had no real way of measuring it; it was too hard. Therefore in one chapter it came to the extraordinary conclusion that those who used the Henderson poverty line should have to justify its use and its accuracy whereas in other cases there was no real measurement of poverty.

Geoffrey Barker, after reading this report, wrote in the Age of 21 November 1981 a critical article, the final words of which I believe are worth quoting because they sum up the situation as many of us see it. He pointed out throughout the article-as many of us see it-the unsatisfactory nature of the report, referring to the way in which the report thought that the problem was too hard. Often addressing his remarks initially to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, finally he said:

Senator Chaney would do well to recognise that we do have a clear concept of poverty. It may be relative; it may be fairly arbitrary. And it may not be possible to define the concept in necessary and sufficient terms.

But it is recognisable: you know it when you see it (even if a lot of poverty is not immediately visible). It is therefore reasonable . . . that poverty is something in the world, and not just in our heads. There are real states of affairs corresponding to it; real people are suffering because of it.
The challenge facing social scientists is to find adequate ways of assessing it ; the challenge facing Governments.
It is a challenge facing Parliament--
is to implement action to ease it. Neither can avoid the issue by simply insisting that poverty is something in the eye of the beholder. That is a counsel of despair or moral cowardice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was this article published?

—It was published in the Age of 21 November 1981 and was written by Geoffrey Barker. I think his words are worth quoting and worth this Parliament taking note of. In fact, parliaments and governments have to do something about poverty. To insist that poverty is something in the eye of the beholder, in the way in which the subsequent report appears to have done, is in fact a counsel of despair and moral cowardice. Therefore we should take note of what Professor Henderson and his colleagues developed between 1972 and 1975. We should make sure that the findings that they produced and the data on which they produced them are continually upgraded so that we in this Parliament have some real concept of what poverty is, where it is and what we should do about it. One of the first statements in the findings of the poverty report which was released in 1975 made the quite clear statement that when poverty before and after housing is compared, fatherless families are clearly the poorest group. Since then, on any comparison of groups in the community likely to be in poverty, fatherless families and lone parent families, 90 per cent of which are headed by women, are the poorest group. They are consistently below the poverty line. They are consistently the ones in great difficulty. A greater percentage of them are poor than applies to any other group in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is disturbing and coincidental that, on the day this notice of motion comes before the Senate, we should see reports in the Press about this very group of people. In particular, we heard reports on the radio last night about Government members and this group of people. I refer to the Queensland Government supporter , Mr Donald Cameron, who is well known for his obsession about lone parent families, particularly deserted wives. Mr Cameron is also known as the gentleman who organised a party in the Parliament one night, the star event of which was a young lady jumping out of a cake to give pleasure to those members of Parliament who became members at the same time as he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —She did not have much on either.

—She did not have much on. Of course, all the members present were males. Mr Cameron's admiration for the female sex does not extend to those women in the community who head fatherless families and who are dependent on government expenditure. He has a particular obsession with those women who, because of domestic strife and violence, have had to leave their homes and seek assistance. He makes a fairly harsh judgment upon them. I refer to what he said on PM last night. He tries to make out that he is a reasonable man and that he believes that there are some women who need help, and he defined them. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Now let me make it clear now. If there is a woman out there who has been belted every night for a month by a drunken husband, I have no argument whatsoever if she has got to flee that household situation and be supported because she is a woman in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —Presumably if he lays off for one night-

—I agree with Senator Haines. If she is belted once a month, once a week or once every two nights apparently it is not reasonable for her to leave . It is her duty to stay at home and cop it. But if she takes that treatment for a month-we do not know whether Mr Cameron means 28, 29 or 30 days-he will concede that she is in need and it may be reasonable for the community to give her some assistance. He has said such things in the past. He persistently makes speeches inside and outside the Parliament about what he sees as hordes of lone parents wandering around the community taking money out of the public purse. He has a general obsession with the level of welfare expenditure but he has a particular obsession with lone parents.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, lone parents are usually the poorest in the community. There is no incentive for them, because of the nature of the means test in our social security system, to go out to work. The harshness of the means test affects not only the level of income they receive from their pensions but also the assistance they receive through fringe benefits. They have to suffer, as well as inadequate social security payments, the scorn of people such as Mr Cameron and his colleagues who seem to pick on this group because they are not organised politically and not large in number. He does not see them as a threat to the votes he needs. He sees them as a convenient group to pick as a scapegoat in his crusade against welfare expenditure.

Professor Henderson and his colleagues came out with a disturbing report which told us that many more people than lone parents were in difficulty. We all knew that. As honourable senators know, he and his colleagues came to the conclusion that 10 per cent of families were in difficulty. They said that fatherless families and recent migrant groups were in particular difficulty. The figures Professor Henderson gave related to 1972-73. He said that the unemployed were also a very poor group as were females and large families. There were many others in difficulty but they were the groups that Professor Henderson picked out in particular. Since the report of this inquiry came out unemployment has increased enormously. We have made changes to our benefits system so that single unemployed people in particular do not receive the benefit of regular indexation and regular increases in payments. Recently the standard pension and benefit has dropped to a level of 22.4 per cent of average weekly earnings, the usual parameter on which we judge the value of pensions and benefits. We know that projected figures suggest that by June this year that level will be down to about 21.6 per cent of average weekly earnings.

There has been no attempt to continue the work of the poverty commission to monitor the level of poverty in the community and to ascertain where it is and who is suffering from it. Obviously, we know from our experiences with the voluntary agencies, and the assistance of the Department of Social Security and the State departments of social welfare that there have been increases in poverty in certain areas, particularly the western suburbs of our two great cities, Sydney and Melbourne, where unemployment is so high. Unemployment is again very high in our rural areas. We know that there has been a general increase in unemployment but we do not have exact figures. We do not know exactly what is happening. We know that housing is becoming an increasingly difficult problem and that people are unable to afford their own houses because of increasing costs and interest rates. This throws more people back on to the private rental market and into the welfare housing area. It therefore puts pressure on those very needy people who have traditionally relied on this area. We know from Professor Henderson's report that housing and its cost are absolutely crucial to the determination of whether someone is in poverty. The poorer one is, the higher the percentage of one's income that will have to be spent on housing.

There are many factors which we need to know if we are to plan sensibly our attack on poverty and achieve not only its alleviation but also its prevention. There are many facts and figures which we should have known from the Census but which were limited because of the Government's short-sighted attitude towards asking sufficient questions about getting sufficient information. We could cull a lot of information which we do not have from welfare organisations, both government and non-government. This Government and the Parliament simply cannot plan properly and judge sensibly welfare legislation and welfare measures until they have this data and some means of evaluating the effectiveness of their programs. The fact that we do not have this knowledge allows people like Mr Cameron and his colleagues to make ill-conceived, heartless and unfair attacks on groups in the community. If Mr Cameron is not attacking lone parents, Mr Lynch is saying that unemployment is a myth and that the unemployed are all dole bludgers. Our ex-colleague in this place, Senator Sheil, used to talk continuously about dole bludgers who were, to use an unfortunate expression he once used in this place, fornicating on the foreshores and somehow striking at the economic heart of this country by eating up our welfare funds.

This ill-informed debate goes on and such people are able to attack the welfare system. They are able to do it firstly because in many cases there is inadequate information about the extent and nature of poverty, and secondly because in times of economic difficulty people in the community are always willing to look for scapegoats. People such as lone parents and the unemployed are convenient scapegoats for those in employment and who are well off. It is because of this that we need to extend our knowledge in this area so that Senator Chaney, or whoever else is Minister for Social Security, his colleagues and public servants can properly plan and properly present proposals to this Parliament; so that the Opposition and welfare agencies can make sensible proposals about what should happen to the welfare scene in this country, and so that we can have a sensible and rational debate. We believe there should be an on-going oversight as to just what is happening in this area in the community. It is for this reason I still consider it reasonable that a Senate select committee should take up where Henderson and his colleagues left off and look at the situation as they saw it. Henderson said in his report that it was only a snapshot of the poverty situation at one time in Australia.

I believe that a Senate Select Committee should be set up so that we can have continual monitoring of just what is happening in this difficult area in the community and, above all, so that we can have an informed debate. We would not have to put up with the sort of headlines we saw on the front page of the Australian today and we would not have to put up with the ravings of Mr Cameron on PM last night.

It is for those reasons that I moved this motion. I hope that at some time the Senate will support such a motion. I realise that the time available to debate this motion tonight is short. This motion has been sprung on myself and the Senate tonight because of a sudden decrease in the verbosity of the lawyers who spoke earlier. However, these things happen and I hope that this debate can continue at another stage so that we can all develop our arguments more carefully, look at the problem more closely and perhaps come up with an inquiry from this chamber. In the past Senate Committees have produced bipartisan reports which have looked carefully at problems like this in the welfare area. They have been useful to governments but they should have been more useful to governments on more frequent occasions. If the Minister for Social Security is willing to continue the debate at another time, I am certainly willing to join in. As mover of the motion I suppose I will get a second bite of the cherry when closing the debate at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would welcome a debate in considered terms on the subject raised in the motion moved by the Opposition spokesman on social welfare, Senator Grimes. Like him, I express concern about the fact that there does exist in Australia some element of what we would describe, without any argument, as poverty. There is nothing in the report which was put down by the social welfare policy secretariat which suggested that that was not the case. The situation is that that report, whatever other contribution it might make, has already served to some extent to clarify the debate on poverty in this country. For example, I note that prior to the issuance of that report it was commonly said by people who are concerned about poverty in Australia that there are now more than two million people who live in poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the useful things stated in the report was the careful application of the statistics available to the Henderson poverty line. The number of people who might be regarded as being in poverty-if one accepts that line-is assessed as being in the order of one million, or slightly more-about the same level that applied in the early 1970s. Those who claimed two million people were in poverty, prior to the issuance of that report, now seem to accept and state that the figure is about one million.

TALK.START.PARA: —That must make you feel good.

—Senator Grimes says: 'That must make you feel good'. I confess it does not make me feel particularly good. To identify a group of one million people who might be in need of greater assistance is a more productive thing than identifying two million, four million or five million. The view is based on common sense. If one can isolate those who generally need assistance one can provide assistance to them. The job is possible. However, on the other hand, if one tries to apply a broad blanket measure to the whole population of Australia it is unlikely that any success will be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: There is very little time to continue the debate this evening but I wish to make some brief comment on the concern expressed by Senator Grimes about the fact that the supporting parents benefit had been raised in public discussion recently by Government supporters in the House of Representatives. I do not think it is surprising or that it is objectionable that the rapid growth in the numbers receiving supporting parents benefit should give rise to some debate. It is a fact that there was a very large increase in the total number of sole parents who were assisted between 1973 and 1981. The number of sole mothers assisted has increased to about 120,000 and sole fathers to 6,000. The increase is very considerable. Currently I think it would be the fastest growing area of the benefits system and that is a matter which naturally attracts attention. One is entitled to ask: 'What are the social implications of the changes which are occurring?' In a welfare system in which the demands, almost by definition, exceed the supply of money which is available, one is entitled to ask whether any particular section of the benefits represents the best possible application of moneys.

I do not believe a single Government supporter would deny that mothers who are supporting children without the assistance of a husband are people whom the community ought to be concerned about, both for the sake of the mothers and the children. But a growth of from somewhere around 20,000 to 120,000 over a few short years suggests that changes are occurring in the community about which all members of this Parliament ought to be concerned.

When one looks at the breakdown of the figures there is room to be concerned about the growth of families which consist of an unmarried mother and a child or children. One is equally entitled to be concerned about the very rapid growth in the numbers of divorced or separated families who require the support of the State. There is no time to develop that point this evening but I suggest that that sort of change occurring in Australia over a relatively short period is something which deserves attention.

The only other point I wish to address this evening, in the very limited time available before the adjournment, is the social welfare policy secretariat discussion paper which was issued late last year. I think it makes a valuable contribution to the discussion of poverty in Australia. Indeed, the findings which it makes seem to be consistent with the current views put forward by Professor Henderson and his associates and are consistent with the views which have been put forward by the social welfare agencies with which I have had contact. For example, the report indicates that whilst the number of people who may be described as being in poverty under the Henderson measurement has not changed to any great extent, the composition of that group has changed over the last ten years. One finds for example that on the basis of theoretical measurement the relative position of the aged has improved. So one finds that the theoreticians, both of the social welfare policy secretariat and, as I understand it, also of Professor Henderson-I am relying here on his published comments following the release of the secretariat report-say that in a relative sense the position of the aged has improved. They would also say, commonly, that there is a larger number of single parents and a larger number of unemployed who might be in a position of real hardship in the community.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Australia Day Committee- Parliamentary Appropriations and Staffing

PROCTEXT.PARA: National Australia Day Committee- Parliamentary Appropriations and Staffing

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I respond to a question that was asked by my colleague Senator Lewis and responded to by my colleague Senator Peter Baume yesterday. Senator Lewis was rather selective in reading from the editorial of the Courier-Mail of 9 February 1982 in supporting his question of Senator Peter Baume. The part he read from the Courier-Mail said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Middle Ages learned academics gathered for the medieval equivalent of weekend seminars to discuss how many angels could dance on the head of a pin.
What he failed to do was to read the last part of that editorial, which says:
The Australia Day committee is worried about the lack of patriotic fervor.
The truth is that most Australians have pride in their country but there is an appalling ignorance about it and why we have Australia Day.
That is where education is needed.

That was the final paragraph of the editorial of the Courier-Mail, but my colleague was very selective and failed to read it. Tonight I rise to defend the Chairman of the National Australia Day Committee, Mr John Newcombe, from an unwarranted attack, one which I might add originated from a totally unexpected quarter. Senator Lewis cast aspersions on the Committee, of which I am also a member. He questioned, in my opinion, the integrity of the Committee when he suggested that it might be functioning outside the limits of its charter. He also denigrated our efforts by suggesting that we were committing a folly. I am sure that I speak for my Chairman and fellow members when I say that we take our duties most seriously. No doubt the honourable senator will receive a detailed reply from the Minister outlining the scope of the Committee's charter. I am sure that that will be forthcoming. However, in the meantime, I quite categorically state that it is within the Committee's charter to promote an awareness of the Australian identity, and to encourage people to focus on what it means to be an Australian, what is so special about this nation and why it is necessary to defend it and our way of life should it ever be threatened. In what better way can this be achieved than by holding a seminar and pooling the ideas of the many ethnic and cultural groups which are now represented in our Australian population?

John Newcombe has not suggested that he, his Committee or the many people who will contribute to such a seminar will come up with the complete answer. But it is a starting point and is innovative in that it has never been tried before, to my knowledge. If it does what I am confident it will do, that is, promote an awareness as to what it means to be an Australian, then in my opinion and in the opinion of the Committee it is not a waste of money. Perhaps Senator Lewis has some ill-informed opinion as to the mental capabilities of sports men and women and believes that because of their physical attributes they must be lacking in other areas. If this is so it is, in his words, 'folly' as this Committee was formed some three years ago under the chairmanship of Mr Herb Elliott, whose academic qualifications cannot, I believe, be challenged even by such a distinguished lawyer as the honourable senator.

I think Senator Lewis underestimates John Newcombe, or 'Newk', as he is known to his myriad of fans throughout this nation and indeed in every country of the world. With the publicity he has already received has he not, indeed, achieved the aim of the Committee? People, the Press and other media have already started to question what an Australian is and what it is to be an Aussie. Even Senator Lewis has now put his point of view forward. What the Committee has done has at least got people talking and thinking about whether we have an identity crisis.

In conclusion I reiterate my and my fellow members' confidence in the Chairman and my disappointment that a member of this chamber has sought to question the capability and, indeed, credibility of perhaps Australia's best-known and best- loved son, a man who by his sporting prowess, humility and great national pride has shown this nation and the world at large what a great ambassador he is and in every respect what it is to be a proud Australian. Therefore, on behalf of this man who has no doubt as to his true national identity may I deliver to Senator Austin Lewis a full-blooded backhand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise tonight I intended to raise by way of a question at Question Time today. But because I did not get the call I raise it tonight in the hope that I will receive an answer to my question next week. I had hoped that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) would be in the chamber to give me an answer tonight but she is not here.
—Let us give it a try. I have some information.

—Senator Peter Baume says he has some information. I asked my Whip's Office to send a message to the Minister that I would be raising this matter tonight. The matter relates to the way in which the Government is squeezing various departments, particularly the Department of Administrative Services. I want to find out whether the same squeeze is applying to the Parliament. Before I pose my question I remind the Senate of a report to the Senate of Estimates Committee A in October of last year. I will read page 2, which deals with parliamentary departments. The committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: A feature of the examination of the Estimates of all four parliamentary Departments was the Government decision, effected by the Department of Finance in negotiations on the original estimates, to impose a 3 per cent across-the- board cut on proposed expenditure, only in the case of the Parliamenary Reporting Staff was that decision reversed.

Even more disturbing was the fact that, following preparation of departmental estimates in accordance with the 3 per cent across-the-board reduction, further reductions in proposed expenditure were made by the Government without consultation with the Presiding Officers, which, as Mr Speaker indicated during hearings of the House of Representatives' Estimates Committee A (H. of R. Hansard, 8 September 1981, pp. 2 and 3), was clearly in breach of well- established arrangements. The Department of the Senate, for example, made bids totalling approximately $174,000 for the upgrading of printing equipment and for the purchase of a six-station word processor. The Committee was advised by the Department that both bids were substantially rejected. Similiarly, the Parliamentary Library had imposed upon it a further reduction of 18 per cent for reprographic services. The Joint House Department, too, found that $50,000 had been subtracted from one bid, and $117,000 from another, without explanation or consultation.

In addition to these general and specific reductions in proposed expenditure, all Parliamentary Departments examined were limited by a directive on staff ceilings and each department suffered a nett loss of full-time positions.

The Committee expresses its grave concern at the unilateral imposition of government controls upon the Parliament, and draws attention to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, which it trusts will soon be debated at length in the Senate and to which it recommends that the Government give urgent consideration.
Under the heading 'Departmental Priorities' the report states:

Given the constraints under which the Parliamentary Departments were forced to operate in the preparation of the Estimates, the Committee expresses some surprise at the priority accorded certain items in the Estimates it examined.

Then the report of Estimates Committee A goes on to deal with the Parliamentary Library. I will not engage the time of the Senate in discussing that matter tonight. I was disturbed today when my leader, Senator Button, posed a question to Senator Guilfoyle about a matter which was raised on a television program this morning. It must have been an early program. Senator Button asked:

I ask the Minister for Finance whether she said on a television program this morning that the Department of Administrative Services had 'mishandled' instructions from the Government to reduce spending.
Senator Guilfoyle answered Senator Button's question and then Senator Button asked a supplementary question. He said:

I wish to ask the Minister a supplementary question. Firstly, do the instructions which were issued apply to the Parliament? Secondly, is it normal practice for a Minister to send directions of this kind to a department without informing the Minister who is responsible for that department?
Senator Guilfoyle said:
Which instruction was sent by a Minister to the Department? I seek clarification of the second part of that question.

Senator Button gave a clarification of the second part of the question but Senator Guilfoyle did not answer the first part; that is, whether these restrictions in expenditure applied to the Parliament. There is no record of her having answered that part of the question. The question I wanted to ask the Minister today, and I ask it now, is this: Has the recent direction of the Department of Finance on further restricting expenditure been issued to the Houses of Parliament as well as to Government departments? If the answer is yes, does this mean that the Government has completely ignored the concern expressed by Estimates Committee A and endorsed by the Senate and that it is now treating the Parliament with contempt?

Last Tuesday I raised with the President a matter concerning the Parliamentary Library. I had a discussion with him about that matter today and I am assured that an answer will be forthcoming next week after he has had discussions with the people in the Library, so I will not pursue that matter tonight. Now that the Minister for Finance is in the chamber I would like to know whether I can get an answer to the question I posed to her tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the early part of Senator McLaren's comments with regard to the Estimates Committee but I take it no response is required with regard to that matter. I will make my remarks and if there is any further comment to make I will do so. With regard to the expenditure for both Houses of the Parliament, a practice and procedure has been established between the leaders of the Houses and the Presiding Officers. The negotiations at present with regard to the Additional Estimates would have been discussed between Mr President and me this evening had I not been on duty in the House. Senator Bonner has been concerned that the question, which was asked by my colleague Senator Lewis, may in some way have reflected upon the Chairman of the National Australia Day Committee, Mr John Newcombe. SPEECH.PARA: I did hear Senator Lewis address the question of whether a seminar as proposed is the best or most appropriate way of achieving the goal which the National Australia Day Committee has identified as a desirable goal.
